column1: 457`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/rev/supp_info/TaxApplicationandAffidavitForms/HardshipApplication2012_Finance.pdf`Success`Success`15`10`Not a fillable PDF.`FINANCIAL HARDSHIP APPLICATION  1) Who should apply? - This Financial Hardship Application (“Application”) is a request for an agreement between  a business or an individual and the Chicago Department of Finance (the “Department”) that resolves the business’s or individual’s tax liability to the City of Chicago.  Under section 3-4-153 of the Municipal Code of Chicago
column2: the City Comptroller (the “Comptroller”)
column3: with the approval of the Department of Law
column4: has the authority to abate any tax liabilities that have been assessed when the Comptroller determines that there is an uncertainty as to the collectability of the assessment within a reasonable period of time.  The Comptroller’s decision will be made after a review of the recommendations presented by the Financial Hardship Committee (the “Committee”).  It is expected that the Committee will make its recommendation to the Comptroller within 45 days of its receipt of a completed Application
column5: and that the Comptroller’s decision will be made within 30 days of the Comptroller’s receipt of the Committee’s recommendation.  2)  3)  4)  5)  6)  7)  8)  Power of Attorney - If this Application is completed by someone other than a) an owner or officer of the business that has been assessed a tax liability or b) an individual who has been assessed a tax liability
column6: a completed  Power of Attorney form must be on file with the Department or submitted with this Application.  Completed Application - This Application is complete when all schedules and line items have been completed or answered
column7: and all supporting documents are attached or included.  The applicant will be contacted for any missing required information.  If no response is received from the applicant or the required information is not received within 45 days of the letter requesting this information
column8: the Application will be rejected as being incomplete
column9: and the Department will continue its efforts to collect the total amount of the tax liability.  Post Assessment Periods - The business must provide all City of Chicago tax returns for the periods subsequent to the close of the period for which the assessment or assessments has been made.  If these returns have previously been filed
column10: amended returns must be filed which conform to the methodology that the Department used in computing the tax liability on the notice of assessment.  Federal Income Tax Returns - Applicant must provide copies of applicant’s federal and state income tax returns that were signed by applicant
column11: including all schedules
column12: that encompass the periods of the assessment
column13: as well as any recent returns that include periods subsequent to the assessment periods.  Other Supporting Documents - All documents that support the applicant’s claim of an inability to pay a tax liability owed to the City of Chicago because of financial hardship should be included.  In addition to the documents requested in the Application
column14: supporting documents which must also be submitted are a) bank statements for the last six months
column15: b) debts secured by liens or mortgages
column16: and c) for individuals
column17: paycheck vouchers for the last two months.  Responsible Owner/Officer/Partner/Employee's Personal Credit Information - Any owner of a sole proprietorship
column18: or any officer
column19: employee
column20: partner or other individual who controls
column21: supervises
column22: or is responsible for the filing of Chicago tax returns or the payment of Chicago taxes must complete an application for himself or herself and provide and include personal federal and state income tax returns for the same periods as the business.  Related Entity - For purposes of this application

column24: partnership
column25: or other legal entity
column26: including but not limited to individuals
column27: that owns the applicant
column28: is owned by the applicant
column29: or is owned by the owner of the applicant.  Individuals are related if they are spouses
column30: parents
column31: siblings

column33: grandparents
column34: or grandchildren.     SEND YOUR COMPLETED APPLICATION TO:  FINANCIAL HARDSHIP COMMITTEE Chicago Department of Finance 333 South State Street

column20: Illinois 60604-3977             Refund Procedures and Instructions       The Real Property Transfer Tax (“RPTT”) is broken down into two portions:  (1) the City of  Chicago Portion and (2) the CTA Portion.  Qualified applicants are entitled to a refund in the  amount of the CTA Portion.  In no event will this refund extend to any amount paid for the City of  Chicago Portion of the RPTT paid.  Please review the transfer records to verify that the refund  applicant paid the CTA Portion
column21: as only the person who bears the burden of the tax (i.e.
column22: pays the  tax) is eligible for the refund.      REFUND PROCESSING PROCEDURES    Additional supporting documentation to substantiate a claim for refund may be requested. The  request for refund must be filed using the Department of Finance CTA Portion of the Real  Property Tax Refund Application. Refunds will not be approved if the applicant owes other tax or  non-tax debt (e.g.
column23: warrants
column24: parking tickets
column25: or water bills) to the City of Chicago.     After the Department receives a refund application
column26: the applicant will be sent a Notification of  Receipt of Refund Request acknowledging receipt of his or her refund application. The refund  process begins when the Department of Finance issues the applicant the above mentioned  Notification of Receipt of Refund Request.  The entire refund process can take up to six (6)  months to complete.    After the refund request is approved or denied
column27: the applicant will be issued a Notice of Tentative  Determination of Claim (the “Determination”).    If the claim is approved
column28: the applicant will be issued a refund.  Approved refund claims may  receive interest at the statutory rate beginning on the date the tax was paid in error and running  through the date the Department of Finance approves the claim in writing.    If the refund claim is denied
column29: the applicant may file a written protest within 35 days of the date of  receipt of the Determination. If the applicant files a timely protest
column30: a formal administrative hearing  will be scheduled. If the applicant does not file a written protest within 35 days
column31: the Determination  will become final and the applicant will lose his or her right to object to the Determination in court.    Please submit the completed refund application and all supporting documentation to:    Chicago Department of Finance – Tax Division  Senior Exemption Refund Unit  DePaul Center
column32: 333 South State Street – Suite 300  Chicago
column33: Illinois 60604-3977    If you have any further questions
column34: please call (312) 747-1964 or email   ctasr@cityofchicago.org.       Page 3 of 3

column1: 535`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/rev/supp_info/TaxRulingsandRegulations/Amusement_Ruling_4.pdf`Success`Success`3`3`Not a fillable PDF.`"CITY OF CHICAGO    DEPARTMENT OF REVENUE   AMUSEMENT TAX RULING    Amusement Tax Ruling #4  Subject:  Live Cultural Performance Exemption - DJ's  Effective Date:  December 1
column2: 2006   Section 1.  Background   In  general
column3: Section  4-156-020(A)  of  the  Chicago  Municipal  Code  (“Code”)  imposes  a  tax  on  amusements at a rate of eight percent:  ""Except as otherwise provided by this article
column4: an amusement  tax is imposed upon the patrons of every amusement within the city. The rate of the tax shall be  equal to eight percent of the admission fees or other charges paid for the privilege to enter
column5: to  witness
column6: to view or to participate in such amusement
column7: unless subsection E of this section provides  for a lower rate.""   Section 4-156-020(D)(1) provides an exemption for live cultural performances at venues with a  maximum seating capacity of 750 or under:  ""The tax imposed in subsection A of this section shall  not apply to or be imposed upon the admission fees to witness in person live theatrical
column8: live musical  or other live cultural performances that take place in any auditorium
column9: theater or other space in the city  whose maximum capacity
column10: including all balconies and other sections
column11: is not more than 750 persons.""   Section  4-156-020(E)  provides  a  reduced  rate  for  live  cultural  performances  at  venues  with  a  maximum seating capacity of more than 750:  ""The rate of the tax imposed in subsection A of this  section  shall  be  four  percent  of  the  admission  fees  or  other  charges  to  witness  in  person  live  theatrical
column12: live musical or other live cultural performances that take place in any auditorium
column13: theater  or other space in the city whose maximum capacity
column14: including all balconies and other sections
column15: is  more than 750 persons.""   Section 4-156-010 provides a definition of live cultural performance:  ""'Live theatrical
column16: live musical  or other live cultural performance' means a live performance in any of the disciplines which are  commonly regarded as part of the fine arts
column17: such as live theater
column18: music
column19: opera
column20: drama
column21: comedy
column22: ballet
column23: modern  or  traditional  dance
column24: and  book  or  poetry  readings.  The  term  does  not  include  such  amusements as athletic events
column25: races or performances conducted at adult entertainment cabarets (as  defined in Chapter 16-16 of this Code).""   The purpose of this ruling is to specify the situations in which the Chicago Department of Revenue  (“Department”) will consider the activities of a disc jockey (""DJ"") to qualify as a ""live cultural  performance"" at a dance club or other venue
column26: so as to qualify for the exemption or reduced rate set  forth in Sections 4-156-020(D)(1) and (E).   Section 2.  Requirements   In order for the activities of a DJ to be considered a ""live cultural performance"" at a dance club or  other venue
column27: the activities must substantially add to or otherwise modify the pre-recorded material  used by the DJ
column28: in the form of a significant degree of technical manipulation
column29: singing
column30: speaking
column31: dancing or other activity.   Section 3.  Safe Harbor   The Department will assume that the activities of the DJ qualify as a live cultural performance where  both of the following conditions exist:      a.   b.   The pre-recorded material used by the DJ was recorded by the DJ.  This may be original  work composed by the DJ or the work of other artists that the DJ has mixed or otherwise  modified.   The DJ is paid substantially above the rate that would be paid solely for the service of  playing the pre-recorded material of other artists.  As of the date of the issuance of this  ruling
column32: the  Department  will  assume  that  the  payment  of  $2
column33: 000  or  more  for  a  single  performance qualifies the event for this safe harbor.   Section 4.  Additional Factors   Where the activities of a DJ do not qualify for the safe harbor set forth in Section 3
column34: they may  nevertheless qualify as a live cultural performance if at least four of the five following factors apply:   a.	   b.	   c.	   d.	   The DJ is featured in advertisements for the venue.   The DJ is visible to patrons of the venue
column35: who spend a substantial amount of time observing  the DJ’s performance.   The DJ is featured more prominently than other amusements or activities available at the  venue.   The patrons are charged substantially above the amount that would be paid for entry into the  venue in the absence of the DJ.  For purposes of this ruling
column36: the term “substantially above”  means at least one and a half times the amount that would be charged without the DJ.   e.	   The DJ is represented by a manager and/or agent.   Section 5.  Proof   The venue has the burden of proving that it qualifies for the exemption or reduced rate set forth in  Sections 4-156-020(D)(1) and (E).  The proof required includes
column37: at a minimum
column38: a signed and sworn  statement concerning the requirements listed in Section 2 above
column39: along with any of the factors that   apply from Sections 3 and 4
column40: on a form to be provided by the Department.  In addition
column41: the venue  must attach to the statement a copy of the contract between the venue and the DJ.   Upon request
column42: the venue may also be required to provide the Department with books and records  showing the name of each DJ who performed at the venue
column43: the dates and times at which each DJ  performed
column44: and the admission fees or other charges paid by patrons to witness the DJ at each of the  dates and times at which each DJ performed
column45: along with such other documents and information as  the Department may reasonably require.   Section 6.  Procedures   If desired
column46: at least 14 days in advance of an event involving a DJ
column47: a venue may submit to the  Department the materials described in Section 5 above
column48: and the Department will endeavor to provide  the venue with an advance written determination of whether or not the event qualifies for treatment  as a live cultural performance.   "

column1: 1358`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/rev/supp_info/TaxRulingsandRegulations/URPORuling2.pdf`Success`Success`2`2`Not a fillable PDF.`CITY OF CHICAGO   DEPARTMENT OF REVENUE   UNIFORM REVENUE PROCEDURES RULING      Uniform Revenue Procedures Ruling #2  Subject: Reasonable Cause Standards to Abate Late and/or Failure to File Penalties  Effective date:  June 1
column2: 2004    Original effective date: February 15
column3: 1997    SECTION  1.  Under  the  Chicago  Uniform  Revenue  Procedures  Ordinance    (URPO) (Chapter 3-4 of the Chicago Municipal Code) and other Chicago tax ordinances
column4: taxpayers and tax collectors are subject to penalties for failing to file returns
column5: filing late  returns
column6: and making late payments. These penalties may be waived or abated if the return  or  payment  was  late
column7: or  was  not  filed  or  made
column8: due  to  circumstances  beyond  the  taxpayer’s  or  the  tax  collector’s  control.  In  such  cases
column9: “reasonable  cause”    exists  to  excuse the payment of all or part of a penalty.    Taxpayers and tax collectors bear the burden of establishing “reasonable cause.”    Each request to waive or abate the payment of a penalty must be made in writing to the  Chicago  Department  of  Revenue  and  accompanied  by  (1)  a  written  explanation  of  the  reasons why reasonable cause exists and (2) supporting documentation. Each request will  be evaluated on its own merits.    SECTION  2.    A  tax  return  or  tax  payment  is  timely  when  it  is:  (1)  physically    received by the Chicago Department of Revenue on or before the due date; (2) received  by  the  Chicago  Department  of  Revenue  in  an  envelope  or  wrapper  displaying  a  valid
column10: readable United States mail postmark dated on or before the due date
column11: properly addressed  to  the  department
column12: with  adequate  postage  prepaid;  or  (3)  filed  electronically  via  the  Internet through the City of Chicago website on or before the due date.    SECTION  3.  The  examples  set  forth  below  represent  some  of  the  “reasonable    cause” claims most frequently made by taxpayers and tax collectors. These examples are  not intended to be comprehensive.    A.  payment and/or failure to file penalties:      The U.S. Postal Service mishandled the mail and
column13: for this reason only
column14: the  envelope or wrapper containing the tax return or the tax payment was postmarked after  the due date. In such cases
column15: taxpayers and tax collectors must provide a letter written by  the station manager of the local U.S. Postal Service facility
column16: which establishes those facts.    The taxpayer or tax collector provides documentation
column17: which shows that    the business records of the taxpayer or the tax collector were destroyed by a fire or other  casualty and
column18: for this reason only
column19: the tax return or the tax payment was late or not filed.   In  the  following  examples
column20: “reasonable  cause”  exists  to  waive  or  abate  the  late   2.   1.   3.   4.   5.   The  taxpayer  or  tax  collector  reasonably  relied  on  erroneous  written       The  taxpayer  or  tax  collector  provides  documentation  which  shows  that  the tax return or the tax payment was late
column21: or not filed or made
column22: due to (a) an individual  taxpayer’s death or the death of a member of his/her immediate family or (b) the death of  a person having the sole authority
column23: on behalf of a corporation or a partnership
column24: to execute  or file the return or to pay the tax
column25: or the death of a member of such person’s immediate  family.      information as described in URPO Ruling #3.      The  taxpayer  or  tax  collector  relied  on  erroneous  advice  from  an  accountant or an attorney and
column26: for this reason only
column27: the tax return or the tax payment was  late  or  not  filed.  In  such  cases
column28: the  taxpayer  or  tax  collector  must  provide  either  (a)  a  letter  signed  by  the  accountant  or  the  attorney  which  specifically  states  that  he  or  she  gave the advice relied on by the taxpayer or tax collector or (b) a document prepared by  the accountant or the attorney which contains the erroneous advice.    The taxpayer or tax collector was unable to file its tax return electronically    via the Internet solely because the City of Chicago website was out of service on the date  on which the return was due.  The taxpayer or tax collector must demonstrate that it had  its  return  information  filled  out  and  saved  prior  to  attempting  to  file  the  return  electronically.    The  taxpayer  or  tax  collector  also  must  file  its  return  at  the  first  reasonable opportunity thereafter.    B.  payment of late and/or failure to file penalties:      The  tax  return  or  the  tax  payment  was  late
column29: or  was  not  filed  or  made
column30: because  the  taxpayer  or  the  tax  collector  was  not  aware  of  the  obligation  to  file  the  returns or to pay the tax. All taxpayers and tax collectors are required to know about their  tax obligations and to comply with all Chicago tax ordinances.      The taxpayer or tax collector delegated its duty to file the tax return or to  make a tax payment to another person (e.g.
column31: an accountant or an attorney) whom
column32: without  reasonable cause
column33: filed the return or made the payment late. All taxpayers and tax  collectors are required to know about their tax obligations and to comply with all Chicago  tax ordinances. Consequently
column34: they are liable for their delegates’ failure to comply with  Chicago tax ordinances.     In the following examples “reasonable cause” does not exist to waive or abate the   6.   1.   2.

column3: IL 60602   312-744-7124       The Direct Deposit Vendor Payment Program utilizes electronic fund transfers to  provide a timely
column4: accurate
column5: and convenient method of depositing funds owed to  vendors.    With Direct Deposit
column6: the hassle of mail delays and late deposits are eliminated.  Direct Deposit offers:  •  Assurance of Timely Payments  •  Convenient Payment Method  •  Simple and Easy Sign-up   Vendors participating in the Direct Deposit Payments Program ensure necessary funds are available for use as soon as possible.    Deposits are made directly to vendor accounts
column7: eliminating time consuming mail delays
column8: waiting in line at the bank
column9: and waiting  for availability of funds.     Instructions:   Complete the form below and submit it to the Department of Finance.  Attach an unsigned and voided check  from the account to receive direct deposits and send to the above address.   Note:  Direct Deposit for multiple contracts or purchase orders can be set up on this form.  Simply enter multiple numbers on  the line provided below.  However
column10: a separate form is required for each Direct Deposit bank account.     A        t t a c h v o i d e d   c h e c k h e r e      I  authorize The City of Chicago hereafter called  “The City
column11: ” to  initiate credit entries to  my banking account indicated below  and the institution named below

column13: ” to deposit to the same such account.   This authority is to remain in full force and effect until The City and Institution have received written notification from me of its  termination  in  such  time  and  in  such  manner  as  to  afford  The  City  and  Institution  a  reasonable  opportunity  to  act  on  it  prior  to depositing to the account. column1: 1508`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/fin/supp_info/CIP/CIP_Vendor_FAQ.pdf`Success`Success`3`3`Not a fillable PDF.`City of Chicago CENTRALIZED INVOICE PROCESSING Initiative      Frequently Asked Questions (Vendors)       TOPIC – GENERAL    1.  This change might be difficult for my company.  If my contract is eligible   for Centralized Invoice Processing
column2: can I just continue to do business with  the ordering department the way I always have?   •  No. CIP is not optional
column3: and there are no approved alternative   processes.  While we recognize that change is not always easy
column4: we  are also confident that the new CIP policy will provide benefits to  our vendors (like faster payments and easier payment inquiries)  and to the City (like better management reporting) that will outweigh  any short-term difficulties.  We appreciate the support of our  vendors as we implement these and future changes
column5: and look  forward to serving you better.        TOPIC – ORDERS      2.  Is Centralized Invoice Processing for both goods and services?   •  Eligibility for centralized invoice processing is categorized by   Purchase Order type.  An eligible contract may include goods
column6: services or both.      3.  The department that is ordering my goods and/or services creates a PO-  Release after I submit my invoice because they don’t know the actual  quantity they will use at the time they place the order.  Is this OK?   •  No
column7: it is not.  Departments have received instructions and training   on how to create estimated Releases for variable quantity  orders.  They should create these Releases IN ADVANCE
column8: and  then create Receipts for actual quantities upon delivery.  You  should generate an invoice only after the City provides a Receipt  number
column9: and your invoice should include BOTH the Release and  Receipt numbers in order to receive fastest-possible payment.       TOPIC – RECEIPTS    4.  Where do I get a Receipt number?   •  The Receipt number will be provided to you by the department that   ordered and to whom you delivered goods and/or services.           5.  How will the Receipt number be sent?   •   It is up to each department to determine how they will communicate  Receipt numbers to vendors.  Possible communication channels  include USPS mail
column10: email or phone.  We suggest you speak with  the person who is ordering your goods or services to clarify how  their department will communicate Receipt numbers.   6.  When should I start getting Receipt numbers?   •  City departments were advised to start providing Receipt numbers  to their vendors beginning April 1
column11: 2011.  Invoices submitted to CIP  after 4/18 should reference a Receipt number. If the Receipt  number is not included
column12: invoice payment will be delayed.   7.  Is the receipt number the same as the stamped suborder number on the   Blanket Release?   It is not the same number.  The Receipt number is generated only  after you deliver goods or services
column13: and will document the actual  quantities received by the ordering department.  This quantity might  differ from quantities ordered.         8.  What if the department doesn’t send me a Receipt number?   •  Departments have been directed to enter TIMELY and ACCURATE  Receipts in our accounting system to document the exact quantities  delivered by their vendors.  As part of our process improvement  initiative
column14: we will be monitoring and reporting on performance  measurements related to Receipt entry
column15: and addressing any  deficiencies with individual departments.  If you have not received a Receipt number within 5 business days  of delivery
column16: send your invoice to the CIP unit with the notation ‘TBD  – Department’ in the RECEIPT NUMBER field.  While your  payment will be delayed
column17: we will work with the department on your  behalf to get a Receipt number and to prevent further problems.   •   •            TOPIC – INVOICES    9.  My PO is not on the list of eligible contracts.  Where should I submit my   If your PO (contract) is not on the list
column18: or if you are providing goods  or services without a contract
column19: then your invoice is not eligible for  centralized invoice processing.  You should continue to submit your  invoice to the ordering department as you do today.   invoice?   •               10. Can I send my invoice by mail? What about email?   Invoices may be submitted to the CIP unit by mail or as email  attachments.  Instructions and addresses for submitting invoices to  CIP can be found at:   http://www.cityofchicago.org/city/en/depts/fin/provdrs/centralized_invoiceprocessing.html   •   If you are submitting your invoice to the department that ordered  and to whom you delivered goods and/or services
column20: then you should  contact that department to ask how they want the invoice submitted.   11. If I submit my invoice by e-mail
column21: should I also send an original hard copy?   Should I send a duplicate invoice to the ordering department?   •  No
column22: you need not submit a hard-copy in addition to an email   submission
column23: nor should you be submitting duplicate invoice copies  to ANY City department.   12. Should I continue to submit Subcontract Payment Certification forms with   my invoice?   •  DO NOT submit Subcontractor Certification forms to the CIP   unit.  CIP will not enter the information into the accounting  system.  You should contact the City department to which you are  providing goods and/or services to see whether they wish to  continue to receive these forms.   •   13. Should I change the ‘Sold To’ or ‘Bill To’ locations on my invoices?  ‘Sold To' should still be shown as the address of the ordering  department.  'Bill To' can be changed to ‘Invoices
column24: Office of the City  Comptroller
column25: 33 N. LaSalle St.
column26: Room 700
column27: Chicago IL 60602’.   14.  Who should I contact to find out the status of my invoice?   •  You can contact either the department that ordered your goods   and/or services OR the Comptroller’s Office for information on the  status of your invoice.     •

column91: 485.   OVERVIEW OF THE BASIC FINANCIAL STATEMENTS   This discussion and analysis is intended to serve as an introduction to the Airport’s basic financial statements.   The Airport’s basic financial statements are comprised of the financial statements and the notes to financial   - 3 -      statements.  In addition to the basic financial statements this report also presents additional and statistical  information after the notes to basic financial statements.   The Statements of Net Assets present all of the Airport’s assets and liabilities using the accrual basis of  accounting
column92: which is similar to the accounting used by private-sector companies.  The difference between  assets and liabilities is reported as net assets.  The increase or decrease in net assets may serve as an indicator
column94: whether the Airport’s financial position is improving or deteriorating.  However
column95: the consideration  of other non-financial factors such as changes within the airline industry may be necessary in the assessment  of overall financial position and health of the Airport.   The Statements of Revenues
column96: Expenses and Changes in Net Assets present all current fiscal year revenues and  expenses
column97: regardless of when cash is received or paid
column98: and the ensuing change in net assets.   The Statements of Cash Flows report how cash and cash equivalents are provided and used by the Airport’s  operating
column99: capital financing and investing activities.  These statements are prepared on a cash basis and  present the cash received and disbursed
column100: the net increase or decrease in cash and cash equivalents for the year  and the cash and cash equivalents balance at year-end.   The Notes to Basic Financial Statements are an integral part of the basic financial statements; accordingly
column101: such disclosures are essential to a full understanding of the information provided in the basic financial  statements.     In addition to the basic financial statements
column102: this report includes Additional and Statistical Information.  The  Additional Information section presents debt service coverage calculations and the Statistical Information  section includes certain unaudited information related to the Airport’s historical financial and non-financial  operating results and capital activities.   FINANCIAL ANALYSIS  Landing fees and terminal area use charges and fueling system charges are assessed to the various airlines  throughout each fiscal year based on estimated rates.  Such rates are designed to yield collections from  airlines adequate to cover certain operating expenses and required debt service and fund deposits as  determined under provisions of the Airport Use Agreement and Facilities Leases (Use Agreement).   Incremental amounts due from the airlines arise when amounts assessed
column103: based on the estimated rates used  during the year
column104: are less than actual expenses and required deposits for the year.  Such incremental amounts  due from airlines are included in accrued revenue.  Incremental amounts due to the airlines arise when  amounts assessed
column105: based on the estimated rates used during the year
column106: exceed actual expenses and required  deposits for the year.  Such incremental amounts due to airlines are included in deferred revenue.   - 4 -      2005  Changes in Net Assets  2004  2003  Operating revenues:   Landing fees and terminal area uses     charges   Rents

Incremental amounts due  from the airlines arise when amounts assessed

column122: exceed actual expenses and required deposits for the year.  Such  incremental amounts due to airlines are included in deferred revenue.   - 4 -   Passenger Facility Charge (PFC) Revenue—The Airport imposed PFCs of $4.50 per eligible enplaned  passenger for the years ended December 31

column1: 6943`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/fin/supp_info/CAFR/2010/CAFR2010.pdf`Success`Success`172`10`Not a fillable PDF.`"OFFICE OF THE MAYOH  CITY OF CHICAGO  RAHM EMANUEL  MAYOR  Dear Chicagoans:  Thank you for your interest in the Comprehensive Annual Financial Report (CAFR) of  the City of Chicago for the 2010 fiscal year.  The nation's financial environment of the last several years has presented extraordinary  challenges for local governments around the country. The City of Chicago has experienced a dramatic decrease in revenues during this time and in order to maintain the levels of service that are consistent with the demands and expectations of our citizens we must continue to institute strong management initiatives to ensure that we match our responsibilities to available revenues.  This is a time of great opportunity to address the structural deficits in the City budget and  to lay the foundation for a strong financial future. The decisions we make now will shape the direction of the city for decades to come.  Together. we will make government more effective. deliver better services more  affordably. and enhance the city's programs
column2: economic growth and sustainability to ensure that Chicago remains a world-class city.  Sincerely
column3: CITY OF CHICAGO THE CITY COUNCIL As of June 29

8382`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/fin/supp_info/CAFR/2013/CAFR_2013.pdf`Success`Success`174`10`Not a fillable PDF.`   2      OFFICE   OF  THE  MAYOR   CITY  OF  CHICAGO         June 30
column2: 2014   RAHM  EMANUEL   MAYOR   Dear Chicagoans:   Thank you for your interest in the Comprehensive Annual Financial Report (CAFR) of the   City of Chicago for the 2013 fiscal year.   In  2013
column3: the  City  of  Chicago  made  significant  progress  towards  righting  the  City's  financial  ship.  We  have  reduced  our  structural  deficit  by  making  city  government  smaller
column4: smarter
column5: and simpler.  For the third consecutive year
column6: the City enhanced  its long term financial  outlook by contributing millions of dollars to its reserve fund. In addition
column7: we have taken steps to  address the city's  long-term fiscal liabilities such as pensions in a responsible way that protects  taxpayers and meets our obligations to employees and retirees.   Last year
column8: we also made strategic investments in neighborhoods across the city to ensure  Chicago  remains  an  ideal  place  to  live
column9: work
column10: and  raise  a  family
column11: and  also  visit  or  do  business.   It is important we recognize that while significant progress was made in 2013
column12: we must  continue  our  work  to  strengthen  Chicago's  future  by  reforming  city  government
column13: making  investments  in  our  neighborhoods
column14: and  providing  our  residents  with  the  high  quality  services  they rely upon- all in a fiscally responsible way.                                           Mayor         CITY OF CHICAGO  THE CITY COUNCIL   As of December 31
column15: 2013  RAHM EMANUEL

column28: 2014   To  the  Honorable  Mayor  Rahm  Emanuel
column29: Members  of  the  City  Council  and  Citizens of the City of Chicago:   I am pleased to submit the  Comprehensive  Annual  Financial Report (""CAFR"")  of Chicago Midway International Airport (""Airport"") for the year ended December  31
column30: 2013. State Law  requires  that  all  governmental  units  publish  within  six  months  of  the  close  of  each  fiscal  year
column31: financial  statements  presented  in  conformity with generally accepted accounting  principles (""GAAP"") and audited  by a licensed public accountant.   Responsibility for both the accuracy of the data and completeness
column32: and fairness  of  the  presentation
column33: including  all  disclosures
column34: rests  with  the  City  of  Chicago  (""City"")  Chicago  Department of Aviation  and Comptroller's  Office. The purpose  of the CAFR is to provide complete and accurate information that complies with  reporting  International  Airport's  Management's  Discussion  and  Analysis (""MD&A"")  can  be  found  immediately  following  the  independent  auditors'  report.   requirements.  The  Chicago  Midway   ECONOMIC  CONDITION AND  OUTLOOK   that  generally  specialize   The Airport  provides  regional travelers  with  access  to  service  by a  number  of  airlines  in  low-fare
column35: point-to-point
column36: origin    and  destination  (""O&D"") passenger service.  The Airport's  major attributes that allow  it to  enjoy  a  unique  market  niche  include the Airport's  location  proximate to  a  large  O&D  passenger  base
column37: its  accessibility
column38: and  its  low  per-passenger  cost  structure. In 2013
column39: Midway's passenger  enplanements  grew  by 5.0 percent -  making  Midway one of the fastest growing  large hub airports  in the country. In  fact
column40: 2013 was the busiest year in Midway's 86-year history - a major milestone  for  an  airport when  the aviation  industry  is still recovering the global economic  crisis . .   Given  these  factors
column41: along  with  the  projections  for  air  travel  demand in  the  region
column42: there  is a strong economic  outlook for the Airport.   2  105 10  W E ST  Z E M K E  R O A D
column43: P  0 .  B O X   6 6 142 .   C H I CA G O
column44: I L LI N O I S  60 6 6 6   REPORTING  ENTITY   The Airport  is located approximately  eight miles southwest  of the City's central  business  district  and  is within  one of the  largest  O&D  passenger  bases  in the  United States.  In addition
column45: the Airport  is near the center of the Chicago region's  population. This geographic  advantage  is further  enhanced  by the existence  of  an extensive  highway and passenger  rail network  providing convenient  access  to  the  Airport.  The  Airport  occupies  approximately 840  acres  in slightly  more  than a one-mile  square  area.   MAJOR  INITIATIVES   The  City  has  made  significant  investment  in  Midway  to  address  demand
column46: security
column47: safety  and  community  relations.  With  the  completion  of  the  terminal  development  program and the opening of a new parking garage in the economy  lot
column48: we  have addressed  the continually  increasing demand  at the Airport.   In 2013
column49: Midway completed the Consolidated  Rental Car Facility and additional  airfield  rehabilitation  projects.  Since  1996
column50: the  Department  of  Aviation  at  Midway  has  invested $325  million in  noise  mitigation  projects including  the  sound insulation of 41 schools and more than 8
column51: 000 residents in the community  near  Midway.   In 2012
column52: Midway completed  a rehabilitation  of the airside service  road and the  installation  of  new  runway  centerline  and  threshold  lighting  systems  for  both  ends  of  Runway 4R-22L.   The future ongoing capital program also includes the noise mitigation projects
column53: cyclical rehabilitations of the major runways and taxiways in order to maintain  and enhance operational capability
column54: operational efficiency and greater airfield  safety.   The City is financing the capital program through bond proceeds
column55: federal grants
column56: passenger  facility  charge  revenues  and  other  available Airport  funds.   FINANCIAL  INFORMATION   The Departments of Finance and Aviation are responsible for implementing and  maintaining an internal control structure to ensure the integrity of the Airport's  operations and to allow for the preparation of financial statements in conformity  with generally accepted accounting principles. The internal control structure is  designed  to  provide  reasonable  assurance  that  the  assets
column57: resources  and  operations of the Airport are handled in a manner that protects against waste
column58: theft or neglect and other irregularities that may hinder the operations of the   3  Airport. This  objective  is  being  met  by  adequate  supervision  of  employees
column59: segregation  of duties and  multiple approvals  of expenditures.   The Airport's  budget  is developed  in connection  with  the City's  annual  budget  and is based on an analysis  of the Airport's  historical operating  expenses. The  Commissioner  of Aviation  recommends the final proposed budget to the Budget  Director.  After  approval  by  the  Budget  Director
column60: the  proposed  budget  is  recommended  to the  Mayor for  submission  to the  City  Council for  its approval  following  public  hearings.   The  budget  process  is designed  to  ensure that  the Airport  will  have adequate  funding  to  meet  its operational  objectives.  The Airport  cannot
column61: by  law
column62: exceed  the  level  of  funding  as  established  by the  City  Council-approved  budget.  The  Budget  Director  uses  an  allotment  system  to  manage  each  department's  expenditures against its respective annual appropriations. The Budget Director
column63: through the allotment  system
column64: has the authority to institute economic measures  for  the  Airport  to  ensure  that  its  expenditures  do  not  exceed  its  revenue  collection.  The  Airport  uses  encumbrances  to  control  expenditures  by  preventing appropriated dollars from being used for any purpose other than that  for which  they  have been legally appropriated.   RELEVANT  FINANCIAL  POLICIES   The Airport  is owned  by the  City and operated  by the  Chicago  Department  of  Aviation (""CDA"") and is accounted for as a self-supporting enterprise fund of the  City.  The  City  maintains  the  books
column65: records  and  accounts of  the  Airport  in  accordance  with  generally  accepted  accounting  principles  and  as  required  by  the  provisions  of the Airport  Use Agreements
column66: the  Bond Ordinance
column67: and  Bond  Indentures as supplemented  and  amended.   The Airport  Use Agreements  specify a residual rate-making methodology for the  calculation of airline rates and charges.  Under this methodology
column68: total operating  and  maintenance  expenses  and  debt  service  (including  coverage)    are  calculated for each cost-revenue center and offset by nonairline revenues. The  Airport  Use  Agreements  provide  that  the  aggregate  of  Airport  Fees  and  Charges  paid by the Airline  Parties must be sufficient to  pay for the  net cost of  operating
column69: maintaining  and developing  the Airport
column70: including the satisfaction  of  Debt  Service  coverage
column71: deposit  and  payment  requirements  of  the  Bond  Ordinance  and the  Indentures.   INDEPENDENT  AUDIT   The  Midway  bond  indentures  require the Airport  financial  statements  to  be  audited by independent certified public accountants. The audit was conducted  by Deloitte & Touche LLP and a consortium of Chicago-based minority and   4  MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS (UNAUDITED)  ($ IN THOUSANDS)   This following discussion and analysis of the Chicago Midway International Airport’s (Airport) performance  provides an introduction and overview of the Airport’s financial activities for the years ended December 31

column147: 214        i)   Interest Rate Risk – As a means of limiting its exposure to fair value losses arising from rising interest  rates

column158: the  Securities  and  Exchange  Commission. Details regarding the Sewer Fund’s long-term debt are in Note 4 of the notes  to the basic financial statements.   OVERVIEW OF THE BASIC FINANCIAL STATEMENTS   This discussion and analysis is intended to serve as an introduction to the Sewer Fund’s basic financial  statements. The Sewer Fund’s basic financial statements comprise the basic financial statements and the notes  to basic financial statements. In addition to the basic financial statements
column28: this report also presents statistical  data after the notes to basic financial statements.   The statements of net position present all of the Sewer Fund’s assets
column29: deferred outflows
column30: and liabilities using  the accrual basis of accounting. The difference between assets
column31: deferred outflows
column32: and liabilities is reported as  net position. The increase or decrease in net position may serve as an indicator
column33: over time
column34: whether the Sewer  Fund’s financial position is improving or deteriorating. However
column35: the consideration of other nonfinancial  factors may be necessary in the assessment of overall financial position and health of the Sewer Fund.   The statements of revenues
column36: expenses
column37: and changes in net position present all current fiscal year revenues and  expenses
column38: regardless of when cash is received or paid
column39: and the ensuing change in net position.   The statements of cash flows report how cash and cash equivalents were provided and used by the Sewer  Fund’s operating
column40: capital financing
column41: and investing activities. These statements are prepared on a cash basis  and present the cash received and disbursed
column42: the net increase or decrease in cash and cash equivalents for the  year
column43: and the cash and cash equivalents balance at year-end.   The notes to basic financial statements are an integral part of the basic financial statements; accordingly
column44: such  disclosures are essential for a full understanding of the information provided in the basic financial statements.   In addition to the basic financial statements
column45: this report includes statistical data. The statistical data section  presents unaudited debt-service coverage calculations and includes certain unaudited information related to  the Sewer Fund’s historical financial and nonfinancial operating results and capital activities.   - 10 -

column30: inherent in a swap. Collateral on all swaps is to be in the form  of cash or eligible collateral held by a third-party custodian. Upon credit events
column31: the swaps  also allow transfers
column32: credit support
column33: and termination
column34: if the counterparty is unable to meet  the said credit requirements.   Basis Risk—Basis risk refers to the mismatch between the variable rate payments  received on a swap contract and the interest payment actually owed on the bonds. The  two significant components driving this risk are credit and Securities Industry and  Financial Markets Associations (SIFMA) ratios. Credit may create basis risk because the  Airport’s bonds may trade differently than the swap index as a result of a credit change in  the Airport. SIFMA ratios (or spreads) may create basis risk if SIFMA swaps of the  Airport’s bonds trade higher than the SIFMA received on the swap. This can occur due to  many factors including
column35: without limitations
column36: changes in marginal tax rates
column37: tax-exempt  status of bonds
column38: and supply and demand for variable rate bonds. The Airport is exposed to  basis risk on the swaps if the rate paid on the bonds is higher than the rate received. The  Airport is liable for the difference. The difference would need to be available on the debt  service payment date and would add additional underlying cost to the transaction.   Tax Risk—The swap exposes the Airport to tax risk or a permanent mismatch (shortfall)  between the floating rate received on the swap and the variable rate paid on the  underlying variable-rate bonds due to tax law changes such that the Federal or State tax  exception of municipal debt is eliminated or its value reduced. There have been no tax law  changes since the execution of this swap agreement.   Termination Risk—The risk that the swap could be terminated as a result of certain  events
column39: including a ratings downgrade for the issuer or swap counterparty
column40: covenant  violation
column41: bankruptcy
column42: payment default
column43: or other defined events of default. Termination of  a swap may result in a payment made by the issuer or to the issuer depending upon the  market at the time of termination.   Swap Payments and Associated Debt—As of December 31

column34: 2017    To the Honorable Mayor Rahm Emanuel
column35: Members of the City Council and Citizens of the City of Chicago:    I  am  pleased  to  submit  the  Comprehensive  Annual  Financial  Report  (“CAFR”)  of  Chicago  O’Hare  International  Airport  (“Airport”)  for  the  year  ended  December  31
column36: 2016.  State  law  requires  that  all  governmental units publish within six months of the close of each fiscal year financial statements presented  in  conformity  with  generally  accepted  accounting  principles  (“GAAP”)  and  audited  by  a  licensed  public  accountant.    Responsibility  for  both  the  accuracy  of  the  data  and  completeness  and  fairness  of  the  presentation
column37: including all disclosures
column38: rests with the City of Chicago (“City”) Department of Aviation and Comptroller’s  Office.  The  purpose  of  the  CAFR  is  to  provide  complete  and  accurate  information  that  complies  with  reporting requirements. The Chicago O’Hare International Airport’s Management’s Discussion and Analysis  (“MD&A”) can be found immediately following the independent auditors’ report.    ECONOMIC CONDITION AND OUTLOOK    According  to  preliminary  2016  statistics  compiled  by  Airports  Council  International
column39: the  Airport  was  the  second busiest airport in the world in 2016
column40: as measured by total aircraft operations and the sixth busiest  by  total  passengers.  In  North  America
column41: the  Airport  was  the  sixth  busiest  airport  in  terms  of  total  cargo  tonnage handled. According to the  Official Airline Guide
column42: as of December 31
column44: nonstop service was  provided from the Airport to 238 destinations
column45: consisting of 170 domestic airports and 68 foreign airports.  Given the strength and diversity of the economic base of the region and the resulting high demand for air  transportation services
column46: combined with record breaking passenger activity in 2016
column47: it is expected that the  Airport will remain a major air traffic connecting hub
column48: with a substantial number of airlines providing flights to  all major domestic locations as well as an increasing number of international destinations.   REPORTING ENTITY    The Airport is the primary commercial airport for the City
column49: and the region
column50: as well as an important transfer  and  connecting  point  for  numerous  domestic  and  international  flights.  Located  18  miles  northwest  of  the  City’s  central  business  district
column51: the  Airport  occupies  approximately  7
column52: 265  acres  of  land.  The  Airport  is  accessed  by  a  network  of  highways
column53: including  several  regional  expressways  that  are  part  of  the  federal  Interstate  Highway  System
column54: and  is  directly  linked  to  the  central  business  district  by  a  rapid  transit  rail  system.         The airlines servicing the Airport operate out of four terminal buildings. Three domestic terminal buildings
column55: having  a  total  of  167  gates
column56: serve  domestic  flights  and  certain  international  departures  as  of  December  2016.  The  International  Terminal
column57: having  a  total  of  21  gates  and  four  remote  aircraft  parking  positions
column58: serves the remaining international departures and all arrivals requiring customs clearance.    MAJOR INITIATIVES    The  centerpiece  of  capital  development  at  the  Airport  is  the  O’Hare  Modernization  Program  (OMP)
column59: launched  in  2004  to  preserve  and  enhance  safety  and  efficient  operations  for  the  more  than  70  million  passengers  traveling  through  the  Airport  each  year.  The  OMP  is  designed  to  improve  capacity  of  the  Airport
column60: as  well  as  the  national  air  transportation  system  by:  reducing  delays;  providing  sufficient airfield
column61: landside
column62: and  support  facilities  to  accommodate  existing  and  future  passenger  and  cargo  demand;  providing  efficient  surface  access  for  existing  and  future  Airport  users;  and  providing  opportunities  for  enhanced competition among air carriers.      This program consists of the development of one new runway at the Airport
column63: the relocation of three existing  runways
column64: and the extension of two existing runways at an estimated cost of $5.5   billion dollars.     Improvements  made  by  the  OMP  are  designed  to  reduce  weather  delays  by  95  percent
column65: reduce  overall  delays  by  70  percent  and  meet  projected  aviation  demand  beyond  2030.  To  date
column66: improvements  made  have substantially reduced airfield and airspace delays. In fact
column67: capacity has improved by 50 percent
column68: and  measured  delays  are reduced by  57  percent.  These  improvements  have  a  direct  impact  not  only  for  travelers in and out of Chicago
column69: but impact the efficiency of the broader national airspace system as well.    In 2016
column70: the City of Chicago
column71: with support by its federal partners and airline carriers
column72: announced a nearly  $1.3 billion infrastructure plan to build on the ongoing work of the OMP. This investment directs resources  toward construction of Airport’s newest runway
column74: deicing pads and other critical airfield projects for  further  airport  improvements  that  will  allow  Airport  to  increase  the  number  of  gates  and  modernize  the  terminals. With this latest investment and the final phase of Airport’s newest runway
column75: 9C-27C expected to  be completed in 2020
column76: OMP is on pace to be completed in 2021.    The Airport began construction on a Multimodal facility that will include a Consolidated Rental Car Facility
column77: Public Parking and the extension of the Airport Transit System. In addition to the above
column78: the City is also  implementing an ongoing five-year Capital Improvement Plan (CIP) for the Airport. The CIP includes airfield  improvements
column79: noise  mitigation  projects
column80: parking  and  roadway  improvements
column82: safety  and  security  improvements
column83: other  terminal  enhancements  and  planning  initiatives.     In summer 2016
column84: Mayor Rahm Emanuel and the CDA announced O’Hare 21  - a multi-billion dollar capital  investment program at the Airport that expands Terminal 5
column85: redevelops     Terminal  2
column86: creates  space  for  new  gates
column87: adds  three  hotel  development  projects  and  supports  tens  of  thousands of jobs and economic opportunities in Chicago.     The  City  expects  these  capital  programs  will  be  funded  from  the  following  sources:  proceeds  of  airport  revenue bonds
column88: Passenger Facility Charge (PFC) revenues on a pay-as-you-go basis
column89: PFC-backed bonds
column91: a TIFIA loan and other available Airport funds.           FINANCIAL INFORMATION    The  Departments  of  Finance  and  Aviation  are  responsible  for  implementing  and  maintaining  an  internal  control  structure  to  ensure  the  integrity  of  the  Airport’s  operations  and  to  allow  for  the  preparation  of  financial  statements  in  conformity  with  generally  accepted accounting  principles. As  the  cost  of a  control  should not exceed the benefits to be derived
column92: the internal control structure is designed provide reasonable
column94: assurance to all stakeholders that the financial statements reflect operations free of  theft
column95: neglect  or  material  misstatements  that  could  affect  the  efficiency  of  operations  at  the  Airport.  This  objective  is  being  met  by  adequate  supervision  of  employees
column96: segregation  of  the  duties  and  multiple  approval and budgetary controls over all expenditures.    The Airport’s budget is developed in connection with the City’s annual budget and is based on an analysis  of  the  Airport’s  historical  operating  expenses.  The  Commissioner  of  Aviation  recommends  the  final  proposed  budget  to  the  Budget  Director.    After  approval  by  the  Budget  Director
column97: the  proposed  budget  is  recommended to the Mayor for submission to the City Council for its approval following public hearings.    The budget process is designed to ensure that the Airport will have adequate funding for operations. The  Airport cannot
column99: exceed the level of funding as established by the City Council-approved budget. The  Budget  Director  uses  an  allotment  system  to  manage  each  department’s  expenditures  against  its  respective  annual  appropriation.  The  Budget  Director
column101: has  the  authority  to  institute  economic  measures  for  the  Airport  to  ensure  that  its  expenditures  do  not  exceed  its  revenue  collection. The Airport uses encumbrances to control expenditures by preventing appropriated dollars from  being used for any purpose other than that for which they have been legally appropriated.    RELEVANT FINANCIAL POLICIES    The  Airport  is  owned  by  the  City  and  operated  by  the  Chicago  Department  of  Aviation  (CDA)  and  is  accounted for as a self-supporting enterprise fund of the City. The City maintains the books
column102: records and  accounts of the Airport in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles and as required by the  provisions of the Airport Use Agreements
column103: the Bond Ordinance and Bond Indentures as supplemented and  amended.    The Airport Use Agreements specify a residual rate-making methodology for the calculation of airline rates  and  charges.    Under  this  methodology
column104: total  operating  and  maintenance  expenses  and  debt  service  (including coverage) are calculated for each cost-revenue center and offset by non-airline revenues. The  Airport Use Agreements provide that the aggregate of Airport Fees and Charges paid by the Airline Parties  must be sufficient to pay for the net cost of operating
column105: maintaining and developing the Airport (excluding the  Land Support Area) including the satisfaction of Debt Service coverage
column106: deposit and payment requirements  of the Bond Ordinance and the Indentures.    INDEPENDENT AUDIT         Various  bond  indentures  require  the  Airport  financial  statements  to  be  audited  by  independent  certified  public  accountants.  The  audit  was  conducted  by  Deloitte  &  Touche  LLP  and  a  consortium  of  Chicago- based minority and women-owned certified public accounting firms. An unqualified audit opinion
column108: is included in the financial section of this report.        costs

The dental and vision  coverage  has  been  improved  for  2017  and  separate  payroll  deductions will be taken for each plan.  Dental PPO – the maximum amount the plan pays each year  has been increased and some out-of-pocket costs will be  lower for in-network services; crowns related to implants now  covered and sealants for dependent children.  Dental HMO – Reduced co-pays for children’s braces; lower  out-of-pocket costs for periodontal surgery and endodontic  services.  Vision Plan – improved contact lens formulary; and co-pays  for lens scratch coating eliminated.  WELLNESS PROGRAM  The Chicago Lives Healthy wellness plan no longer requires  annual screenings. Screenings are every three years
column15: except  for new hires

Call Telligen at 1-800-373-3727.  Second Opinion needed for some surgeries.  Call Telligen  as soon as your doctor recommends surgery in any of the  following areas: • Knee; shoulder; hip; neck; and back • Gall bladder • Thyroid • Uterine • Weight loss (bariatric)  There  is  no  charge  for  the  second  opinion  and  no  travel  is  required.  You will not be examined

PPO members are eligible for  the  CCP  program  if  they  have  been  hospitalized  once  in  the  past  year.    If  you  are  interested  in  the  CCP  program you will  be  asked  to  switch  to  a  primary  care  doctor  at  the  University of Chicago Medicine. column15: 2017 to the medical Blue Choice OPT PPO.  This plan will be  administered by Blue Cross Blue Shield of Illinois and includes  the same network of providers (doctors and hospitals) as the  current  medical  PPO  plan.    The  difference  is  that  the  Blue  Choice OPT PPO adds a third provider network with enhanced  benefit coverage levels.  This means the PPO plan for 2017  will have three different network choices called Tiers:    Tier 1   Blue Choice OPT PPO – a narrow network with the   lowest out-of-pocket costs   Tier 2   Blue Cross PPO  – includes the same “in-network”  providers (doctors and hospitals) as the current plan.  Tier 3   Out-of-network – no cost savings and highest out-  of-pocket costs.    When a Blue Choice OPT PPO member needs medical care
column16: they  have  the  option  of  selecting  a  provider  from  any  Tier.     C H I C AG O   B E N E F I T S   O F F I C E   •   W W W. C I T YO F C H I C AG O B E N E F I T S . O R G   •   1 - 8 7 7 - 2 9 9 - 5 1 1 1  2016 FALL BENEFITS BULLETIN   Family members can also choose to use physicians and hospitals  in different Tiers. column17: co-insurance and co-pays are in Tier 1.  In addition to the new three tier network

You’ll need your group number and your Blue Cross ID number (this is not your City employee ID number).       Call BCBSIL at 1-800-772-6895 to get the numbers you need.  BCBSIL is available 8:00 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. CST.  2. Log into www.bcbsil.com/cityofchicago.  3. On the right side of the screen

This will create        your Blue Cross ID card for printing.   PAYING FOR HEALTH COVERAGE ON LEAVE  Employees  on  a  leave  of  absence  who  wish  to  continue  City  healthcare  coverage  must  pay  contributions  directly  to the City.  If the leave is a Family Medical Leave (FMLA) or Duty Disability (DD)
column19: employees will be charged their  regular paycheck contributions for healthcare.  Employees on other types of leave will be charged the Direct Pay Rate  (below).  Employees on leave are sent a monthly bill for health coverage.  The bill must be paid on time or health  coverage terminates.  Employees are also responsible for making payments directly to Prudential to continue their  Long Term Disability Insurance and/or additional Life Insurance.  Call the Benefits Service Center at 1-877-299-5111  for more information about Direct Pay or to re-enroll for benefits within 30 days of returning to work after any  leave. column1: 9439`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/fin/supp_info/Benefits/Bulletins/2017_Spring_Benefits_Bulletin_Plan_B.pdf`Success`Success`2`2`Not a fillable PDF.`C I T Y   O F   C H I C A G O   •   D E P A R T M E N T   O F   F I N A N C E  BENEFITSBULLETIN    S P R I N G   2 0 1 7     For all benefits eligible Police Officers below the rank of Sergeant represented by the Fraternal Order of Police (FOP).  HOW TO AVOID FINANCIAL PENALTIES IN THE PPO   Certain PPO healthcare services need to be pre-approved* by Telligen
column2: an independent medical advisor.  There are  financial penalties if Telligen is not contacted in time for pre-approval
column3: also known as pre-certification.    Although the PPO member has to pay the penalty if care is not pre-approved
column4: it is usually the healthcare provider who  calls Telligen to start the process.  PPO members should call Telligen at 1-800-373-3727 to make sure the pre-approval  call has been made
column5: especially when more than one provider is involved in the care
column6: such as:     THERAPY AND COUNSELLING  AMBULANCE TRANSFERS  Outpatient  mental  health  and  substance  abuse  therapy  and  counselling  needs  to  be  pre-approved  after  the  7th  session each year
column7: even when sessions are combined from  one or more providers.  For example
column8: if a PPO member  has four individual counseling visits with a psychologist and  three  group  therapy  sessions  with  a  social  worker
column9: these  will count as a total of seven sessions. The eighth session  and any future counselling and/or therapy needs to be pre- approved by Telligen or the member will have to pay the  full cost.      If the sessions continue from one year into the next
column10: pre- approval needs to be requested again in the new year after   seven sessions.    All inpatient mental health and substance abuse treatment  must be pre-approved before the patient is admitted or a  $1
column11: 000 penalty applies.  When  a  private  ambulance  is  used  to  transfer  a  PPO  member  between  hospitals
column12: Telligen’s  pre-approval  is  required even if the hospital orders the transfer.  Telligen  needs to be contacted before the ambulance is arranged.   The  PPO  member  will  be  responsible  for  the  cost  of  the  transfer if approval is not provided by Telligen before the  transfer takes place.  DIAGNOSTIC IMAGING     MRIs
column13: PET  and  CT  scans  need  pre-approval  or  the  PPO  member  pays  the  full  cost.    Pre-approved  scans  are  covered  at  100%  if  done  at  a  free  standing  facility.  PPO  members  should  call  Telligen  before  the  scan  is  done  to  find the location of free standing facilities.  Deductibles and  co-insurance amounts apply when a pre-approved scan is  done at a hospital or billed by a hospital
column14: or if it is an MRA  scan to get pictures of blood vessels inside the body.    *For a complete list of all PPO services that need to be pre-approved
column15: refer to the pre-certification list in your   2107 open enrollment or new hire guide
column16: or visit www.cityofchicago.org/benefits.    C H I C AG O   B E N E F I T S   O F F I C E   •   W W W. C I T YO F C H I C AG O B E N E F I T S . O R G   •   1 - 8 7 7 - 2 9 9 - 5 1 1 1  2017 SPRING BENEFITS BULLETIN   DENTAL CHECKUPS - JUST AS IMPORTANT AS HEALTH SCREENINGS  Gum disease has been linked to heart attacks and other health conditions.  Regular preventive dental checkups with professional  cleaning help prevent gum disease by removing plaque.  Even though brushing and flossing helps control plaque
column17: it still builds up and forms tartar which needs to be removed with  professional teeth cleaning.  Gums become infected if plaque and tarter are not removed.  This can lead to gum disease  and loss of bone holding the teeth.  Warning signs of gum disease include a bad taste in the mouth
column18: chronic bad breath and  bleeding gums when brushing or flossing your teeth.    The City’s Dental PPO and Dental HMO plans both cover two preventive visits each year which include professional cleanings
column19: oral exam and x-rays for a $10 co-pay (in-network).  For more information about dental benefits and to find an in-network  dentist
column20: visit www.bcbsil.com/cityofchicago or call 1-855-557-5487.  Dental insurance is provided to all employees and dependents enrolled in the City’s healthcare plan.  The dental plans are  available to new hires after one calendar year of full-time employment.  Those without dental coverage can save on the cost of  preventive dental visits and other dental care by enrolling in the Flexible Spending Account (FSA) and using pre-tax dollars for  dental check-ups.  Enroll in the FSA when hired or during open enrollment.    GETTING DIVORCED?  An ex-spouse cannot be covered as a dependent in the City’s health plan.  This is true even if the divorce decree states the City  employee needs to provide health insurance for the ex-spouse.  Employees need to drop the ex-spouse as a dependent and  submit a certified copy of the divorce decree:  • Call the City Benefits Service Center at 1-877-299-5111 to cancel an ex-spouse’s healthcare coverage within 30 days of the       date of divorce. • Take a certified copy of the entire divorce decree to the Chicago Benefits Office within 60 days of the date of divorce.  A copy       will be made of the last page and the decree will be given back to you.  Employees who do not comply with this procedure will have to pay any healthcare costs the City incurs for the ex-spouse.   In addition
column21: failure to notify the City of the divorce may be treated as fraud.    The Chicago Benefit Office is located on the 4th floor
column22: 333 South State Street; open Monday thru Friday
column23: 8:30 a.m. until  4:30 p.m.  Employees getting divorced may want to change their life insurance beneficiary.  Call Prudential at 1-800-778-3827 to find out  how to update your beneficiary.    C H I C AG O   B E N E F I T S   O F F I C E   •   W W W. C I T YO F C H I C AG O B E N E F I T S . O R G   •   1 - 8 7 7 - 2 9 9 - 5 1 1 1
