column1: 9799`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/rev/supp_info/ParkingMeter/CityResponsetoATAReport.pdf`Success`Success`4`4`Not a fillable PDF.`   CITY OF CHICAGO RESPONSE TO ATA REPORT      Active Transportation Alliance (ATA)
column2: formerly the Chicagoland Bicycle Federation
column3: released a report today concerning the lease of the City’s parking meters.  While the  report does an admirable job of summarizing parking goals originated and championed  by economists like Donald Shoup – many of which the city supports – it fails in its  discussion of the meter concession.  The report shows a fundamental lack of  understanding of the basic terms of the concession agreement and their impact upon the  City of Chicago.    Transaction Provides Optimal System Utilization  As ATA notes
column4: the objective of market-based pricing is to bring pricing to a level that will  provide optimal utilization of the system.  The meter rate increase implemented in early  2009 were intended to do just that
column5: specifically reducing cruising for underpriced parking  and promoting turnover and availability.  This makes locations served by meters more  popular.  Before that
column6: meter rates had not been increased at nearly 75% of the parking    meters in more than two decades.    Parking Meter Concession Will Help Maintain and Improve City Neighborhoods  The ATA argues that revenues generated from parking meters should be earmarked for  “filling potholes
column7: repairing sidewalks
column8: planting trees
column9: replacing streetlights
column10: and funding  more efficient transportation options.”  First – net revenue from the parking meter system  historically did not fund these specific items
column11: but rather was part of the general corporate  fund revenue stream.    But the proceeds from this transaction – as well as other long-term leases – have very  much allowed the City to continue to invest in neighborhood improvements and quality of  life.    In fact
column13: after the City closed the Skyway transaction and set aside $500 million  in a long-term reserve
column14: the City earned rating upgrades from all three rating agencies.      A strong credit rating has an substantial impact on the City’s cost to issue debt – higher  credit ratings mean lower borrowing costs
column15: which is critical to funding transportation  infrastructure projects that improve Chicago’s neighborhoods and transportation system    And it is misleading for the ATA to assert that drivers will not see benefits from the  concession deal – the benefits of greater parking availability
column16: less congestion
column17: as well as  the benefits that the city’s corporate fund provides – including clean and safe streets and  traffic control – are all being furthered by this transaction.      The City also must balance a need for a variety of other city services that are not only  limited to transportation or sidewalk landscaping.  That includes those basic city services  – police
column18: fire
column19: emergency dispatch
column20: and sanitation – that are paid for by the city’s  corporate fund and ensure all Chicago residents can live in safe
column21: clean
column22: and viable  communities.    With the transaction proceeds
column23: we are including funding for the city’s corporate fund to  continue providing those services
column24: as well as programs that help Chicago residents most      in need
column25: including meals on wheels for seniors
column26: after-school programs for children
column27: and  affordable housing programs.    It is the City’s goal to include funding these needs both in the long and short term
column28: and  funds from the concession agreement will allow the City to accomplish this.      City Maintains Control Over Public Way  Further
column29: the City of Chicago always retains control of its public way.  The claim that the  City has lost control of “one of their most powerful urban planning and revenue- generating tools” is absolutely incorrect.        Chicago has a 15 plus-year track record of improving the bike
column30: pedestrian and transit  environment (i.e. non-motorized) including one of the country’s largest on-street bike  networks and myriad safety education and outreach programs. Those programs are    continuing across the City
column31: and will continue for years to come
column32: in part
column33: because of the  money received from the concession agreement.    To suggest that the parking meter concession “restrictions will severely limit innovative  planning for bicyclists
column34: pedestrians and transit users” is wholly wrong.  To the contrary
column35: the City continues to pursue a wide range of planning efforts and construction projects
column36: part of an ongoing effort to offer attractive non-driving options.    Substantial Operating Efficiencies and Customer Service Improvement to Be  Realized  The ATA is also critical of the concession
column37: claiming that there are “no appreciable  operating efficiencies to be gained.”  At the same time
column38: the ATA also notes that the    concessionaire “is required to pay for all capital improvements to the system
column39: including     the transition from typical meters to pay and display boxes that accept credit cards.”    Pay and displays are costly.  In the first year alone
column40: the capital expenses for this  technology will cost the concessionaire between $40 and $50 million to install 3
column41: 000 pay  and display boxes
column42: while the City only installed 190 over the last five years.   $40 million  to $50 million is more than two times the meter revenue in 2008
column43: and it is an expense the  concessionaire will own several times over during the life of the agreement.      This is the very technology necessary to measure utilization and accomplish the ATA’s  goals of congestion and peak period pricing
column44: as well as its goal of un-cluttering city  streets and sidewalks.       The City Sheds Risk of Reduced Auto Parking   The ATA’s report also neglects the notion of risk.  The ATA would like to see a reduction  in vehicle use and an increase in walking
column45: biking
column46: and public transportation.  Increased  use of other modes of transit – which ATA supports – will surely negatively impact meter  utilization.  And that is a significant risk to revenue that the City no longer owns.        In fact
column47: over the 75-year period of the concession there are a number of significant risks  that the City no longer bares
column48: including those utilization risks associated with changes in  population
column49: economic activity
column50: and technology.  For instance
column51: there were no combustible  engines 75 years ago
column52: and 50 years ago there were no parking meters.  To assume  there are no technological advances that will change the use of on-street parking meters  would be naïve.                 City Uses Proceeds for the Long-term and Today    The $1.156 billion received by the City is not an “upfront payment that solves short term  financial problems without considering the long term implications.”  A significant portion  of the payment the City received is being invested for future use.  In fact
column53: the City  invested more than $400 million in a long-term reserve that will replace the net revenue  provided by the meter system and increase the City’s long-term reserves to $900 million.      The City also invested $325 million in a mid-term budget relief fund that will help us  balance budgets through 2012
column54: and $320 million in a budget stabilization fund that may  be used to help bridge the period until the nation’s economy recovers
column55: allowing the City  to continue vital services and avoid steep tax increases.  Finally
column56: the City is investing  $100 million in human infrastructure programs like the low income housing trust fund
column57: and ex-offender and other job and social programs.  Finally
column58: $150 million was used to  help balance the 2008 and 2009 budgets
column59: avoiding major layoffs or tax increases.      City Maintains Control Over Parking Rates and Meter Placement  And finally
column60: the ATA’s claim that the City has lost control over the parking meters  specifically is purely fiction.  The setting of meter rates is a reserve power of the City.  It  cannot be assigned to the concessionaire.  Changes to the rate structure and hours of    operation can be implemented
column61: but the City must be cognizant of the implications those  changes may have on revenues.  The City has historically always owned the risk of a    revenue impact when changes to the meter system are made.  It continues to own the  risk today.    There are opportunities
column62: however
column63: to reduce the economic risk.  The City can increase  rates
column64: hours of operation
column65: or even the number of meters to mitigate the impact.  A cost    benefit analysis is always necessary to determine if changes to on-street parking are  advisable.  These benefits are not always economic
column66: but could have to do with promoting  the free flow of traffic or providing deterrence to parking in heavily congested area.      In conclusion
column67: the “Implications” detailed in the report are all erroneous.  Those mistakes  are detailed below:     1.  “The overarching impact is that the City has essentially given up control over         pricing of the meters and placement of the meters.”   FALSE.  As noted above
column68: the City has retained full control over the public way  and the parking meter system
column69: including pricing and placement of meters
column70: and  the ability to implement market-rate parking policies.     2.  “This agreement makes it impossible for the City to test any new hourly meter   rates for price elasticity of demand...”                  FALSE.  The City has retained full control over rate setting.  Further
column71: the  transaction has actually enabled the City to test new hourly meter rates because  the new meter technology provides real time utilization information.  The old  meters made it impossible to accurately measure price elasticity.   3.  “The cost for temporary removal of a parking meter is based on ‘the maximum         utilization or a comparable meter…’”      FALSE.  When a meter is temporarily removed
column72: the City only pays the amount of  lost revenue as measured by actual revenue in the previous year for the period of  time during which the meter is out of service.  It is not based on the revenue  generated by the highest producing meter.   4.  “So while the city technically retains control over these spaces
column73: any move to      remove or adjust parking will financially penalize the City.”   FALSE.  As stated above
column74: the financial impact of changes now are largely the  same as those prior to the concession.  Before the City entered into the  transaction
column75: if it removed meters
column76: it lost revenue.     5.  “This means that every potential project on a street with meter
column77: including…. …are       dictated
column78: controlled and limited by parking meters.”   FALSE.  The degree to which meters impact projects has not changed.  The  financial impact on City revenues from potential projects has not changed.     6. 	 “…the cost of removing parking or placing rush hour parking controls over the   length of a potential route such as Western Avenue would be staggering.”    FALSE.  Again
column79: the cost of any such controls is no different under the  transaction.  The costs
column80: if staggering
column81: would have been equally as staggering  prior to the transaction.     7.  “The prices increase
column82: but drivers will not see the benefits in increases sidewalk   cleaning
column83: pothole mending
column84: or tree planting.”               FALSE.  Prior to the transaction
column85: all net meter revenue went to the general fund
column86: not the specific areas that contained parking meters.  Further
column87: the transaction has  ensured that the City has the funds necessary to continue providing vital  municipal services
column88: which it would have to have reduced otherwise.     ###

column2: 2009    This week
column3: the political organization known as the Independent  Voters of Illinois – Independent Precinct Organization (IVI-IPO) filed a  lawsuit against the City of Chicago to challenge the City’s parking  meter concession agreement.      The lawsuit is wholly without merit
column4: both factually and legally
column5: and the  City will vigorously defend against it. In their press conference and  legal filings
column6: the organization made a number of misstatements of  fact
column7: and their allegations have been both erroneous and  irresponsible.    First
column8: the City did not delegate the ability to set rates for parking  meters
column9: as the organization and its counsel assert.  The parking  meter concession agreement and the City’s Municipal Code are  clear: the setting of meter rates is a reserve power of the City.  That  power cannot be assigned to the concessionaire
column10: Chicago Parking  Meters
column11: LLC (CPM).  Changes to the rate structure and hours of  operation can be implemented
column12: but only through action by the City.   CPM is obligated to abide by these decisions. CPM’s activities are  limited to the operation
column13: management
column14: rehabilitation
column15: and collection of  the parking meter system.    Second
column16: the concession agreement is an agreement to operate the  meter system over 75 years.  It is neither a sale nor a lease
column17: as the  organization wrongly suggests.  The public way was not sold nor  leased to CPM. CPM has no ownership interest or lease right to the  roads or sidewalks.  While ownership of the equipment was  transferred
column18: the City will own any and all improvements made to the  system by CPM upon expiration or termination of the agreement.       Third
column19: the IVI-IPO’s claim that the City should not enforce parking  meter violations or assist with the maintenance of parking meters has  no foundation.  The City maintains a responsibility for traffic  management
column20: and remains fully engaged in ensuring parking meters  and their enforcement are utilized as tools to carry out this    responsibility in the public interest.     By limiting the time a vehicle may park in a particular space
column21: parking meters create  turnover and increase availability.  When there are available spaces to park
column22: there is  less cruising for parking.  Cruising leads to increased congestion and pollution.  The  maintenance and enforcement of parking meters plays a vital role in reducing  congestion and travel times
column23: promoting local businesses
column24: and cutting pollution.      Fourth
column25: the City bears the financial costs of meter removals today
column26: just as it did before  the parking meter concession was approved.  Historically
column27: the City has always had the  risk of negative revenue impacts when meters were removed.  The City continues to  bear that risk.      CPM
column28: on the other hand
column29: bears the risks associated with reductions in vehicle use and  increases in walking
column30: biking
column31: and the use of public transportation.  Reductions in parking  meter utilization and the resulting revenue are CPM’s burdens
column32: not the City’s.  The IVI- IPO’s assertions to the contrary are wrong.    Lastly
column33: the City has not delegated its police powers
column34: as the organization incorrectly  asserts. Revenue from parking violations is retained solely by the City of Chicago.   Although CPM could assist the City with enforcing meter violations
column35: subject to strict  operational standards
column36: all of the revenue derived from parking meter enforcement  belongs to the City.    For more information about the parking meter concession agreement
column37: please visit  www.cityofchicago.org/revenue and select the “About Parking Meters” icon.    Sincerely
column38: Gene Saffold  Chief Financial Officer  City of Chicago

column1: 9801`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/rev/supp_info/ParkingMeter/MeterFAQs.pdf`Success`Success`8`8`Not a fillable PDF.`"Why does the City have parking meters?  By limiting the time that a vehicle may park in a particular space
column2: meters play a vital role  in facilitating traffic management
column3: promoting business
column4: and reducing congestion and  pollution.      Do all meters operate 24 hours per day?  No.  Meters are free during evenings in most places except for City parking lots and the  Loop.  Days and hours of operation should be posted on the meters.      When do I have to pay the parking meter?  Please look at the time and days of operation on the meters.  Generally meters operate  from: 9 a.m. to 6 p.m. on residential streets; 8 a.m. to 9 p.m. on business streets
column5: and 24  hours in the Loop and City parking lots.  There are
column6: however
column7: exceptions.  Days and  hours of operation should be posted on the meters.    Are there parking meter holidays?    Unless otherwise posted
column8: there are no meter holidays.    Can I park at a broken parking meter?  Yes
column9: you may park at the broken meter for free if you report it as broken within 24 hours  by calling 877.242.7901.    How do I report a broken parking meter?  Please call the 24 hour customer service line at 877.242.7901 and provide information  about the meter
column10: including the meter ID number.  You will be provided with a  confirmation number.      How do I request a refund?  If you have had a payment issue with a parking meter and would like to request a refund

column12: the meter ID number is located on the front panel.    What happens once I report a meter as broken?  All reports of broken meters are investigated promptly
column13: most within a few hours.    Can meters be impacted when there are drastic changes in temperature including  freezing conditions?  Yes.  Similar to most on-street equipment
column14: parking meters may experience problems  when there are drastic changes in temperature including freezing conditions.  The City of  Chicago and the parking meter concessionaire—Chicago Parking Meters
column15: LLC— recognize that any broken meter can be an inconvenience to motorists.  The  concessionaire is committed to ensuring that each motorist has a pleasant parking  experience.  During near sub-zero temperatures
column16: the concessionaire will maintain and  de-ice parking meters.  Problems reported to their customer service personnel are  largely addressed within an hour or two.            1  Will I get a ticket when a pay box is broken because of the cold?  Although parking enforcement personnel work during freezing conditions
column17: they have  been instructed to verify whether a parking meter is operational before issuing any  parking meter violation. If a parking enforcement aide determines that there is a problem  at a meter
column18: he or she is instructed to report it to the concessionaire.  Motorists parking at  a broken meter should report it by contacting the 24 x 7 customer service line at  877.242.7901.        Will I get a ticket when my windshield is covered by snow or ice?  Motorists are obligated to pay to park at a metered space regardless of the weather  conditions.  When parking at a pay box
column19: a motorist should display his or her receipt on  the curb side of the dashboard regardless of the presence of snow or ice.      Drivers generally clear snow off their windshields prior to driving
column20: parking
column21: and displaying  a pay box receipt.  And parking enforcement personnel will gently brush away snow to  determine if a pay box receipt is displayed.  This protocol is not different from years past  when the City operated pay boxes in the Loop and some neighborhoods.  This protocol  is similar to how personnel have historically enforced city sticker
column22: disabled placard
column23: residential permit
column24: and expired plate violations.  Personnel may also need to brush snow  from a single space meter to determine if it is active or from a vehicle’s license plate to  capture the plate number.        Parking enforcement personnel are instructed to use discretion.  In the rare occasion  when a vehicle is covered by an excessive amount of snow or ice
column25: it may be difficult to  determine if a pay box receipt is displayed.   In cases where a pay box receipt may be  obscured by excessive snow or ice
column26: personnel will forego issuing a ticket.  In the  unfortunate event that a motorist receives a ticket in error

What happens if I get a meter violation (section 9-64-190 of the Chicago Municipal  Code) at a broken parking meter?  It is important to report any parking meter problem that you identify.  After reporting the  meter as broken
column28: please request an in-person hearing or contest the violation by mail.   Hearing officers have access to all reports of broken meters and can access that  information when reviewing your case.    Why did I get a ticket if the meter is broken?  Enforcement personnel are trained to recognize inoperable meters.  Unfortunately
column29: a  meter may not always be visibly broken.  If you are issued a meter violation and you feel  it was issued in error

Then contest the violation by  following the directions on the back of the ticket.  Use your reference number during your  hearing or in your correspondence.  Information about your call and the meter history will  be available to a hearing officer during the hearing.    The red light is flashing on the single space meter. What does that mean?   The red light means that time has expired and the meter requires payment.    What types of coins do the old-style meters take?   Quarters and sometimes dollar coins.        2  What types of coins do the “pay and display” boxes take?    Generally quarters and dollars
column31: but the pay and display boxes take credit and debit cards  as well.  They also accept the East Lakeview Chamber of Commerce gift card.     What are some other benefits of pay boxes?  Pay and displays reduce clutter on sidewalks and make neighborhoods more attractive.    These smart boxes notify operators wirelessly when they require collection or are  broken.  Consequently
column32: collection and maintenance crews need to visit meters less  often.  Travel reductions shrink the carbon footprint of collectors and mechanics and  reduce congestion.      How else are the pay boxes “green”?  These environmentally-friendly devices are solar-powered

A motorcycle or scooter owner should write the  license plate number on the receipt to discourage theft.  A receipt is only valid if  displayed on the motorcycle or scooter bearing that license plate number.     CPM worked closely with ABATE

column55: 59 seconds to each initial pay-and-display purchase.  The program was  implemented to mitigate any minor time variations between the pay boxes and other  digital clocks

Parking enforcement aides are instructed to look for motorists before issuing a parking  meter violation.  They are asked to determine if a motorist might be at or walking to or  from a pay box.   Unlike the old single space meters

A maximum of 15 spaces can be served by one box.  Pay and display boxes generally  increase the number of cars that can park on a block.    Where on a block are the pay boxes placed?  On short block faces

column72: the operator tries not to place pay and display boxes in  front of restaurants that might apply for an outdoor café license.  Although the boxes can  be fairly easily moved

column80: consequently

Then select the “Business Feedback Form” to  provide information to us about the needs of your business.       Why did parking meter rates increase?  Properly priced parking meters create better turnover and availability

The central business district is the area bounded by:  South: the south side of Roosevelt Road;  East: Lake Michigan;  North: the north side of North Avenue;  West: the west side of Halsted Street (excluding the area within the boundaries of the  Loop).    What are the boundaries of the Loop?  The Loop is the area bounded by:   On the South: the south side of Congress Parkway;  On the East: Lake Michigan;  On the North: the north side of Wacker Drive;   And on the West: the west side of Wacker Drive.      5  What is the schedule for rate increases over the next three years?  Loop (per hour): 2011: $5.00; 2012: $5.75; 2013: $6.50;  Central Business District (per hour): 2011: $3.00; 2012: $3.50; 2013: $4.00; and  Neighborhoods (per hour): 2011: $1.50; 2012: $1.75; 2013: $2.00.    What are the scheduled rate increases after 2013?  Increases are generally scheduled to track with inflation.    If I buy 2 hours of parking at a 2 hour single space meter

column112: the single space meter will add time until it tops off at  the maximum limit
column113: whether that is 2 hours or some other duration.     What is the parking meter concession?  The concessionaire (or “Chicago Parking Meters
column114: LLC”) paid the City of Chicago $1.156  billion.  In addition
column119: and  repair parking meters for 75 years in return for the revenue from those meters.      How was the parking meter concessionaire selected?  The City sent a request for qualifications to more than 150 infrastructure investors and  parking investors in February 2008.  Ten prospective bidders sent in responses.  Six  were deemed qualified.  Ultimately
column125: 2008.  For a detailed discussion of  the selection process
column126: please visit cityofchicago.org/revenue and select the “About  Parking Meters” link.  Once there
column127: select the link “Selection Process and Timeline”.    Isn’t the concession just a long-term lease?  No
column128: the agreement between the City of Chicago and Chicago Parking Meters
column129: LLC (or  “CPM“) represents a concession to operate the parking meter system. The agreement  requires CPM to provide “metered parking services” which includes the operation
column133: and the collection of  parking meter revenue. No interest in real estate of any kind was conveyed in any form  (sale
column135: or other). The only title received by CPM was for the existing meter  inventory
column136: and that inventory reverts back to the City’s possession upon the agreement’s  expiration or termination.    Why is the concession to operate meters for 75 years?  Why not a shorter period?    This is a requirement of investors.  Typically
column137: debt issued to fund infrastructure projects  is 30-year debt.  Lenders require an additional 10-year ""tail"" in case revenues don't  come in high enough to pay the debt off during the original 30-year period.  Equity  investors are able to increase their returns by refinancing debt during the term of the  concession and thus require at least an additional 10 years.  That results in a minimum  term of 50 years.  In addition
column138: the City received strong indications from the bidders that  they would increase the up-front payment to the City if given an additional 25 years.  And  the increase is greater than the time value of money of an additional 25 years worth of  revenue.      6  Did the City get a good deal?  Yes
column139: the City received a very good deal.  Third party financial advisors used  sophisticated modeling software to determine the likely range of bids.  They predicted  bids between $650 million and $1.2 billion for the parking meter system.  The City’s  minimum acceptable bid was $1 billion
column140: a figure calculated to compensate for the loss of  existing meter revenues and stabilize the budget.  The best and final bid was $1.156  billion from Chicago Parking Meters
column142: an amount at the top end of the projections.   For a detailed discussion of the valuation
column143: please visit cityofchicago.org/revenue and  select the “About Parking Meters” link.  Once there
column144: select the links labeled “Value”  prepared by third party financial advisor William Blair.     Why do some reports suggest that the City could have received more?  Most underestimate risks and operational costs.  Chicago Parking Meters
column146: owns  the risk of installing equipment
column152: changes in driving behavior.  Those risks are  significant.  For a detailed discussion of the valuation
column153: please visit  cityofchicago.org/revenue and select the “About Parking Meters” link.  Once there
column154: select  the links labeled “Value” prepared by third party financial advisor William Blair.       What is the difference between “reserve” and “concession” meters?  There are two types of parking meters operated by the concessionaire: reserve parking  meters and concession parking meters.  The City retains the revenues (minus an  operating expense of 15%) for reserve parking meters
column155: while the concessionaire  receives the revenues from concession parking meters.  The City has the power to  change the status of a meter from reserve to concession
column156: and vice versa.     What is the true-up system?  Under the agreement
column157: the City has agreed to an initial set of scheduled rate increases
column158: followed by annual adjustments to the system value equal to inflation. To the extent the  City implements changes that negatively impact the meter system value
column159: the City may be  required to compensate the concessionaire (“true up”). Similarly
column160: if the City takes action  that increases the value of the system more than is required
column161: the City may capture that  value. Adjustments to meter system value can be in the form of increases in rates
column162: hours  and the number of meters.    How is the dollar amount of any true-up determined?  Each meter is different.  Not only do meters operate at different rates and hours  throughout the City
column163: but utilization also differs depending on the area and businesses  served.  Each meter equates to a fraction of the overall system based on its rate
column165: and utilization (note: this fraction is recalibrated annually based on changes  in utilization).  When a meter is closed--or added--the total system value may be  impacted.  Comparing the fractional value to the revenue for the entire system derives  the revenue value for a particular meter.  Negative impacts are credits due to the  concessionaire.  Positive impacts are credited to the City.  Small changes are less likely  to carry a significant economic impact
column166: especially when utilization is factored into the  analysis already.  Further
column167: financial impacts may be mitigated by other changes to the  meter system.         Did the City bear the same financial risk before the meter concession?  Yes.  The City owns the economic impact today just as it did prior to the concession  when the removal of a parking meter reduced the City’s revenue.  Today
column168: if the meter is      7  a reserve meter
column169: there is still economic impact to the City’s revenue.  If the meter is a  concession meter
column170: the closure of a meter may necessitate a payment to the  concessionaire…or it may not.    What is the process for a developer who needs to temporarily remove parking  meters?  Temporary removals usually result from commercial development projects.  The  municipal code requires developers to apply for a permit and compensate the City for  any associated loss in meter revenue.  This provision of the code predates the parking  meter concession agreement.  Money from the developers is then deposited into a  compensation fund.  That compensation fund is used to offset reductions in City revenue  (for reserve meters) or
column172: to compensate the concessionaire (for  concession meters).    What is the formal process for a business or developer who proposes  permanently altering the public way in a manner that would require the removal of  parking meters?  Permanent meter removals have and continue to require aldermanic approval and  passage by the City Council.  The City Council retains the authority under the  concession agreement to add and remove meters
column175: hours and  days of operation.  When an alderman introduces an ordinance concerning parking  meters
column176: the City reviews the potential social-economic impacts.  Initial considerations for  removing a meter include the impact on congestion
column180: and safety.  The City also considers the economic impact.   For permanent  closures
column181: the City may seek to offset revenue losses through the exercise of reserved  powers like adding meters.  Alternatively
column182: the City may increase the hours or days of  operation or adjust the rates.    Does the business or developer have to pay costs for permanent removals?  There are really no costs assumed by a developer or business if the meter removal is  approved by the City Council.  As stated above
column183: the City would have owned similar  economic risks even if the concession agreement had not been negotiated.  To date
column185: aldermen and city officials have worked closely together in an effort to avoid  negative economic impacts.  For instance
column186: on one occasion an ordinance was  introduced to remove meters to increase sidewalk width in order to have sidewalk cafes  installed.  Passage of the ordinance would have reduced the system in service.   However
column187: the ordinance was amended to allow for the addition of a handful of parking  meters
column188: thereby ensuring that there was no negative impact to the City or the  businesses.      8  "

column1: 9802`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/rev/supp_info/ParkingMeter/PayandDisplayBenefits.pdf`Success`Success`1`1`Not a fillable PDF.`  Pay and Displays  Chicago Parking Meters

column3: or “CPM” is adding pay and displays to the streets of  Chicago at an unprecedented rate of about 30 per day.  In a 5 year period

column7: 236 meters.  In addition

column12: especially and pay and displays  are replaced every 7 to 10 years.        The benefits of pay and displays are significant:     •	  Motorists may pay by credit and debit card or use a  quarter or dollar coin;              •	  They beautify commercial areas by reducing clutter;            •	  They use solar power
column13: reducing the need to recycle more than 40
column14: 000 9-volt               and lithium batteries per year;   •	  Wireless connectivity immediately informs mechanics when the box is broken            or in need of collection.  Consequently
column15: collection and maintenance crews need    to visit meters less often.  Travel reductions shrink the carbon footprint of    collectors and mechanics and reduce congestion.;     •	  Motorists can “pre-pay” for time when there are no posted restrictions;              •	  Motorists will not be charged for time beyond the meters hours of operation;              •	  They can be programmed for variable periods of stay and rates;              •	  Utilization can be measured by hour at each and every block;              •	  They provide a receipt for business and tax purposes.

column1: 9806`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/rev/supp_info/ParkingMeter/ValueAnalysisByWilliamBlair.pdf`Success`Success`12`10`Not a fillable PDF.`Background      value for the Concession of the System.  Although these observers
column2: in many cases
column3: make  an  earnest  attempt  to  analyze  the  value  of  the  System
column4: we  believe  that  many  of  their  assertions
column5: assumptions  and  conclusions  are  not  correct.    In  the  following  analysis
column6: we  illustrate the impact of these misconceptions
column7: using as a basis of comparison information  presented  in  the  Report.    As  discussed  below
column8: the  two  most  significant  inaccuracies  contained in the Report are (i) its use of gross System revenue rather than free net cash  flow in estimating System value and (ii) its use of an inappropriately low discount rate in  estimating the value of the System to the City.  Our analysis confirms that by properly  projecting System revenues and by applying a discount rate that appropriately reflects the  relative risks of the System
column9: the conclusion that the City received full and fair value for  the Concession of the System is clearly supported and affirmed.     The  City  of  Chicago  (the  “City”)  has  been  a  leader  among  American  state  and  local  governments  in  successfully  partnering  with  the  private  sector  by  pursuing  and  completing innovative long-term concessions of the Chicago Skyway
column10: the underground  parking  garages  located  in  Grant  and  Millennium  Parks
column11: and  the  Chicago  Metered  Parking  System.    In  total
column12: those  transactions  have  provided  nearly  $3.6  billion  for  Chicago  residents  and  taxpayers.      Many  other  American  cities  now  hope  to  copy  Chicago’s success
column13: particularly in the area of parking.    The  City  has  applied  the  nearly  $3.6  billion  of  proceeds  from  these  transactions  to:  establish long-term reserve funds of more than $1 billion
column14: including $900 million for the  City and $120 million for the Chicago Park District
column15: to replace revenue generated by the  Skyway
column16: parking garages and parking meters; retire $925 million in debt; reserve more  than $700 million for mid-term budget relief in order to maintain essential City services;  and  invest  more  than  $322  million  in  neighborhoods
column17: parks  and  programs  that  serve  people most in need.    Each  of  the  three  successful  transactions  eliminated  long-term  risks  of  increased  operating  and  capital  expenditures
column18: while  mitigating  the  risk  of  future  changes  in  technology and in the behavior of the users of the assets.    After the $1.83 billion Chicago Skyway concession transaction closed
column19: and the long-term  reserve was established
column20: all three bond rating agencies upgraded the City's credit rating.   Today
column21: the City enjoys its highest credit ratings since 1978.     The $563 million concession of the downtown parking garage system helped to pay off  all of the debt used to build Chicago's world-class Millennium Park
column22: and allowed for a  shift  of  capital  resources  from  downtown  parking  garages  to  neighborhood  parks  throughout the city by investing $122 million in neighborhood park infrastructure.     The City’s announced policy is to pursue long-term public-private partnerships involving  infrastru    cture assets only when:      2  •  There is substantial potential financial benefit to the Chicago tax payers   and residents;   •  The  assets  involved  do  not  involve  the  core  competencies  of  City   government; and    •  Experienced  and  professional  operators  are  able  to  improve  efficiency
column23: quality of service and make enhanced capital investments in the assets.     City  policy  and  concession  agreements  further  require  that  private  operators  treat  employees  fairly
column24: provide  a  high  level  of  safety  and  security
column25: and  satisfy  strong  performance
column26: operating and engineering standards.  Throughout each transaction
column27: the City  has provided great transparency in the robust competitive bidding process and through  the plan      ning of the use of concession proceeds.    How the City Estimated the Value of the System  and Determined the Minimum Acceptable Bid     The City and Blair worked together over a period of months to estimate the value of the  System to infrastructure investors
column28: estimate the potential value of the System to the City  and  identify  the  minimum  bid  amount  that  the  City  would  accept  for  a  75-year  Concession.  Before  proceeding  with  the  transaction
column29: the  City  wanted  reasonable  assurance
column30: using widely-accepted financial valuation methods applicable to infrastructure  assets
column31: and  incorporating  various  assumptions  concerning  rates
column32: utilization
column33: risk  allocation
column34: discount rate and other factors affecting valuation
column35: that a long-term concession  of the System would produce an upfront payment that would be both sufficient to replace  the revenues currently produced by the System and to produce a substantial premium that  would f   Infrastructure Investor Valuation Approach  Blair  used  a  multi-variable  discounted  cash  flow  analysis  to  estimate  the  value  of  the  System to infrastructure investors.  The value of the metered parking system is primarily  a function of two factors:     airly compensate the City for a 75-year concession.        •  The  long-term  free  cash  flow  of  the  System  ---  estimated  operating  revenue  (which  makes  assumptions  about  driver  utilization)
column36: minus  operating  expenses
column37: minus  capital  expenditures  and  corporate  tax  liabilities; and   •  The  bidder’s  cost  and  mix  of  debt  and  equity  financing  or  cost  of   capital.   In  estimating  the  value  of  the  proposed  long-term  concession  of  the  System
column38: Blair  prepared and continued to refine its multi-variable analysis using a variety of assumptions  for the factors that impact long-term free cash flow and the bidder’s cost of capital.  Blair  began  by  identifying  all  the  factors  that  impact  either  long-term  free  cash  flow  or  the      3  bidder’s cost of capital.  Next
column39: Blair constructed a range of potential values for each of  those factors and assigned each potential value with a probability of occurrence.  As such
column40: the probabilities for all the potential values of a factor add up to 100%.  A scenario was  calculated for every possible combination of those factors
column41: which produced thousands of  outcomes
column42: each  with  a  very  small  probability  of  occurrence  based  on  the  individual  probabilities of the factors.  The analysis produced a standard distribution of outcomes
column43: similar to a “bell curve” of grades in a college class.  Based on this bell curve
column44: Blair was  able to predict a range of values based on confidence intervals.       Using the valuation method described above
column45: Blair initially established a valuation range  for  the  Concession  of  between  $650  million  and  $1.2  billion.    While  this  range  was  refined  during the bidding process
column46: the top end of the range never exceeded $1.2 billion.       City Held System Valuation Approach     The estimated value of the System in the City’s hands is much more hypothetical.  As  such
column47: there are several ways to approach the value of the System had the City not entered  into the Concession.    Approach 1 – Current Practices    In 2005
column48: the City increased the rate on meters located in the Loop from $1.50 to $3.00 per  hour.  This marked the first time in many years that the City increased meter rates on  such  a  widespread  basis.    This  increase  affected  approximately  1
column49: 000  spaces  and  represented  only  3%  of  the  System.    More  importantly
column50: the  $0.25  hourly  rate  for  approximately 75% of the System had not been increased in over 20 years.  Exhibit 1  (attached) estimates the value of the System assuming continued operation by the City  and annual rate increases of 3.0%.  This assumption is probably aggressive given the fact  that the rates on 75% City meters had not increased in over 20 years.  During that 20-year  period
column51: the rate of inflation average approximately 3.2% per year.     Using  this  valuation  method  and  a  discount  rate  ranging  from  10.00%  to  14.00%
column52: the  estimated  value  of  the  System  would  be  between  $177  million  and  $276  million  (see  Exhibit 1).      Approach 2 – Concession Practices    The  City  faced  two  significant  challenges  to  increasing  parking  meter  rates.    First
column53: as  discussed above
column54: the rates on most meters in the System had not been increased in many  years  and  there  was  a  general  lack  of  uniformity  as  to  rates  and  hours  of  operation.   Second
column55: there was also the challenge of acquiring the expensive “pay and display” meter  technology that would be needed to support higher meter rates.  The estimated total cost  (equipment and labor) for upgrading the City’s meter technology is approximately $50  million.    Given  the  other  higher  priority  demands  on  the  City’s  limited  capital  improvement funds
column56: it seemed unlikely that adequate funding would be available from      4  City  capital  dollars  to  pay  for  the  prompt  acquisition  and  installation  of  new  meter  technology.      This valuation approach ignores these two challenges and the risks associated with each  and assumes that the City increased rates in the same manner as under the Concession  transaction.  Although many factors impact the value of the System to the City
column57: the two  that have the largest impact are the reaction of parkers to rate increases during the initial  five years of rate increases and the City’s discount rate.    Starting  in  year  six  of  the  pricing  structure
column58: rates  increase  to  keep  pace  with  inflation.   Because beginning in year six rates do not increase on a real basis
column59: there is no reason to  expect that utilization will be impacted solely by parking meter rates.  However
column60: during  the first five years rates do increase substantially
column61: in some cases going from $0.25 per  hour to $2.00 per hour.  The impact on utilization due to price increases is the elasticity  of  demand
column62: defined  as  the  percentage  impact  on  demand  when  price  changes  by  1%.   Obviously
column63: as  discussed  below
column64: utilization  may  be  adversely  impacted  by  a  variety  of  other factors
column65: and the City has shifted all of these utilization risks to the concessionaire.    The Inspector General’s Report analyzes five separate revenue scenarios
column66: which are each  produced by differing assumptions regarding the elasticity of demand for street parking.   The analysis that Blair prepared for the City analyzed the impact that all relevant factors  had on value
column67: not just demand elasticity.  However
column68: given that this is the only factor that  the Report used and to keep things simple
column69: Exhibit 2 (attached) uses those scenarios and  produces a value for each:     (cid:131)  Scenario 1 - Year five revenue is $85 million – The estimated value of the  System is $515 million to $850 million
column70: assuming a discount rate of 10.0%  to  14.0%  (see  discussion  below  concerning  the  calculation  of  discount  rates).     (cid:131)  Scenario 2 - Year five revenue is $100 million – The estimated value of  the System is $625 million to $1.024 billion
column71: assuming a discount rate of  10.0% to 14.0%.                  (cid:131)  Scenario 3 - Year five revenue is $107.5 million – The estimated value of  the System is $678 million to $1.111 billion
column72: assuming a discount rate of  10.0% to 14.0%.   (cid:131)  Scenario 4 - Year five revenue is $115 million – The estimated value of  the System is $732 million to $1.198 billion
column73: assuming a discount rate of  10.0% to 14.0%.   (cid:131)  Scenario 5 - Year five revenue is $130 million – The estimated value of  the System is $839 million to $1.372 billion
column74: assuming a discount rate of  10.0% to 14.0%.   5  Assuming  that  the  City  could  raise  rates  in  the  same  manner  as  under  the  Concession  transaction
column75: and  had  adequate  capital  dollars  available  to  fund  meter  technology  upgrades
column76: the City established its minimum acceptable bid of $1 billion at the high-end of  the  estimated  System  value.    This  target  is  affirmed  as  reasonable  and  fair  given  the  revenue assumptions that we utilized.  As it turned out
column77: the winning bid was at the very  top range of the estimated value to the City based on this method.      Analysis of the Inspector General’s Report     While the Report represents an earnest attempt to analyze and critique the Concession
column78: we  believe  that  many  of  the  assertions
column79: assumptions  and  conclusions  contained  in  the  Report  are  not  correct.    It  appears  that  the  Report  reflects  a  number  of  conclusory  statements
column80: the merits of which are impossible to determine since they are made without  citing  any  authoritative  sources  or  precedent.    Rather  than  attempt  a  point-by-point  rebuttal
column81: the  following  discussion  focuses  on  the  two  main  major  issues  raised  in  the  Report that deal with System value to the City.    Revenue vs. Free Cash Flow    The Report assumes $500
column82: 000 in annual capital expenditures for the System beginning in  year three.  Upon conversion to cashless payment meter technology
column83: the System will be  comprised of approximately 4
column84: 000 meters with an average acquisition cost of $11
column85: 250 per  meter.    Meters  of  this  nature  typically  last  seven  to  ten  years  before  they  need  to  be  replaced.  Assuming the meters are replaced every 10 years
column86: annual capital expenditures  would actually equal $4
column90: 250 / 10 years).  This figure represents only  true capital costs and does not reflect any increases to operating expenses associated with  repair  and  maintenance  of  technologically  advanced  machinery  that  is  exposed  to  the  elements.  Further
column91: it completely ignores any other capital expenditures throughout the  System.  It appears that the Report understates the cost of System capital expenditures  by $4 million every year
column92: thus overstating the amount of System free cash flow in each  year.    The Report states that “Free Cash Flow” in year five in each of the five scenarios was  $85 million to $130 million.  The Report’s analysis then applies a discount rate to these  sums to determine value.  The Report’s analysis confuses the concept of free cash flow  with revenue
column93: thus completely ignoring significant operating costs of at least $5 million  per year.  It appears that the Report understates the cost of operating the System by $5  million every year
column94: thus overstating System free cash flow in each year.    These two mistakes combine to overstate annual free cash flow by $9 million per year.   Exhibit 3 (attached) demonstrates the impact that these mistakes have on the value of the  System for each of the Report’s revenue scenarios.          6  Discount Rate    Discount rates are applied by investors based upon perceived risk.  In determining the  applicable  discount  rate
column95: the  Report  cites  a  single  study  by  Partnerships  Victoria  to  determine  the  applicable  discount  rate.    According  to  this  study
column96: municipal-owned  projects fall in one of three risk categories:     Very Low: Discount Rate of 7.06%  Low: Discount Rate of 8.26%  Medium: Discount Rate of 10.4%   (cid:131)  (cid:131)  (cid:131)     (cid:131)  (cid:131)  (cid:131)   The Report states that the System should be placed in the “Very Low” category with a  discount  rate  of  7.06%.    However
column97: the  Partnerships  Victoria  study  specifically  places  parking  in  the  Low  category
column98: not  the  Very  Low  category.    Additionally
column99: the  System  clearly  meets  the  criteria  identified  by  Partnerships  Victoria  that  justify  placing  the  System in an even higher risk category than it would otherwise be placed:     Project value in excess of $500 million  Unique system risks  Demand risk is fully transferred     Therefore
column100: correctly applying the Partnerships Victoria methodology would result in the  System being placed in the “Medium” category with a discount rate of 10.40%.    The Report does not state why it chose to place the System in the “Very Low” category
column101: but there is no stated logic behind that decision.  For example
column102: the Partnerships Victoria  study places drinking water in the “Low” risk category.  Thus the Report implies that the  demand for drinking water is more elastic or risky than the demand for on-street parking.   This  unexplained  judgment  alone  causes  a  seismic  shift  in  the  estimated  value  of  the  System.  Exhibit 3 demonstrates the impact that this flaw has on the value of the System  for each of the Report’s revenue scenarios.    Correcting the Report’s mistakes with regard to confusing revenue with free cash flow  and  using  the  improper  discount  rate  creates  a  valuation  range  of  between  $848  million and $1.295 billion and clearly reflects the soundness of the winning bid – even  when evaluating it using the Report’s selected source.    More on Discount Rates    Again
column103: the Partnerships Victoria report is only one source regarding the proper discount  rate for municipal-owned concession projects.  We are unaware why the author chose this  source.  It appears to be an obscure report produced over four years ago by an Australian  state government.  It is
column105: readily available for download on the internet.  The  truth is
column106: there is no generally accepted approach to determining the applicable discount  rate for municipal owned concession projects.  The City used discount rates in the range      7  of 10% to 14% for its valuation analysis.  The following is the logic behind the City’s  approach.      Definition  -  Discount  rate  is  defined  by  Investopedia.com  as  “the  interest  rate  used  in  determining  the  present  value  of  future  cash  flow”.    Simply  put
column107: it  is  the  rate  used  to  convert the value of dollars in the future into the value of dollars today.  For any given  valuation  analysis
column108: the  applicable  discount  rate  equals  the  “risk-free  rate”  plus  a  “risk  premium.”  Although the risk-free rate is a hypothetical rate
column109: it is generally accepted by  financial analysts to equal the rate of a United States Treasury bond with a maturity equal  to the related cash flow stream.  The risk premium is specific to the risks attributable to  the specific investment being valued and is defined by Investopedia.com as “a form of  compensation for investors who tolerate the extra risk - compared to that of a risk-free  asset  - in  a  given  investment”.    For  example
column110: the  risk  premium  for  an  internet  start-up  company is higher than that associated with a well-established company like Microsoft
column111: given the greater risks related to a start-up business.      Risk-free rate - The current yield on a 30-year Treasury bond (i.e. the 30-year risk-free  rate) is approximately 4.591%.  Obviously
column112: the term of the concession is 75 years
column113: which  would suggest an even higher risk free rate.    Risk premium – The fact that City has shifted 75 years worth of considerable risk to the  concessionaire can not be ignored.  Infrastructure investors demand a higher return than  investors in bonds and stocks
column114: which means that the risk premium for infrastructure assets  is  higher.    Typically
column115: a  diversified  stock  portfolio  has  a  risk-premium  of  3%  to  5%.   Depending upon the industry
column116: A-rated corporate bonds currently have a risk-premium of  3% to 5%. As a stand alone revenue source
column117: the System would achieve a credit rating of   BBB+ at best (compared with the City’s “AA” credit rating)
column118: requiring a higher premium  to compensate for the risks described below.    Conclusion  -  Even  risk-free  investments  (if  there  were  such  a  thing)  would  be  valued  using a discount rate of at least 4.5%.  The appropriate risk premium should be higher  than either a diversified stock portfolio or an A-rated corporate bond.  Accordingly
column119: a risk  premium range of 5.5% to 9.5% would be more appropriate.  Based on a risk-free rate of  4.5%
column120: this results in a discount rate range of 10.0% to 14.0%.    Alternative – One way to provide a reality check to the City’s discount rate of 10.0% to  14.0% is to ask the following hypothetical question: If the City issued $1 billion of bonds  secured  only  by  the  net  operating  revenue  of  the  System  (i.e.  no  general  obligation  backing by the City)
column121: what interest rate would they pay on those bonds?  Those bonds
column122: if  they could be sold at all

column1: 9809`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/rev/supp_info/Vandalism/Vandalism201005.pdf`Success`Success`1`1`Not a fillable PDF.`       Revenue Department Comments on a Recent Report    Concerning Parking Meter Vandalism      A recent report implied that vandalism is on the rise.  It is not.  Vandalism has actually declined.     During the summer of 2009
column2: the parking meter concessionaire reported only 47 incidents of  vandalism including attempts to willfully damage parking meters.  In the months of May and June
column3: one vandalized meter was reported by the concessionaire per day.  In July and August
column4: the  concessionaire reported a 50% reduction: only one vandalized meter every two days.      The concessionaire reports that more than 99% of the meter system is operational on average.   Graffiti has remained fairly stable throughout the summer of 2009. Graffiti usually is limited to  “tagging” or the act of writing a name or nickname on a meter
column5: and typically has no impact on the  operation of the meter.  The concessionaire documented about 4.4 incidents per day in May/June  and about 5.5 incidents per day in July/August.       Vandalism or graffiti are nothing new.  The City’s meter mechanics regularly dealt with  intentionally broken and tagged meters.  And Chicago is not alone in this regard.  It takes just a  quick Google search to find cities from coast to coast that have dealt (and will continue to deal)  with vandalism.    Vandalism and graffiti of any kind are not tolerated by businesses and residents.  If you park at a  parking meter that is inoperable or would like to report graffiti on a parking meter
column6: please call the  concessionaire’s 24 hour customer support line at 877.242.7901.  Inoperable or “tagged” parking  meters are addressed in just a few hours
column7: a significant improvement over past years.  All repairs  are made at the concessionaire’s expense.

column1: 11342`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/rev/supp_info/TaxRulingsandRegulations/AmusementTaxRuling1.pdf`Success`Success`2`2`Not a fillable PDF.`   CITY OF CHICAGO   DEPARTMENT OF REVENUE  AMUSEMENT TAX RULING      Amusement Tax Ruling #1  Subject:   Application of tax to patrons of participatory entertainment and recreational                   activities.  Effective date:  June 1
column2: 2004    Formerly Ruling #86-1
column3: as amended  Original effective date:  February 17
column4: 1986  Amended:  March 1
column5: 1989    In  general
column6: Section  4-156-020(A)  of  the  Chicago  Municipal  Code  Section 1.  (“Code”)  imposes  a  tax  upon  the  patrons  of  every  amusement  within  the  City  (the  “amusement tax” or “tax”).  Section 4-156-010 defines an “amusement” as including (1)  various exhibitions
column7: performances
column8: presentations or shows that a person may witness or  view
column9: (2)  various  entertainment  or  recreational  activities  in  which  a  person  may  participate
column10: and  (3)  paid  television  programming.    This  ruling  discusses  primarily  the  second category described above (i.e.
column11: entertainment or recreational activities in which a  person may participate).    Section 2.  In  general
column12: all  entertainment  or  recreational  activities  offered  for  public  participation or on a membership or other basis are amusements subject to the tax.  Code  Section  4-156-020.    This  includes  entertainment  and  recreational  activities  such  as  amusement  park  rides  and  games
column13: circuses
column14: carnivals
column15: fishing
column16: skating
column17: pleasure  boat  rides
column18: dancing
column19: bowling
column20: golf
column21: pool
column22: billiards
column23: swimming
column24: racquetball
column25: weightlifting
column26: and  bodybuilding.    Activities  that  are  primarily  educational  are  not  amusements and therefore are not subject to the tax.     Section 3.  The  tax  is  on  the  patrons  of  any  amusement  within  the  city.  The  tax  is  based  on  the  admission  fees  or  other  charges  for  the  privilege  to  participate  in  the  amusement.  Initiation fees and membership dues paid to a health club
column27: racquetball club
column28: tennis club or a similar club or organization
column29: when such club or organization is organized  and operated on a membership basis and for the recreational purposes of its members and  its members' guests
column30: are exempt from the tax.  This exemption does not apply to any fees  paid or based upon
column31: in any way whatsoever
column32: a per-event or a per-admission basis.    Section 4.  The term “admission fees or other charges” includes
column33: but is not limited to  any fee
column34: charge or other consideration paid for the right to participate in the recreational  activity or entertainment.  This includes fees paid to a club or other organization
column35: other  than initiation and membership fees referred to in section 3 above
column36: for the right to use the  recreational or entertainment facilities of such club or other organization. Guest fees or  charges  paid  by  non-members  of  a  club  or  other  organization  for  the  right  to  use  the  recreational or entertainment facilities of such club or other organization also are taxable.   tennis
column37: However
column38: additional  fees  or  other  charges  paid  by  a  member  or  guest  solely  for  instructors (such as for tennis or racquetball instruction)
column39: or for the purchase of goods
column40: are  not  taxable  charges
column41: because  they  are  not charges  for    amusements.    Such  non-taxable  charges  must  be  separately  stated  by  the  amusement  provider
column42: otherwise  they  shall  be  deemed to be part of the charge for the  taxable amusement.    Section 5.  The  amusement  tax  is  collected  by  the  amusement  provider  from  the  amusement patron.  The tax is collected at the time the taxable fees
column43: dues or other charges  are paid.  All tax returns are to be filed with the department on an annual basis on or  before August 15 of each year in accordance with Sections 3-4-186 and 3-4-189 of the  Code
column44: and  all  tax  payments  are  to  be  made  in  accordance  with  either  Section  3-4-187  (payment of actual tax liabilities) or Section 3-4-188 (payment of estimated taxes).    Section 6.  recreational facilities
column45: and one or more of such facilities are located outside the city
column46: the  patron shall owe a tax only on a prorated portion of such fee and may exclude that  portion of the fee which relates to the actual percentage of time he or she enters and uses  such facilities located outside the city
column47: as compared with the total time he or she enters  and uses all of the facilities.  The Department of Revenue shall also deem a proration  based upon the square footage of the recreational or entertainment space of the facilities  to be a reasonable proration.  Other systems of proration may be approved by the  Department
column48: upon application to the Department. (This section does not apply to patrons  who pay a fee to enter
column49: within the city
column50: a mobile entertainment or recreational vehicle.)   If a patron pays one fee to enter and use two or more entertainment or

column1: 11343`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/rev/supp_info/TaxRulingsandRegulations/AmusementTaxRuling2.pdf`Success`Success`1`1`Not a fillable PDF.`CITY OF CHICAGO   DEPARTMENT OF REVENUE   AMUSEMENT TAX RULING AND   PERSONAL PROPERTY LEASE TRANSACTION TAX RULING      Amusement Tax Ruling #2 and  Personal Property Lease Transaction Tax Ruling #7  Subject: Boat rides and boat leases  Effective date:  June 1
column2: 2004    Formerly Amusement Tax Ruling #2 and  Personal Property Lease Transaction Tax Ruling #11  Original effective date:  April 30
column3: 1991           Where boats are leased or chartered or where sightseeing or other boat rides are  provided
column4: the  boat  operator  must  collect  and  remit  either  the  personal  property  lease  transaction tax (Chicago Municipal Code chapter 3-32) or the amusement tax (Chicago  Municipal Code chapter 4-156)
column5: depending on the nature of the transaction.      The amusement tax applies under the following circumstances:     ·  The boat operator provides a pilot
column6: and the boat will travel on a route that is  predetermined by the boat operator and not subject to negotiation with the patron.     The transaction tax applies in either of the following circumstances:      ·  The boat is leased without a pilot.   ·  The boat is leased with a pilot and the patron/lessee may determine the route.  In  this  situation
column7: piloting  and  other  service  charges  will  not  be  subject  to  the  transaction  tax  if  these  charges  are  separately  stated.  The  remaining  charge  is  subject to the transaction tax.     All separately stated service charges must be supported by documentary evidence in  order to be non-taxable.

column1: 11344`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/rev/supp_info/TaxRulingsandRegulations/AmusementTaxRuling3.pdf`Success`Success`2`2`Not a fillable PDF.`       CITY OF CHICAGO   DEPARTMENT OF REVENUE  AMUSEMENT TAX RULING      Amusement Tax Ruling #3   Subject: Record Retention Requirements  Effective date:  June 1
column2: 2004    Formerly Ruling #3  Original effective date:  November 13
column3: 1996    Section 1.  Section 4-156-030(B) of the Amusement Tax Ordinance
column4: chapter 4-156 of the  Municipal  Code  of  Chicago
column5: requires  every  amusement  tax  collector  to  keep  accurate  books  and  records  of  its  business  or  activity
column6: specifically  including  original  source  documents.  Pursuant to this requirement
column7: every  amusement tax collector must retain one  of the following:     a.   Admission tickets in the form and containing such information as provided  by section 2 below;          b.   c.   Cash register receipts; or   Such  other  records  in  a  form  previously  approved  in  writing  by  the  director of revenue.     Section 2.  If tickets are used
column8: each ticket shall consist of at least two parts; one part shall  be issued to the patron
column9: the other part shall be retained by the tax collector.  Each part of  the ticket shall state on its face the name and address of the place where the amusement is  being held
column10: the amount paid for the ticket and the date of the event.  Tickets issued for  amusements that do not have a specific address where the amusement is held
column11: such as  boat  tours  or  horse-and-carriage  rides
column12: shall  state  the  location  where  the  tour  or  ride  begins.  Tickets shall be issued in numerical order
column13: and each part shall contain the same  serial number.    Section 3.  If an amusement tax collector retains both cash register receipts and admission  tickets
column14: the admission tickets do not need to comply with section 2 of this ruling.    Section 4.  All source documents required by section 4-156-030(B) shall be retained for  at least four years after the end of the calendar year in which they are created; provided
column15: however
column16: that an operator on an annual basis may request approval from the director of  revenue to discard source documents that were created more than one year earlier
column17: and  the  director  will  grant  approval  if  he  or  she  determines  that  the  operator’s  source  documents contain all information required by section 4-156-030(B) and this ruling.     Section 5.  Pursuant to section 3-4-310 of the Uniform Revenue Procedures Ordinance
column18: chapter 3-4 of the Municipal Code of Chicago
column19: tax collectors who violate section 4-156- 030(B) and this ruling shall be subject to  the fines and penalties set forth in section 3-4- 310
column20: including a fine of not less than $50.00 nor more than $200.00 for the first offense.   The failure of a tax collector to retain required source documents also may result in the  department of revenue estimating additional amusement tax liability and issuing the tax  collector a tax determination and assessment.

column1: 11346`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/rev/supp_info/TaxSupportingInformation/December_1998_Info_Bulletin_Amusement_Tax.pdf`Success`Success`2`2`Not a fillable PDF.`December 1998 Information Bulletin    Information Bulletin  Amendments to Chicago Amusement Tax Ordinance     TO: REGISTERED AMUSEMENT PROVIDERS  The Chicago City Council recently passed amendments to the Amusement tax ordinance
column2: effective January 1
column4: which include amongst other things
column5: a reduction in the rate of the tax  for certain amusements and the elimination of tax on others. Both of these amendments are  dependant on the maximum capacity of the venues in which the amusements will be conducted  and the nature of the related performances.   Tax Reduction on Certain Amusements:  Pursuant to revisions to section-4-156-020 E.
column6: the rate of tax on admission fees or other charges
column7: to witness in person live theatrical
column8: live musical or other live cultural performances that take  place in any auditorium
column9: theater or other space in the city
column10: whose maximum capacity
column11: including  all balconies and other sections
column12: is more than 750 persons and less than 5000 persons
column13: has been  reduced to 3%.   Elimination of Tax on Certain Amusements and Maximum Capacity:  Pursuant to revisions to section 4-156-020 D.
column14: the amusement tax shall not apply to or be  imposed upon the admission fees to witness in person live theatrical
column15: live musical or other live  cultural performances that take place in any auditorium
column16: theater or other space in the city whose  maximum capacity
column17: including all balconies and other sections
column18: is not more than 750 persons.   If all of the amusements conducted in your venue meet the requirements of this section and  your venue AT ALL TIMES has a capacity of not more than 750 persons
column19: you should  complete and return the enclosed affidavit according to the instructions included thereon.  Upon verification and approval
column20: we will deactivate your amusement tax account.   Clarification of Effective Date:  Both of the rate amendments shall take effect on January 1
column21: 1999. The 3% rate and the  elimination of tax
column22: shall only apply to admission charges or other fees billed and paid on or after  January 1
column23: 1999.   If you have any questions as to whether your amusements qualify as musical
column24: theatrical or  cultural performances
column25: you   may either contact our Tax Customer Service unit at (312) 747-9723 or the Law Department's  Tax Division
column26: at 30 N. LaSalle
column27: Room 1040
column28: Chicago IL. 60602. You may also contact Customer  service for a complete copy of the ordinance revising the Amusement tax.            Questions?  If you have questions or need more information
column29: please write or call us. Our address and  telephone numbers are:   City of Chicago  Department of Revenue  Tax Policy Division  333 South State Street
column30: Ste. 300  Chicago

column1: 11347`https://www.cityofchicago.org/dam/city/depts/rev/supp_info/TaxSupportingInformation/December_2006_Info_Bulletin_Amusement_Tax.pdf`Success`Success`1`1`Not a fillable PDF.`"Vol. 2006  No. 3                                               CHICAGO DEPARTMENT OF REVENUE  December 2006  TO:  All Bar and Night Club Owners:  The purpose of this informational bulletin is to clarify  the Chicago Amusement Tax
column2: chapter 4-156 of the Chicago Municipal Code (“Code”)
column3: as it pertains to disc jockeys (DJs) who service various bars and night clubs within the City of Chicago.  General Information  An amusement tax is imposed upon the patrons of every amusement within the city.  Section 4-156-020 provides for an exemption or for a reduced rate of tax for live cultural performances.  The Chicago Department of Revenue (“Department”) has released a tax ruling that specifies situations in which the Department will consider the activities of a DJ to qualify  as a ""live cultural performance"" at a dance club or other venue
column4: and therefore qualify for the exemption or reduced rate set forth in Subsections 4-156-020(D)(1) and (E) of the Code.  This ruling
column5: Amusement Tax Ruling #4
column6: is attached to this bulletin.  What is the tax rate?  The rate of the tax shall be equal to eight percent of the admission fees or other charges paid for the privilege to enter
column7: to witness
column8: to view or to participate in such amusement
column9: unless (1) the event is considered to be a live cultural performance at a venue with a maximum seating capacity of more than 750
column10: in which case the tax rate is four percent (see subsection 4-156-020(E)
column11: or (2) the event is considered to be a live cultural performance at a venue with a maximum seating capacity of 750 or less
column12: in which case the event is exempt (see subsection 4- 156-020(D)(1))  INFORMATIONAL BULLETIN  #Chicago Amusement Tax  Can all bars and night clubs claim the live cultural exemption for any night a DJ is playing?  How often is the Amusement Tax  remitted and when are returns due?  No.  The ruling sets very specific guidelines that dictate under which circumstances a DJ qualifies as live entertainment.  The ruling states that the DJ’s activities must substantially add to or otherwise modify the pre-recorded material used by the DJ
column13: in the form of a significant degree of technical manipulation
column14: singing
column15: speaking
column16: dancing or other activity.  Please refer to Amusement Tax Ruling #4 for further clarification on how to determine if the Department will deem a DJ to be live entertainment.  What if
column17: after reading the Tax Ruling
column18: I still cannot determine if the DJ can be considered a live cultural performance for Chicago amusement tax purposes?  If desired
column19: at least 14 days in advance of an event involving a DJ
column20: a venue may submit to the Department books and records showing the name of each DJ who will perform at the venue
column21: the dates and times of each DJ performance
column22: and the admission fees or other charges paid by patrons to witness the DJ at each of the dates and times at which each DJ performs
column23: along with the DJ’s contract
column24: and such other documents and information as the Department may reasonably require. The Department will endeavor to provide the venue with an advance written determination of whether or not the event qualifies for treatment as a live cultural performance.  The tax is to be remitted monthly with taxes collected in one month payable by the last day of the subsequent month.  The tax return for periods commencing on July 1st of each year and ending on June 30th of the subsequent year
column25: is filed annually and is due by August 15th of each year.  Questions?  Please visit our website at: www.cityofchicago.org/revenue for more information on this tax or any of our other taxes.  If you wish to speak with someone in person
column26: please call our customer service unit at 312-747-IRIS (4747) between the hours of 8am and 4pm.  You may also write us at the address below:  City of Chicago Department of Revenue Tax Policy Division c/o Raul Medina 333 South State Street
column27: Suite 300 Chicago
column28: Illinois 60604-3977 rmedina@cityofchicago.org  "
