column8: Illinois 60604-3977 rmedina@cityofchicago.org  You may also visit our website: www.cityofchicago.org for more information on Amusement Tax.  This Informational Bulletin is provided for general informational purposes only.  Please consult the Municipal Code of Chicago for specific requirements.

column1: 11349`https://www.cityofchicago.org/dam/city/depts/rev/supp_info/TaxSupportingInformation/March_2009_Info_Bulletin_ Amusement_Tax.pdf`Success`Success`1`1`Not a fillable PDF.`Vol. 2009  No. 1                                               CHICAGO DEPARTMENT OF REVENUE  March 2009  INFORMATIONAL BULLETIN  TO:  All wireless phone service providers:  The purpose of this informational bulletin is to discuss “Mobile Television” (Mobile TV) as it pertains to the Chicago Amusement Tax
column2: Chicago Municipal Code (Code) chapter 4-156.  Please refer to the ordinance for exact terms.   What is considered an Amusement?  Per Code section 4-156-010
column3: the term “amusement” includes:  “(3) any paid television programming
column4: whether transmitted by wire
column5: cable
column6: fiber optics
column7: laser
column8: microwave
column9: radio
column10: satellite or similar means.”  What is the tax rate?  Please visit our website for current tax rate information.  Our web address is  www.cityofchicago.org/revenue.  What is Mobile TV?  Mobile TV is a service which allows users to view paid television programming on their wireless phones.  The users are typically charged a monthly fee for this type of service
column11: and the charge appears on their wireless phone bill.  Is Mobile TV an amusement?  Yes.  Mobile TV is a form of paid television programming that fits the definition of “amusement” per Code section 4-156-010 and is therefore subject to the amusement tax.   #Chicago Amusement Tax Who is responsible for payment of the tax?  The subscribers of the service are responsible for paying the tax to their wireless phone service providers.  Who is responsible for collection of the tax?  It is each wireless phone service provider’s responsibility to collect the tax and remit it to the Department.   How often is the tax remitted?  The tax is to be remitted monthly with taxes collected in one month payable by the last day of the subsequent month.  The tax return for periods commencing on July 1 of each year and ending on June 30 of the subsequent year
column12: is filed annually and is due by August 15 of each year.    Once registered
column13: returns and payments can be made through the U.S. postal service
column14: in person
column15: or online at www.cityofchicago.org/revenue  How do I determine which customers are subject to the Chicago Amusement Tax on Mobile TV?  The Department will accept use of the Mobile Telecommunications Sourcing Conformity Act
column16: 35 ILCS 638
column17: as the basis for determining which Mobile TV customers are subject to the City’s amusement tax.  This is the same rule that is used to determine which wireless phone service customers are subject to the City’s simplified telecommunications tax
column18: Code chapter 3-73.  Therefore
column19: customers who are subject to the City’s   telecommunications tax on their wireless phone service charges are subject to the City’s amusement tax on any charges for Mobile TV.  Conversely
column20: customers who are not subject to the City’s telecommunications tax on their wireless   phone service charges are not subject to the City’s amusement tax on any charges for Mobile TV.  Where a customer is subject to both the City’s telecommunications tax and the City’s amusement tax
column21: the wireless phone service provider is responsible for collecting both taxes and remitting them to the  Department.  Questions?  If you have questions or need more information
column22: please write us.  Our address is:  City of Chicago Department of Revenue Tax Policy Division c/o Raul Medina 333 South State Street
column23: Suite 300 Chicago
column24: Illinois 60604-3977 rmedina@cityofchicago.org

column1: 11350`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/rev/supp_info/TaxSupportingInformation/AmusementTaxGeneralInfo-UpdatedFor2018.pdf`Success`Success`1`1`Not a fillable PDF.`"IS YOUR EVENT SUBJECT TO THE CHICAGO AMUSEMENT TAX?      Section  4-156-020  of  the  Chicago  Municipal  Code  imposes  a  tax  upon  the  patrons  of  every  amusement  within  the  City.    The  tax  is  based  on  the  admission  fees  or  other  charges  for  the  privilege  to  enter
column2: to  witness
column3: to  view  or  to  participate  in the  amusement.    This  publication  is  a  summary.   Please consult the ordinance and any applicable rulings or other official statements for details.    What is an amusement?  In general
column4: all entertainment or recreational activities offered for public participation or on a membership or other basis are  amusements subject to the tax.      How  do  I  know  if  my  event  is  taxable?    Examples  of  taxable  fees  or  charges  include  but  are  not  limited  to  those  for  sporting  events
column5: concerts
column6: movies
column7: cover charges
column8: pub crawls
column9: sport and social clubs
column10: tours
column11: cruises
column12: etc.      Who  is  responsible  for  collecting  and  remitting  the  tax?    Owners
column13: managers
column14: and  operators  of  amusements  or  places  where  amusements  are  conducted  and  resellers  must  collect  from  patrons  the  tax  imposed  by  the  amusement  tax  code.  Note:  ""Operator""  means  any  person  who  sells  or  resells a ticket to an amusement or who
column15: directly or through an agreement or arrangement with another party indirectly
column16: collects the charges paid for  the sale or resale of a ticket to an amusement. The term includes
column17: but is not limited to
column18: persons engaged in the business of selling or reselling tickets to  amusements
column19: whether  on-line
column20: in  person  or  otherwise.  The  term  also  includes  persons  engaged  in  the  business  of  facilitating  the  sale  or  resale  of  tickets to amusements
column21: whether on-line
column22: in person or otherwise.    What is the tax rate?  The tax rate is 9% of charges paid.  The term ""charges paid"" includes any and all charges that the patron pays incidental to  obtaining  the  privilege  to  enter
column23: to  witness
column24: to  view  or  to  participate  in  an  amusement
column25: including  but  not  limited  to  any  and  all  related  markups
column26: service fees
column27: convenience fees
column28: facilitation fees
column29: cancelation fees and other such charges
column30: regardless of terminology.    The  capacity  of  my  venue  is  not  more  than  1
column31: 500  persons.    Are  my  events  exempt  from  the  tax?      The  Amusement  Tax  shall  not  apply  to  admission fees to witness in person live cultural performances that take place in any auditorium
column32: theater or other space in the city whose maximum  capacity
column33: including all balconies and other sections
column34: is not more than 1
column35: 500 persons.  Note: this exemption applies only to venues where admission  fees are paid to witness live cultural performances.  It does not apply to charges for movies
column36: pub crawls
column37: sporting events
column38: etc.  The 9% Amusement  Tax will continue to apply to these types of amusements
column39: regardless of venue capacity.      How should resale transactions be taxed?  The rate of tax imposed upon the buyer of a ticket in a resale transaction shall be equal to 3% of the  admission fees or other charges paid for the ticket in the resale transaction.   If the buyer in a resale transaction purchases the ticket for purposes of  resale
column40: then  no  tax  shall be  due  from  the  buyer  on  the  purchase  if  the  buyer  is  registered  with  the City's  Department  of  Finance  as  a  tax  collector  under Section 4-156-030.  Finally
column41: if the original sale of a ticket is exempt
column42: then the resale of that ticket is exempt as well.   How do I get registered with the Department of Finance? If you do not have an account number with the City of Chicago and your business does  not require a license issued by the City
column43: complete and submit a Tax Registration Form and an Affidavit for Initial Tax Period.  If you already have an  account number with the City because you have a business license or are registered for another tax
column44: you do not need to submit the Tax Registration  Form.  You  may  submit  the  Affidavit  for  Initial  Tax  Period  indicating  your  existing  City  of  Chicago  account  number.    Please  visit  our  website  at  www.cityofchicago.org to obtain these forms.   When is my payment due?  Amusement Tax must be remitted on or before the 15th day of the month following the month in which the liability was  incurred.   When is my tax return due?  Amusement Tax returns are due on August 15th for the preceding fiscal year of July 1st through June 30th.     How  do  I  apply  for  an  exemption?    Certain  live  cultural  performances  as  well  as  certain  amusements  sponsored  by  religious
column45: charitable
column46: or  educational not-for-profit organizations for fund-raising purposes are exempt (restricted to two events per calendar year not exceeding a total of 14  calendar days.)  If  you think your event is  exempt from  Amusement Tax in accordance with Section 4-156-020B(5)(a) through (g) of the Chicago  Amusement Tax ordinance
column47: you must submit an Amusement Tax Exemption Application at least 30 calendar days prior to the date of the amusement
column48: or 15 calendar days prior to the date that admission tickets to the amusement are first made available for sale
column49: whichever is earlier.  The application  can be found on our website at  www.cityofchicago.org.  For Amusement Tax exemption requests in accordance with 4-156-020B(5)(a)through (f)
column50: the  applicant  must  demonstrate  that  the  proceeds  intended  to  inure  exclusively  to  the  benefit  of  the  exempt  entity  or  entities  are  reasonably  anticipated to equal at least 10 percent of the gross revenues from the amusement.    Have more questions regarding the Amusement Tax or other taxes enforced by the Chicago Department of Finance?  Please contact Customer  Service by phone at 312-747-4747 or via e-mail at revenuedatabase@cityofchicago.org.     "

column1: 11358`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/rev/supp_info/TaxSupportingInformation/AmusementTaxInfoBulletinforSatelliteTV-BusSub33117ext.pdf`Success`Success`1`1`Not a fillable PDF.`                    DEPARTMENT OF FINANCE   INFORMATIONAL BULLETIN   Amusement Tax   for Business Subscribers of Satellite Television     The purpose of this bulletin is to  provide business subscribers of  satellite television with  information regarding their  obligation to remit the Chicago  Amusement Tax.    General Information  The Chicago Amusement Tax  (Amusement Tax)
column2: Chapter   4-156 of the Municipal Code   of Chicago (Code)
column3: applies to   paid television programming
column4: including satellite TV.  The  Federal Communications Act  exempts satellite TV providers  from having to collect local  taxes
column5: but it does not exempt  customers from having to pay  them.    Who is required to pay the  Amusement Tax?  Chicago businesses that  subscribe to and use satellite  TV are required to pay the  Amusement Tax directly to the  Chicago Department of Finance  (Department).  This includes  bars
column6: restaurants
column7: and all other  businesses that subscribe to  satellite TV.    How do I calculate the  Amusement Tax due?  As of the date of this bulletin
column8: the Amusement Tax rate is nine  percent of the charges paid for  satellite TV services used in  Chicago.  Please note
column9: taxable  charges do not include this or  any other tax imposed on these  charges.             When are payments due?  In general
column10: business subscribers  must pay the Amusement Tax  to the Department by the 15th of  each month for the previous  month if their total tax liability  is more than $1
column11: 200 per year. If  total tax liability is less than or  equal to $1
column12: 200 per year
column13: the  Amusement Tax is due only  once per year by August 15th.   See Code Section 3-4-187 for  more details.    When is the tax return due?  The tax return for the fiscal  year
column14: July 1st through June 30th
column15: is filed annually and is due by  August 15th of each year.  See  Code Section 3-4-186 for  details.    How do I register for the tax?    Applications can be found at             www.cityofchicago.org/finance  in the Tax Collection and  Enforcement section of the  webpage.     Voluntary Disclosure –  Special Limited Time Offer  Because many businesses were  previously unaware of their  obligation to pay the  Amusement Tax
column16: the  Department is offering to accept  the payment of Amusement Tax  from July 1
column17: 2015 to the date of  payment
column18: waiving all interest  and penalties
column19: and waiving all  liability for periods before July  1
column20: 2015 (including Amusement          Tax
column21: interest and penalties)
column22: for any business that applies to  the Department by March 31
column23: 2017.      Any business that wishes to  accept this offer should submit  the 2016 Voluntary Disclosure  Application for Business  Subscribers of Satellite  Television Services which is  included with this bulletin.    Why should I participate in  this Voluntary Disclosure  program?  Generally
column24: the statute of  limitations is six years for non- filers.  If a business chooses not  to participate in this program  and the Department later  determines that there is  Amusement Tax liability
column25: the  business may be assessed tax
column26: interest
column27: and penalties for all  periods open under statute.    Additional Questions?  Additional tax information and  forms can be found at  www.cityofchicago.org/finance.     You may also contact us by  email at  revenuedatabase@cityofchicago .org or by phone at (312) 747- 4747.

column2: effective as of the date stated above
column3: the  Chicago amusement tax (Municipal Code
column4: Chapter 4-156 et seq.)
column5: rather than the Chicago  personal property lease transaction tax (Municipal Code
column6: Chapter 3-32 et seq.)
column7: should be  imposed upon charges for the use of telecommunications converters and remote control devices  (whether or not separately stated) in connection with the provision of paid television  programming. Paid television programming specifically includes
column8: but is not limited to
column9: television  programming transmitted by cable. Implementation of this determination should be made within  sixty days. If additional time is needed
column10: you must make a written request to the Department  stating the reasons in support of the request.   If you should have any questions
column11: or require additional information
column12: or if you wish to request  additional time for implementation
column13: you may contact the Department in writing or by telephone  as follows:     City of Chicago  Department of Revenue  Tax Policy Division  333 South State Street

column1: 11646`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/fin/supp_info/AssetLeaseAgreements/MeteredParking/TransactionSummaryandValuationAnalysis.pdf`Success`Success`12`10`Not a fillable PDF.`Background      value for the Concession of the System.  Although these observers
column2: in many cases
column3: make  an  earnest  attempt  to  analyze  the  value  of  the  System
column4: we  believe  that  many  of  their  assertions
column5: assumptions  and  conclusions  are  not  correct.    In  the  following  analysis
column6: we  illustrate the impact of these misconceptions
column7: using as a basis of comparison information  presented  in  the  Report.    As  discussed  below
column8: the  two  most  significant  inaccuracies  contained in the Report are (i) its use of gross System revenue rather than free net cash  flow in estimating System value and (ii) its use of an inappropriately low discount rate in  estimating the value of the System to the City.  Our analysis confirms that by properly  projecting System revenues and by applying a discount rate that appropriately reflects the  relative risks of the System
column9: the conclusion that the City received full and fair value for  the Concession of the System is clearly supported and affirmed.     The  City  of  Chicago  (the  “City”)  has  been  a  leader  among  American  state  and  local  governments  in  successfully  partnering  with  the  private  sector  by  pursuing  and  completing innovative long-term concessions of the Chicago Skyway
column10: the underground  parking  garages  located  in  Grant  and  Millennium  Parks
column11: and  the  Chicago  Metered  Parking  System.    In  total
column12: those  transactions  have  provided  nearly  $3.6  billion  for  Chicago  residents  and  taxpayers.      Many  other  American  cities  now  hope  to  copy  Chicago’s success
column13: particularly in the area of parking.    The  City  has  applied  the  nearly  $3.6  billion  of  proceeds  from  these  transactions  to:  establish long-term reserve funds of more than $1 billion
column14: including $900 million for the  City and $120 million for the Chicago Park District
column15: to replace revenue generated by the  Skyway
column16: parking garages and parking meters; retire $925 million in debt; reserve more  than $700 million for mid-term budget relief in order to maintain essential City services;  and  invest  more  than  $322  million  in  neighborhoods
column17: parks  and  programs  that  serve  people most in need.    Each  of  the  three  successful  transactions  eliminated  long-term  risks  of  increased  operating  and  capital  expenditures
column18: while  mitigating  the  risk  of  future  changes  in  technology and in the behavior of the users of the assets.    After the $1.83 billion Chicago Skyway concession transaction closed
column19: and the long-term  reserve was established
column20: all three bond rating agencies upgraded the City's credit rating.   Today
column21: the City enjoys its highest credit ratings since 1978.     The $563 million concession of the downtown parking garage system helped to pay off  all of the debt used to build Chicago's world-class Millennium Park
column22: and allowed for a  shift  of  capital  resources  from  downtown  parking  garages  to  neighborhood  parks  throughout the city by investing $122 million in neighborhood park infrastructure.     The City’s announced policy is to pursue long-term public-private partnerships involving  infrastructure assets only when:        2  •  There is substantial potential financial benefit to the Chicago tax payers   and residents;   •  The  assets  involved  do  not  involve  the  core  competencies  of  City   government; and    •  Experienced  and  professional  operators  are  able  to  improve  efficiency
column23: quality of service and make enhanced capital investments in the assets.     City  policy  and  concession  agreements  further  require  that  private  operators  treat  employees  fairly
column24: provide  a  high  level  of  safety  and  security
column25: and  satisfy  strong  performance
column26: operating and engineering standards.  Throughout each transaction
column27: the City  has provided great transparency in the robust competitive bidding process and through  the planning of the use of concession proceeds.        How the City Estimated the Value of the System  and Determined the Minimum Acceptable Bid     The City and Blair worked together over a period of months to estimate the value of the  System to infrastructure investors
column28: estimate the potential value of the System to the City  and  identify  the  minimum  bid  amount  that  the  City  would  accept  for  a  75-year  Concession.  Before  proceeding  with  the  transaction
column29: the  City  wanted  reasonable  assurance
column30: using widely-accepted financial valuation methods applicable to infrastructure  assets
column31: and  incorporating  various  assumptions  concerning  rates
column32: utilization
column33: risk  allocation
column34: discount rate and other factors affecting valuation
column35: that a long-term concession  of the System would produce an upfront payment that would be both sufficient to replace  the revenues currently produced by the System and to produce a substantial premium that  would fairly compensate the City for a 75-year concession.      Infrastructure Investor Valuation Approach  Blair  used  a  multi-variable  discounted  cash  flow  analysis  to  estimate  the  value  of  the  System to infrastructure investors.  The value of the metered parking system is primarily  a function of two factors:        •  The  long-term  free  cash  flow  of  the  System  ---  estimated  operating  revenue  (which  makes  assumptions  about  driver  utilization)
column36: minus  operating  expenses
column37: minus  capital  expenditures  and  corporate  tax  liabilities; and   •  The  bidder’s  cost  and  mix  of  debt  and  equity  financing  or  cost  of   capital.   In  estimating  the  value  of  the  proposed  long-term  concession  of  the  System
column38: Blair  prepared and continued to refine its multi-variable analysis using a variety of assumptions  for the factors that impact long-term free cash flow and the bidder’s cost of capital.  Blair  began  by  identifying  all  the  factors  that  impact  either  long-term  free  cash  flow  or  the      3  bidder’s cost of capital.  Next
column39: Blair constructed a range of potential values for each of  those factors and assigned each potential value with a probability of occurrence.  As such
column40: the probabilities for all the potential values of a factor add up to 100%.  A scenario was  calculated for every possible combination of those factors
column41: which produced thousands of  outcomes
column42: each  with  a  very  small  probability  of  occurrence  based  on  the  individual  probabilities of the factors.  The analysis produced a standard distribution of outcomes
column43: similar to a “bell curve” of grades in a college class.  Based on this bell curve
column44: Blair was  able to predict a range of values based on confidence intervals.       Using the valuation method described above
column45: Blair initially established a valuation range  for  the  Concession  of  between  $650  million  and  $1.2  billion.    While  this  range  was  refined during the bidding process
column46: the top end of the range never exceeded $1.2 billion.       City Held System Valuation Approach     The estimated value of the System in the City’s hands is much more hypothetical.  As  such
column47: there are several ways to approach the value of the System had the City not entered  into the Concession.    Approach 1 – Current Practices    In 2005
column48: the City increased the rate on meters located in the Loop from $1.50 to $3.00 per  hour.  This marked the first time in many years that the City increased meter rates on  such  a  widespread  basis.    This  increase  affected  approximately  1
column49: 000  spaces  and  represented  only  3%  of  the  System.    More  importantly
column50: the  $0.25  hourly  rate  for  approximately 75% of the System had not been increased in over 20 years.  Exhibit 1  (attached) estimates the value of the System assuming continued operation by the City  and annual rate increases of 3.0%.  This assumption is probably aggressive given the fact  that the rates on 75% City meters had not increased in over 20 years.  During that 20-year  period
column51: the rate of inflation average approximately 3.2% per year.     Using  this  valuation  method  and  a  discount  rate  ranging  from  10.00%  to  14.00%
column52: the  estimated  value  of  the  System  would  be  between  $177  million  and  $276  million  (see  Exhibit 1).      Approach 2 – Concession Practices    The  City  faced  two  significant  challenges  to  increasing  parking  meter  rates.    First
column53: as  discussed above
column54: the rates on most meters in the System had not been increased in many  years  and  there  was  a  general  lack  of  uniformity  as  to  rates  and  hours  of  operation.   Second
column55: there was also the challenge of acquiring the expensive “pay and display” meter  technology that would be needed to support higher meter rates.  The estimated total cost  (equipment and labor) for upgrading the City’s meter technology is approximately $50  million.    Given  the  other  higher  priority  demands  on  the  City’s  limited  capital  improvement funds
column56: it seemed unlikely that adequate funding would be available from      4  City  capital  dollars  to  pay  for  the  prompt  acquisition  and  installation  of  new  meter  technology.      This valuation approach ignores these two challenges and the risks associated with each  and assumes that the City increased rates in the same manner as under the Concession  transaction.  Although many factors impact the value of the System to the City
column57: the two  that have the largest impact are the reaction of parkers to rate increases during the initial  five years of rate increases and the City’s discount rate.    Starting  in  year  six  of  the  pricing  structure
column58: rates  increase  to  keep  pace  with  inflation.   Because beginning in year six rates do not increase on a real basis
column59: there is no reason to  expect that utilization will be impacted solely by parking meter rates.  However
column60: during  the first five years rates do increase substantially
column61: in some cases going from $0.25 per  hour to $2.00 per hour.  The impact on utilization due to price increases is the elasticity  of  demand
column62: defined  as  the  percentage  impact  on  demand  when  price  changes  by  1%.   Obviously
column63: as  discussed  below
column64: utilization  may  be  adversely  impacted  by  a  variety  of  other factors
column65: and the City has shifted all of these utilization risks to the concessionaire.    The Inspector General’s Report analyzes five separate revenue scenarios
column66: which are each  produced by differing assumptions regarding the elasticity of demand for street parking.   The analysis that Blair prepared for the City analyzed the impact that all relevant factors  had on value
column67: not just demand elasticity.  However
column68: given that this is the only factor that  the Report used and to keep things simple
column69: Exhibit 2 (attached) uses those scenarios and  produces a value for each:     (cid:131)  Scenario 1 - Year five revenue is $85 million – The estimated value of the  System is $515 million to $850 million
column70: assuming a discount rate of 10.0%  to  14.0%  (see  discussion  below  concerning  the  calculation  of  discount  rates).     (cid:131)  Scenario 2 - Year five revenue is $100 million – The estimated value of  the System is $625 million to $1.024 billion
column71: assuming a discount rate of  10.0% to 14.0%.                  (cid:131)  Scenario 3 - Year five revenue is $107.5 million – The estimated value of  the System is $678 million to $1.111 billion
column72: assuming a discount rate of  10.0% to 14.0%.   (cid:131)  Scenario 4 - Year five revenue is $115 million – The estimated value of  the System is $732 million to $1.198 billion
column73: assuming a discount rate of  10.0% to 14.0%.   (cid:131)  Scenario 5 - Year five revenue is $130 million – The estimated value of  the System is $839 million to $1.372 billion
column74: assuming a discount rate of  10.0% to 14.0%.   5  Assuming  that  the  City  could  raise  rates  in  the  same  manner  as  under  the  Concession  transaction
column75: and  had  adequate  capital  dollars  available  to  fund  meter  technology  upgrades
column76: the City established its minimum acceptable bid of $1 billion at the high-end of  the  estimated  System  value.    This  target  is  affirmed  as  reasonable  and  fair  given  the  revenue assumptions that we utilized.  As it turned out
column77: the winning bid was at the very  top range of the estimated value to the City based on this method.      Analysis of the Inspector General’s Report     While the Report represents an earnest attempt to analyze and critique the Concession
column78: we  believe  that  many  of  the  assertions
column79: assumptions  and  conclusions  contained  in  the  Report  are  not  correct.    It  appears  that  the  Report  reflects  a  number  of  conclusory  statements
column80: the merits of which are impossible to determine since they are made without  citing  any  authoritative  sources  or  precedent.    Rather  than  attempt  a  point-by-point  rebuttal
column81: the  following  discussion  focuses  on  the  two  main  major  issues  raised  in  the  Report that deal with System value to the City.    Revenue vs. Free Cash Flow    The Report assumes $500
column82: 000 in annual capital expenditures for the System beginning in  year three.  Upon conversion to cashless payment meter technology
column83: the System will be  comprised of approximately 4
column84: 000 meters with an average acquisition cost of $11
column85: 250 per  meter.    Meters  of  this  nature  typically  last  seven  to  ten  years  before  they  need  to  be  replaced.  Assuming the meters are replaced every 10 years
column86: annual capital expenditures  would actually equal $4
column90: 250 / 10 years).  This figure represents only  true capital costs and does not reflect any increases to operating expenses associated with  repair  and  maintenance  of  technologically  advanced  machinery  that  is  exposed  to  the  elements.  Further
column91: it completely ignores any other capital expenditures throughout the  System.  It appears that the Report understates the cost of System capital expenditures  by $4 million every year
column92: thus overstating the amount of System free cash flow in each  year.    The Report states that “Free Cash Flow” in year five in each of the five scenarios was  $85 million to $130 million.  The Report’s analysis then applies a discount rate to these  sums to determine value.  The Report’s analysis confuses the concept of free cash flow  with revenue
column93: thus completely ignoring significant operating costs of at least $5 million  per year.  It appears that the Report understates the cost of operating the System by $5  million every year
column94: thus overstating System free cash flow in each year.    These two mistakes combine to overstate annual free cash flow by $9 million per year.   Exhibit 3 (attached) demonstrates the impact that these mistakes have on the value of the  System for each of the Report’s revenue scenarios.          6  of 10% to 14% for its valuation analysis.  The following is the logic behind the City’s  approach.      Definition  -  Discount  rate  is  defined  by  Investopedia.com  as  “the  interest  rate  used  in  determining  the  present  value  of  future  cash  flow”.    Simply  put
column95: it  is  the  rate  used  to  convert the value of dollars in the future into the value of dollars today.  For any given  valuation  analysis
column96: the  applicable  discount  rate  equals  the  “risk-free  rate”  plus  a  “risk  premium.”  Although the risk-free rate is a hypothetical rate
column97: it is generally accepted by  financial analysts to equal the rate of a United States Treasury bond with a maturity equal  to the related cash flow stream.  The risk premium is specific to the risks attributable to  the specific investment being valued and is defined by Investopedia.com as “a form of  compensation for investors who tolerate the extra risk - compared to that of a risk-free  asset  - in  a  given  investment”.    For  example
column98: the  risk  premium  for  an  internet  start-up  company is higher than that associated with a well-established company like Microsoft
column99: given the greater risks related to a start-up business.      Risk-free rate - The current yield on a 30-year Treasury bond (i.e. the 30-year risk-free  rate) is approximately 4.591%.  Obviously
column100: the term of the concession is 75 years
column101: which  would suggest an even higher risk free rate.    Risk premium – The fact that City has shifted 75 years worth of considerable risk to the  concessionaire can not be ignored.  Infrastructure investors demand a higher return than  investors in bonds and stocks
column102: which means that the risk premium for infrastructure assets  is  higher.    Typically
column103: a  diversified  stock  portfolio  has  a  risk-premium  of  3%  to  5%.   Depending upon the industry
column104: A-rated corporate bonds currently have a risk-premium of  3% to 5%. As a stand alone revenue source
column105: the System would achieve a credit rating of   BBB+ at best (compared with the City’s “AA” credit rating)
column106: requiring a higher premium  to compensate for the risks described below.    Conclusion  -  Even  risk-free  investments  (if  there  were  such  a  thing)  would  be  valued  using a discount rate of at least 4.5%.  The appropriate risk premium should be higher  than either a diversified stock portfolio or an A-rated corporate bond.  Accordingly
column107: a risk  premium range of 5.5% to 9.5% would be more appropriate.  Based on a risk-free rate of  4.5%
column108: this results in a discount rate range of 10.0% to 14.0%.    Alternative – One way to provide a reality check to the City’s discount rate of 10.0% to  14.0% is to ask the following hypothetical question: If the City issued $1 billion of bonds  secured  only  by  the  net  operating  revenue  of  the  System  (i.e.  no  general  obligation  backing by the City)
column109: what interest rate would they pay on those bonds?  Those bonds
column110: if  they could be sold at all
column111: would surely sell at double-digit yields.    Another  way  to  look  at  this  would  be  the  appropriate  discount  rate  the  City  would  be  advised to use if it were bidding on a similar system in another city -- Los Angeles
column112: for                                                     1 The weighted average of System cash flows is greater than 30 years.  4.59% does not reflect this fact to  simplify the analysis.      8     example.  Again
column114: Blair would advise the City to use a discount  rate of 10.0% to 14.0% given the risk.      More on Risk Transfer   The characterization of the System as a “very low risk” project is simply inaccurate and  without basis.  There are substantial risks associated with the operation and value of the  System  that  have  been  transferred  by  the  City  to  the  concessionaire.    The  concession  agreement requires the concessionaire to operate the System for 75 years
column119: and  the  myriad other factors that might affect the economic value of the System.  There was no  such thing as a parking meter 75 years ago—the first ones were installed in 1935. And if  you  go  fifty  years  farther  back  than  1935
column120: there  were  no  vehicles  powered  by  internal  combustion engines.  A lot can and will change in 75 years.  Chicago has experienced  meaningful  fluctuations  in  population  during  the  last  75  years.  There  is  substantial  uncertainty associated with the future availability and cost of motor fuel
column123: and  so  on.  Just  as  the  application of improved meter technology may enhance the value of the System
column124: it is also  true that technological innovations may adversely impact the value of the System.  For  example
column125: it may be that individual motor vehicles are replaced by other forms of personal  transportation that do not require as much or even any street parking.  The concessionaire  has  assumed  all  of  the  risks  associated  with  declines  in  System  utilization
column126: including  declines  related  to  rate  increases  and  those  driven  by  technology
column128: attractive  transportation alternatives and other factors.  All substantial risks have been transferred to  the  concessionaire
column129: many  of  which  may  adversely  affect  the  long-term  value  of  the  System.  Had the City continued operation of the System
column130: it would retain these risks and  therefore need to attribute a significant risk premium itself that should be reflected in the  discount rate used in valuing the future cash flows from the System – even for the City.    While there is no purely mathematical way to assess these risks
column131: it seems arbitrary and  inappropriate to characterize this concession a “very low-risk” endeavor over its 75-year  life.  As  discussed  above
column132: the  appropriate  discount  rate  should  reflect  a  substantial  risk  premium
column133: whether or not the System is subject to the concession.    Conclusion  For the reasons discussed above
column134: we believe that the System is much more valuable to the  City under the Concession.  The incremental value resulting to the City from completing  the Concession can be expressed in two ways:          (cid:131)   If the estimated value of the System operated by the City is between $177 to $276  million (see discussion above)
column135: the incremental value to the City resulting from  the concession is $880 million to $979 million     (cid:131)  The  City  deposited  $400  million  in  a  revenue  replacement  fund  to  generate  earnings  to  replace  he  net  revenues  it  previously  received  from  the  System  (increased by inflation each year)
column136: resulting in an incremental value to the City of      9  $756 million.  The City will also benefit from a risk transfer
column137: as the investment  returns  on  the  revenue  replacement  fund  will  be  less  volatile  and  more  certain  than the cash flow produced by the System     Assuming that the City continued to operate the System
column138: could implement the same rate  increases  and  expanded  days  and  hours  of  operation  included  in  the  Concession  and  could obtain adequate capital dollars to make required improvements in meter technology  needed to support the higher meter rates
column139: the winning bid of $1.156 billion is at the high- end of the “best case” estimated range of value of the System
column141: utilizing even the  lowest appropriate discount rate of 10.0%
column142: the estimated value of the System if operated  by the City is $845 million to $1.3 billion.    The winning bid $1.156 billion represented a very aggressive bid
column143: reflecting the robust  competitive  bidding  process
column144: the  trophy  nature  of  the  asset  and  the  limited  number  of  American  public  infrastructure  investment  opportunities.    The  winning  bid  was  at  the  high-end of the estimated range of value of the System to a private infrastructure investor  and to the City under continued City operation.          10

column62: 2017  New in 2017:  The dental and vision plans are no longer bundled with the HMO or PPO medical insurance coverage.  You can purchase medical or vision or dental coverage separately.  No action is needed if you want to continue your same  dental or vision coverage for 2017.  If you want to cancel your dental or vision or medical coverage during open enrollment
column63: go online at www.cityofchicagoben- efits.org or call the Benefits Service Center at 1-877-299-5111.  If you  do  not  currently  have  medical  coverage
column64: you  can  enroll in  the vision  insurance  separately.   You can also  enroll in the  dental insurance separately if you have qualified for this benefit (see page 16 ).  You must provide documents to verify the  dependents you enroll (see page 5).  Open enrollment is the time of year when you can:  ü Cancel your medical
column65: or vision
column66: or dental insurance ü Switch medical or dental plans ü Add dependents to your plan (for example a spouse
column67: civil union or same sex domestic  partner
column68: or children)  ü Drop dependents from your plan ü Enroll or re-enroll in a health care or dependent care Flexible Spending Account (FSA) ü Buy optional life insurance or voluntary long term disability insurance  To make changes
column69: go to the City of Chicago Benefits Services Center website:  www.cityofchicagobenefits.org  To enroll online you must use your eight digit employee number. Find your employee number in the upper left of your  paystub and simply add zeroes to the front to make it eight numbers.  Follow the prompts on the website if you forgot your  username or password.  Open enrollment changes can also be made over the phone by calling:  Benefits Service Center 1-877-299-5111 Monday through Friday 8:00 a.m. until 5:00 p.m.  Enrollment in a healthcare Flexible Spending Account (FSA) does not carry over from year to year.  You must re-enroll in an FSA if you want this benefit for 2017.    Enroll online at www.cityofchicagobenefits.org or call the Benefits Service Center.   Plan A effective 1/1/2017. The Plan Document and subsequent updates always supersede this summary.PPO MONEY SAVINGS  Save by using tax-free money to pay for out-of-pocket costs: Enroll in a Healthcare Flexible Spending Account  (FSA) and reduce your income tax.  Save by using doctors and hospitals in the PPO Tier 1 network: The PPO gives you freedom to choose from  three different network tiers. You can select doctors and hospitals (providers) from Tier 1 for some of your care
column77: and use Tier 2 or  Tier 3 providers for other services. You pay the lowest deductible and coinsurance when you use providers in  Tier 1. To find a Tier 1 provider call 1-800-772-6895 or go to www.bcbsil.com/cityofchicago.  Two ways to save on prescription medications:  1) Choose generic medications and pay the lowest copay. 2) Use  mail order for long term “maintenance” medications. You will pay more if you don’t use mail order for long term medications  after the 3rd fill.  Save on lab tests – use a free-standing lab: Get your lab tests paid in full by using a free-standing lab (such as a Quest  lab) which is not affiliated with a hospital. Even if your doctor already has an arrangement with Quest
column78: ask for a lab order for tests  to be done at a Quest facility. Take this paperwork to the Quest lab and test results will be sent directly to your doctor.  Call 1-866- 697-8378 to find the location of a Quest lab near you
column79: or go to www.Questdiagnostics.com.  Save on scans – use a free-standing imaging center: Scans are covered in full if done at a fee-standing imaging center. When  your doctor orders an MRI
column80: CT
column82: call Telligen at 1-800-373-3727 to pre-certify the test and locate a free-standing  imaging center near you.   Become pregnant?  Earn a $100 incentive:  Enroll in a free
column83: confidential maternity management program designed  to encourage a healthy baby by providing telephone support for moms-to-be. To qualify for the $100 incentive
column84: call Telligen (1- 800-373-3727) to enroll and complete at least eight doctors’ visits during the pregnancy. column1: 19815`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/rev/supp_info/NonCommercial/NonCommercialLoadingZonePermit_App.pdf`Success`Success`2`2`Not a fillable PDF.`City of Chicago   NON-COMMERCIAL LOADING ZONE PERMIT      The current Non-Commercial Loading Zone Permit will expire July 7th.        The Non-Commercial Loading Zone permit was established to assist businesses making deliveries  and fast service calls throughout Chicago’s commercial districts.  The loading zone permit is issued  to the owner or lessee of a passenger vehicle normally used to transport property in the furtherance  of  a  commercial  or  industrial  enterprise.    A  loading  zone  permit  is  not  required  for  trucks
column2: commercial vehicles or vehicles registered with the Illinois Commerce Commission.   A completed application along with the permit fee should be submitted to:      City of Chicago   121 N. LaSalle Street
column3: Room 107   Chicago
column4: IL 60602   Attention: Non-Commercial Loading Zones   Make checks payable to: City of Chicago      Please  note:  Effective  July
column5: 2001  the  non-commercial  loading  zone  permit  can  be  renewed  semi-annually or annually.  The permits are valid July 8th – January 7th and January 8th –  July  7th  of  each  year.    You  can  purchase  a  semi-annual  permit  for  $125.00  or  an  annual  permit for $250.00.      All vehicle license plates will be reviewed for outstanding parking tickets.  All parking tickets must  be paid or a hearing scheduled.  If you have any questions regarding outstanding parking tickets
column6: please call (312) 744-PARK.   If you have any questions regarding the non-commercial loading zone permit program
column7: you may  contact a customer service representative at (312) 747-0110.            City of Chicago   NON-COMMERCIAL LOADING ZONE PERMIT APPLICATION      Applicant Name:   Applicant Address:   (City/State/Zip)   Company Name:   Company Address:   (City/State/Zip)   Contact Name:   Nature of Business:                              Type of Property Transported:      License Plate #:      Date:  Contact Phone:                       State of Registration:  Expiration Date:     Each vehicle must have a permit affixed to the windshield of the vehicle while standing in a loading zone.   Semi-Annual Permit Valid January 8th-July 7th OR July 8th-January 7th……………………………  Annual Permit Valid January 8th- January 7th………………………………………………………….   $125 $250  Make checks payable to City of Chicago               ____________________________________  Signature    *************************************************************************************  For Office Use Only:  FINANCE (27) 027-Non-Commercial Loading Zone Permit  Cashier To Capture:  License Plate Number (in “Receipt” field)  Applicant Name (in “Customer Name” field)     Applicant Address (in “Address” fields)  Company Name (in “Comment” field)   ________________________  Date   POS Invoice                 Date Issued:  Semi-annual Permit #            Permit Fee:  Annual Permit #         Check #:  Processed by:

The details of the exemption
column4: effective  January 1
column6: are available on the City’s web site at www.cityofchicago.org.  According to  our records
column7: the property identified above received an exemption from water and sewer service  charges during 2012
column8: and may be eligible for an exemption during 2013.         To determine whether your property is still eligible in 2013 for an exemption from  water and sewer service charges under the City’s new eligibility criteria

column11: and certify  that your property is eligible for an exemption.     Enclosed

column1: 19877`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/rev/supp_info/WaterDivision/NFPWaterConservationPlan12-13-13.pdf`Success`Success`1`1`Not a fillable PDF.`   Water Conservation Plan Requirement     Eligibility for the Not-for Profit Exemption requires that you have a Water Conservation Plan on file with the  City of Chicago.  This requirement is met by filing your plan with the Department of Water Management.     For the purpose of this first application
column2: you need only file the statement below by faxing to: 312-744-3719 or  by emailing to waterconservationplan@cityofchicago.org      You are committing to formulate a plan specific and appropriate to your properties.     Development of this plan should include a thoughtful audit of your water systems in any facility owned and/or  operated by the applying entity.  This will include checking for leaks and looking for conservation opportunities  such as low flow fixtures and staff training.    The City of Chicago is working with numerous organizations
column3: including the Interfaith Coalition
column4: to provide  work pages
column5: resources
column6: and experts to guide and assist you.  There will be a series of trainings for your  volunteers.    Your plan should also include any appropriate opportunities to assist members
column7: clients
column8: or neighbors in gaining  an understanding of conservation and Green design strategies that will benefit them and serve the larger  community by conserving potable water and managing storm water.      I
column9: ________________________ plan to develop an Action Agenda for water conservation that includes:     1.  A self-conducted audit of our premises and staff practices  2.  Submitting a list of identified conservation options  3.  A schedule for implementation that is realistic
column10: given costs and logistics  4.  A commitment to work with the City of Chicago to help teach members and/or clients about the benefits   and options for water conservation and storm water management. 20512`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/rev/supp_info/enEspanol/SpanishPayOnline.pdf`Success`Success`1`1`Not a fillable PDF.`  DENTRO  DE  LOS  7  DÍAS  POSTERIORES  DE  HABER  RECIBIDO  ESTE  AVISO  DE  INFRACCIÓN
column2: USTED  DEBE  PAGAR  LA  MULTA  CORRESPONDIENTE O BIEN
column3: OBJETAR EL AVISO.   (Ya sea por correo o personalmente
column4: pero no de ambas maneras)   PARA PAGAR POR INTERNET: visítenos en aqui.  PARA PAGAR POR CORREO: adjunte un cheque o giro a la orden de City of  Chicago  en  este  sobre  y  marque  el  casillero  que  dice  “pago  adjunto”  en  el  presente aviso de infracción. Remítase al dorso para ver la multa aplicable. NO  ENVÍE DINERO EN EFECTIVO.  PARA  PAGAR  PERSONALMENTE:  lleve  este  sobre  a  cualquiera  de  los  centros incluidos en la lista.   Según  la  ordenanza
column5: se  admiten  los  siguientes  fundamentos  para  objetar  una  infracción:   1. el demandado no era el propietario ni el arrendatario del citado vehículo en   el momento de producirse la infracción;   2. el vehículo mencionado o sus placas patente de registro estatal habían sido   robados cuando tuvo lugar la infracción;   3. faltaban los carteles correspondientes que indicaban que se trataba de un   área de estacionamiento prohibido o restringido
column6: o no eran claros;   4.  el  parquímetro  relevante  no  funcionaba  o  funcionaba  mal
column7: sin  que  el   demandado tuviera la culpa de ello;   5. los hechos que se alegan en el aviso de infracción por mal estacionamiento  o incumplimiento son inconsistentes o no se refieren a un hecho que viole  la norma específica (por ejemplo
column8: Artículos 9-64-125 y 9-76-170: cuando  se  produjo  la  infracción
column9: la  persona  llevaba  menos  de  treinta  (30)  días  como residente de la Ciudad
column10: o no habían transcurrido al  menos treinta  (30)  días  desde  la  compra  del  citado  vehículo;  Artículo  9-76-220:  el  vehículo cumple con los requisitos para uso médico
column11: según se dispone en  el Capítulo 625 de la sección de Transporte de los Estatutos Compilados  de Illinois [ILCS
column12: Illinois Compiled Statutes] Art. 5/12 - 503(g)
column13: etc.);   6.  la  condición  ilegal  que  se  describe  en  el  aviso  de  infracción  por   incumplimiento no existía en el momento en que se emitió dicho aviso;   7. la infracción por incumplimiento se había corregido antes de la audiencia;  siempre y cuando
column14: no obstante ello
column15: que esta defensa no se aplicará a los  Artículos 9-64-125; 9-76-140(a); 9-76-160 (a)
column16: (f); y 9-76-220.   Si su vehículo estaba en poder de un asistente de estacionamiento en la fecha y  hora que se produjo la infracción
column17: usted tiene sesenta (60) días para presentar  una copia clara y legible del recibo de estacionamiento asistido
column18: de conformidad  con el Art. 4-232-080(d).  PARA  OBJETAR  POR  CORREO:  marque  el  casillero  que  dice  “objetar  por  correo” y complete con su nombre y domicilio. Utilice el sobre para enviar una  declaración  firmada  en  la  que  se  describan  los  hechos  que  establecen  una  defensa. La declaración debe estar firmada por el propietario registrado. Adjunte        COPIAS de todos y cada uno de los documentos (por ejemplo
column19: fotografías
column20: denuncia policial o el registro de su automóvil) necesarios para demostrar que  usted no es responsable. INCLUYA EL NÚMERO DE BOLETA DE DIEZ  DÍGITOS EN TODOS LOS DOCUMENTOS DE RESPALDO. El número de  boleta de diez dígitos es la serie contigua de números impresos en el extremo  superior izquierdo de este aviso de infracción. Dicho número incluye todos los  ceros de adelante. NO ENVÍE DOCUMENTOS ORIGINALES PORQUE NO  LE SERÁN DEVUELTOS. Le enviarán por correo la decisión de la audiencia.  PARA OBJETAR EN PERSONA: en presencia de un oficial de audiencias
column21: marque el casillero que dice “pedido de audiencia en persona”
column22: complete con su  nombre
column23: dirección y número de teléfono para llamarlo de día y envíe este sobre  por correo. Le notificarán las opciones de fechas y horarios para la audiencia por  correo. Todas las notificaciones le serán remitidas por correo al domicilio del  propietario registrado
column24: según consta en la Secretaría de Estado.  SI USTED NO RESPONDE ESTE AVISO DE INFRACCIÓN
column25: PUEDE  DICTARSE UNA DECISIÓN DE RESPONSABILIDAD EN SU CONTRA. Si  no se paga la multa dentro de los 21 días posteriores a la decisión de  responsabilidad
column26: es probable que se sume una penalidad por pago en mora
column27: cuyo  importe puede ser equivalente al de la multa. La decisión se considerará  definitiva a los efectos de la revisión administrativa y judicial. Si usted acumula  3 ó más decisiones definitivas de responsabilidad por mal  estacionamiento/incumplimiento
column28: cualquier vehículo que sea de su propiedad  puede ser secuestrado y confiscado hasta que haya pagado todas las multas.  Después de 10 decisiones definitivas de responsabilidad por mal  estacionamiento
column29: la Ciudad enviará la certificación a la Secretaría de  Estado
column30: indicando que usted puede ser elegible para que le suspendan la  licencia de conductor. Una decisión definitiva puede ejecutarse de la misma  manera que una sentencia dictada por un tribunal competente. Las decisiones  definitivas quedan sujetas a cobranza por medio de agencias de cobranza y por  acción de la oficina de crédito
column31: y la imposición de gravámenes sobre bienes  raíces y personales. La emisión o renovación de cualquier licencia otorgada por  la Ciudad —lo cual incluye licencias comerciales y como chofer particular—  pueden quedar suspendidas por no pagar las boletas que se encuentren en estado  de decisión definitiva. Todo gasto en el que la Ciudad hubiera incurrido para  ejecutar la decisión
column32: incluidos
column33: entre otras cosas
column34: los honorarios de los abogados  y las costas judiciales
column35: serán deudas pendientes con la Ciudad. Recuerde: su  derecho a audiencia vencerá por ley. Si desea objetar esta boleta
column36: asegúrese de  enviar el pedido por correo en los plazos pertinentes. Los pedidos de audiencia  en persona también se aceptan por teléfono.

column1: 20513`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/rev/supp_info/enEspanol/30094_45_SpanishTruck031009.pdf`Success`Success`2`2`Not a fillable PDF.`Permisos comerciales para  camiones: De acuerdo con la naturaleza de su negocio
column2: tal  vez sea necesario que usted obtenga un permiso  comercial  para  llevar  a  cabo  sus  actividades  comerciales  en  Chicago.  Para  saber  si  se  requi- ere  dicho  permiso
column3: póngase  en  contacto  con  el  Departamento de Asuntos Comerciales y Permisos  al 312-74G-OBIZ.   He aquí algunos consejos: •		Se requiere un permiso (Junk Peddler License)  para  recolectar
column4: transportar  o  deshacerse  de  chatarra.  •		Se  requiere  un  permiso  (Scavenger  License)  para  el  servicio  particular  de  recolección  de  basura. La inspección anual de estos camiones
column5: realizada  por  el  Departamento  de  Limpia  Pública
column6: es obligatoria.   •		Se requiere un permiso (Mobile Food License)  para  vender  comida  directamente  desde  un  vehículo. Todos los alimentos deben ser previa- mente preparados y empaquetados. En algunos  distritos  de  Chicago  se  prohíben  los  camiones  que	venden	comida	(‘loncheras’).  Secretario de Estado—Placas B: El  Secretario  de  Estado  de  Illinois  requiere  que  algunos  camiones  exhiban  placas  de  circulación  tipo B. Para más información al respecto
column7: consulte  www.cyberdriveillinois.com.  Permisos para camiones con  sobrepeso o tamaño excesivo: Se  pueden  requerir  permisos  especiales  para  vehículos  que  sobrepasan  los  límites  estableci- dos  de  peso  y  tamaño.  Para  informarse  sobre  este particular
column8: llame a la Oficina de Manejo de  Emergencias y Comunicaciones al 312-744-4652.  Altura de puentes y pasos a  desnivel:  Se  proporciona  información  sobre  la  altura  de  puentes  y  pasos  a  desnivel  tanto  en  la  señal- ización  vial  como  en  el  sitio  de  web  municipal   (www.cityofchicago.org/transportation)  y  el  Departamento  de  Transporte  de  Chicago  (312- 744-3520).  Restricciones aplicables a bulevares:  Los  vehículos  comerciales  (los  diseñados  y  uti- lizados  para  llevar  carga  u  otras  mercancías  o  artículos con fines comerciales) no podrán circular  en  los  bulevares.  Sin  embargo
column9: cuando  resulta  imposible entregar o recibir mercancías llegando  por una calle lateral o callejón
column10: se permite recor- rer un bulevar desde el cruce más cercano al edi- ficio en cuestión. Para mayores informes llame al  Depto. de Transporte al 312-744-3600. (Código  Municipal
column11: sección 9-72-020). column14: pero  sólo  mientras  dicho  vehículo  hace  entregas  o  provee  servicios  a  clientes  (p.ej.
column15: contratistas
column16: electricistas
column17: plomeros
column18: entrega de  muebles u otros artículos
column19: etc.)
column20: o sólo durante  las  operaciones  oportunas  de  carga  o  descar- ga.  •		Los  vehículos  estacionados  en  calles  mientras  no proveen servicios a clientes
column21: están sujetos a  ser inmovilizados.  ¿Puede estacionarse un camión   comercial en una calle residencial?   Sí
column22: pero sólo mientras dicho camión (sin importar  su peso) está haciendo entregas o prestando ser- vicios  a  clientes  (p.ej.
column23: contratistas
column24: electricistas
column25: plomeros
column26: entrega  de  muebles  u  otros  artículos
column27: etc.)
column28: o sólo durante las operaciones oportunas de  carga o descarga.  O:  Cuando se exhibe el permiso de camión residen- cial en el vehículo y éste está estacionado cerca  del domicilio de su dueño. Esta excepción es apli- cable sólo en determinados distritos (wards).  ¿Qué consecuencias trae el  estacionamiento de vehículos comerciales en zonas prohibidas? El  vehículo  puede  ser  inmovilizado  inmediata- mente
column29: con  multas  de  $60  por  la  inmovilización  y  $125  por  infracción  de  tránsito.  Para  los  camiones con peso superior a 4
column30: 500 libras
column31: estas  multas  suben  a  $400  y  $125
column32: respectivamente.  Los  vehículos  inmovilizados  pueden  ser  remol- cados
column33: con  multas  adicionales  por  remolque  y  almacenaje.  ¿En qué circunstancias puede ser  inmovilizado un vehículo comercial? •		Cuando está estacionado en una calle y no está   proveyendo servicios.  •		Cuando está estacionado en una calle residen- cial  en  un  distrito  que  no  permite  el  estacio- namiento  de  camiones  y  no  está  proveyendo  servicios.  •		Cuando está estacionado en una calle residencial  en un distrito que sí permite el estacionamiento  de camiones pero no exhibe el permiso corre- spondiente y no está proveyendo servicios.  •		Todo vehículo registrado en su nombre puede  ser  inmovilizado  (booted)  si  usted  acumula  3  o más multas en estado de determinación final  (final determination status) o 2 multas en estado  de  determinación  final  de  más  de  un  año.  Se  ofrecen  facilidades  de  pago  de  multas  para  evitar  la  inmovilización  del  vehículo  afectado  en  esta  forma.  Llame  al  312-744-PARK  para  mayores informes.  ¿Para qué sirve el Permiso para  Camión Residencial? •			Este  permiso  hace  posible  que  los  camiones  con peso inferior a 4
column34: 500 libras se estacionen  en  zonas  residenciales  cerca  del  domicilio  de  su dueño
column35: pero únicamente en aquellos distritos  que  permiten  estacionamiento  de  camiones  comerciales.  La participación de los distritos está sujeta a cambio.  Favor de comunicarse con la oficina del City Clerk  para conocer la información más actualizada 312- 744-1528.  ¿Qué se requiere para obtener el  permiso para camión residencial? •		El vehículo debe pesar menos de 4
column36: 500 libras;  •		El vehículo no puede tener infracciones de esta-  cionamiento pendientes en Chicago;  •		Se debe demostrar que el vehículo cuenta con   la calcomanía de impuestos municipio.  ¿Dónde puedo solicitar el permiso  para camión residencial? S e   o f r e c e n   s i n   c o s t o   a l g u n o   p e r m i s o s  para  camiones  de  las  oficinas  de  concejales   ( a l d e r m e n )  e n   d i s t r i t o s   q u e   p e r m i t e n   e l   e s t a c i o n a m i e n t o   d e   c a m i o n e s .   L l a m e  a l  3 1 2 - 7 4 4 - 1 5 2 8  p a r a   a v e r- i g u a r  c u á l e s   s o n  l o s   d i s t r i t o s   p a r t i c i- pantes  o  visite www.chicityclerk.com.  Información adicional  Tamaño y peso de los camiones  Los  camiones  que  circulan  en  Chicago  deben   cumplir  con  los  requisitos  de  tamaño  y  peso  establecidos en el Código Municipal de Chicago
column37: Capítulo  9-72-070
column38: y  el  Código  Vehicular  de  Illinois
column39: Capítulo  15-111.  Para  más  información  llame al 312-744-4006. Los vehículos con sobrepe- so están sujetos a multas.  Estacionamiento de vehículos  comerciales en Chicago Esta guía explica el reglamento aplicable al esta- cionamiento de camiones comerciales y vehículos  transportadores  de  chatarra  en  la  Ciudad  de  Chicago.  Desde hace muchos años
column40: se prohíbe el estaciona- miento en esta ciudad de camiones (de 18 ruedas)  con un peso superior a 4
column41: 500 libras.  En Chicago se ha promulgado una nueva ley con  restricciones  sobre  el  estacionamiento  de  estos  tipos de vehículos con la finalidad de:  •	garantizar la seguridad en los barrios residenciales •	 evitar  la  impresión  de  comercialización  en  zonas    •		disponer  de  más  estacionamiento  en  áreas  densa-  residenciales  mente pobladas  Las  normas  expuestas  en  este  folleto  están  suje- tas  a  algunas  excepciones.  La  ley  NO  pretende  impactar en sentido negativo a los negocios que  proveen servicios a los habitantes de Chicago. ¿Qué es un “camión comercial”?   Un camión comercial es un vehículo utilizado para  transportar artículos con fines comerciales o indus- triales
column42: o un vehículo transportador de mercancías  o  provisiones  de  índole  comercial  o  industrial
column43: o  un  vehículo  transportador  de  chatarra*  (texto  citado del capítulo 9-64-170). *¿Qué es un “vehículo transportador  de chatarra”?  Cualquier camión
column44: automóvil o vehículo automotor  utilizado en la recolección
column45: disposición o transporte  de chatarra de un lugar a otro.

column1: 20514`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/rev/supp_info/enEspanol/PaymentPlanSpanishVersionPlanesdepago3-15-2016.pdf`Success`Success`2`2`Not a fillable PDF.`Planes de pago por estacionamiento
column2: cámaras de semáforo en rojo
column3: cámaras automatizadas de velocidad   El Departamento de Finanzas ofrece opciones de plan de pagos a los propietarios de vehículos que tengan deudas por  estacionamiento
column4: cumplimiento
column5: cumplimiento de velocidad automatizada o violaciones de cumplimiento de la ley de  tránsito automatizado (es decir
column6: luz roja) (deudas de vehículos). Participar en un plan de pago le permite a un propietario  de vehículo hacer pagos durante el transcurso del tiempo
column7: a la vez que evita la inmovilización del vehículo (el  inmovilizador) o la suspensión de la licencia de conducir.     Los planes de pago también están disponibles para motoristas que ya tienen sus vehículos inmovilizados o sus licencias  de conducir suspendidas.     Planes generales de pago   Requisitos para propietarios de vehículos cuyos vehículos NO han sido inmovilizados o cuyas licencias de conducir NO  se han suspendido:   •  el primer pago es el primer pago mensual;     •  más el pago total de todas las tarifas de inmovilizadores
column8: grúa
column9: manipulación y almacenamiento; y  •   futuros pagos hechos en mensualidades iguales durante un período de 5 a 24 meses.   Requisitos para propietarios de vehículos cuyos vehículos han sido inmovilizados o cuyas licencias de conducir se han  suspendido:   •  Primer pago del 50% sobre la deuda total del vehículo;  •  más el pago total de cualquier tarifa de inmovilizadores
column10: grúa
column11: manipulación y almacenamiento; y  •   futuros pagos hechos en mensualidades iguales durante un período de 6 a 24 meses.   Planes de pago por dificultad financiera   Las personas que cumplen con al menos una de las siguientes cualidades son elegibles para un plan de pago por  dificultad financiera:   •  estudiante (que asiste actualmente a la universidad o la escuela secundaria
column12: de comercio o vocacional) con una   tarjeta de identificación de estudiante válida;   •  adulto mayor (mayor de 65 años);  •  miembro activo del ejército (incluyendo reservistas y guardia nacional);  •  miembro del ejército recientemente inactivo (dado de baja del ejército en los últimos 180 días);  •  ejecución hipotecaria (recibió un aviso de ejecución hipotecaria
column13: inició un consentimiento de ejecución   hipotecaria
column14: entregó una escritura en lugar de una ejecución hipotecaria o recibió una sentencia de ejecución  hipotecaria sobre su residencia primaria dentro de los últimos tres años);   •  bancarrota (responsabilidad por multas y sanciones que se mantienen después de obtener una liberación de   •   bancarrota);  reclamo de crédito fiscal por ingresos ganados (sobre declaración de impuesto sobre la renta individual estatal o  federal para el año fiscal más reciente);   •  participación en cualquiera de los siguientes programas:  o  Compensación por desempleo emitida por el gobierno  o  Programa de Asistencia de energía residencial por bajos ingresos (Low income home energy assistance
column15: LIHEAP)  o  Vivienda federal pública/Sección 8  o  Cupones de alimentos  o  Medicaid o Ingreso suplementario de Seguro Social (Suplemental Security Income
column16: SSI)  o  Programa Asistencia Temporal para Familias Necesitadas (Temporary Assistance for Needy Families
column17: TANF)   administrado por el Departamento de Salud y Servicios Humanos de EE. UU.   o  Programa de Nutrición complementaria especial para mujeres
column18: bebés y niños (Special Supplemental Nutrition   Program for Women
column19: Infants
column20: and Children
column21: WIC)     o  Beneficios por ingresos de compensación de los trabajadores   Requisitos para propietarios de vehículos cuyos vehículos NO han sido inmovilizados o cuyas licencias de conducir NO  se han suspendido:   •  el primer pago es el primer pago mensual;   •  más el pago total de todas las tarifas adeudadas pendientes de inmovilizadores
