column1: 20525`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/fin/supp_info/Revenue/Contractor_Application.pdf`Error`'charmap' codec can't encode character '\u25a1' in position 5741: character maps to <undefined>

20526`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/fin/supp_info/Revenue/Contractor_Placard.pdf`Success`Success`1`1`Fillable PDF.`CONTRACTOR PARKING PLACARD   Chicago Municipal Code:  Section 9-64-170(a)(3) and (b)(3) of the Municipal Code of Chicago   allows a contractor who is actually engaged in delivery
column2: service or repair work at a particular  address for a particular customer to park their vehicle within a reasonable distance of the address  where such work is being performed if (1) the vehicle is emblazoned with the business name and  business license number of its owner; and (2) the customer’s address is clearly displayed on the  vehicle’s dashboard; and (3) the vehicle is lawfully parked in accordance with the general  parking requirements of this Code.  Parking is permitted only while such work is actually being  performed and at no other time. If a service vehicle permit is required under Section 9-68-060
column3: such permit must be obtained.    I
column4: the undersigned
column5: certify
column6: under penalty of law
column7: that this vehicle is  actually engaged in delivery
column8: service or repair work (circle one) at  the following location:  BUSINESS NAME__________________________________________________    BUSINESS LICENSE NUMBER______________________________________   CUSTOMER ADDRESS_____________________________________________           _____________________________________________                  [To include unit or floor number

column1: 20527`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/rev/supp_info/TaxRulingsandRegulations/ParkingTaxRuling1.pdf`Success`Success`1`1`Not a fillable PDF.`PARKING LOT AND GARAGE OPERATIONS TAX RULING      CITY OF CHICAGO   DEPARTMENT OF REVENUE   Parking Lot and Garage Operations Tax Ruling #1  Subject: Residential Off-Street Parking Exemption  Effective date:  June 1
column2: 2004    Original effective date:  June 22
column3: 1992    Section  1.    Pursuant  to  chapter  4-236  of  the  Chicago  Municipal  Code
column4: the  Chicago  Parking Lot and Garage Operations Tax (the “parking tax” or “tax”) is imposed upon the  use and privilege of parking a motor vehicle in or upon any parking lot or garage in the  City of Chicago.  Under Section 4-236-020(c)
column5: the tax does not apply to residential off- street  parking  of  house  or  apartment  tenants  or  condominiums  required  by  the  City  of  Chicago Zoning Ordinance
column6: wherein an arrangement for such parking is provided in the  house or apartment lease or in a separate writing between the landlord or tenant
column7: or if in a  condominium between the condominium association and the owner
column8: occupant or guest of  a unit
column9: whether the parking charge is payable to the landlord
column10: condominium association
column11: or to the operator of the parking lot or garage.    Section 2.  To claim the exemption set forth in subsection 020(c)
column12: the landlord/operator  must maintain supporting documentation.  If called upon by the Department of Revenue
column13: the landlord/operator will be required to substantiate the claim by producing the lease
column14: separate writing or other supporting documents.  Failure to provide proof acceptable to  the Department will bar the landlord/operator from claiming this exemption
column15: in which  case the landlord/operator will be liable for the unpaid tax
column16: plus interest and applicable  penalties.

column1: 20528`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/rev/supp_info/TaxRulingsandRegulations/ParkingTaxRuling2.pdf`Success`Success`1`1`Not a fillable PDF.`PARKING LOT AND GARAGE OPERATIONS TAX RULING      CITY OF CHICAGO   DEPARTMENT OF REVENUE   Parking Lot and Garage Operations Tax Ruling #2  Subject: Valet Parking Operators  Effective date:  June 1
column2: 2004    Original effective date:  February 14
column3: 1995    Section  1.    Pursuant  to  chapter  4-236  of  the  Chicago  Municipal  Code
column4: the  Chicago  Parking Lot and Garage Operations Tax (the “parking tax” or “tax”) is imposed upon the  use and privilege of parking a motor vehicle in or upon any parking lot or garage in the  City of Chicago.    Under Section 4-236-020(a) the tax is due when consideration is paid  for the privilege of occupying a space in or upon any parking lot or garage in the City of  Chicago.  See also section 4-236-020(h).    Section 2.   It shall be presumed that the consideration paid by a person for valet parking  includes  payment  for  the  privilege  of  occupying  a  parking  space  since  the  parking  tax  becomes due whenever payment is made for use of a space in a parking lot or garage.  Valet  parking  operators
column5: as  defined  by  Section  4-232-050(a)
column6: are  therefore  required  to  collect the parking tax and remit it to the Department of Revenue
column7: except as provided in  section 3 and 4 below.    Section 3.    Under Section 4-236-010
column8: the parking tax does not apply to motor vehicles  parked on the public way.  Therefore
column9: a valet parking operator that parks a motor vehicle  on  the  public  way  is  not  obligated  to  collect the  tax  in  that  instance.    A  valet  parking  operator claiming no tax liability
column10: or claiming a reduced liability
column11: pursuant to this section  3 shall have the burden of proving to the Department that the parking occurred on the  public way and not in  a parking lot or parking garage.    Section 4.   A valet parking operator is not required to collect or remit the parking tax if  the valet parking operator or the recipient of the parking space pays the tax to a parking  lot or garage operator other than the valet parking operator.    Additional rules relating to the tax collection responsibilities of valet parking operators    may be promulgated.

column1: 20529`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/rev/supp_info/TaxRulingsandRegulations/ParkingTaxRuling3.pdf`Success`Success`1`1`Not a fillable PDF.`PARKING LOT AND GARAGE OPERATIONS TAX RULING      CITY OF CHICAGO   DEPARTMENT OF REVENUE   Parking Lot and Garage Operations Tax Ruling #3  Subject:  Advertised Rates  Effective date:  June 1
column2: 2004    Original effective date:  March 1
column3: 2001    Every operator of any parking lot or garage that advertises any rate to the public shall  include the total sum of all charges and all applicable taxes as its advertised rate.   Nothing in this section shall prohibit the operator from also disclosing the amount of  applicable taxes included in the advertised rate; provided that the advertised rate shall  appear in larger print.  Any display of the advertised rate shall include in a clear and  conspicuous manner
column4: the following language: “All taxes included.”

column1: 20530`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/fin/supp_info/Revenue/7530_Tax_Info_Bulletin.pdf`Error`'charmap' codec can't encode character '\uf06e' in position 1984: character maps to <undefined>

20531`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/rev/supp_info/TaxSupportingInformation/InformationBulletinParkingTaxJune2013.pdf`Success`Success`2`2`Not a fillable PDF.`"  Vol.   2013   No.  1                                                            CHICAGO DEPARTMENT OF FINANCE                                                               JUNE 2013                     INFORMATIONAL BULLETIN     Registered Parking Lot  And Garage Operators   TO:      The purpose of this bulletin is to outline the  recent amendments to the Parking Lot and  Garage Operations Tax (“Tax”).  This  bulletin discusses certain issues pertaining  to the Tax and what tax rate applies to  specific situations.     General Information     The Tax is imposed on the use and  privilege of parking a motor vehicle in or  upon any parking lot or garage in the City  of Chicago. The ultimate incidence of and  liability for payment of the Tax is on the  parking recipient.      Amendments to the Parking Tax     On April 10
column3: the City Council passed  amendments which are effective July 1
column4: 2013. The amendments include the  following changes to the daily
column5: weekly and  monthly rates (with the old rates stricken  and the new rates underscored):    4-236-010 Definitions.    The following definition was added to the  ordinance    “Charge or fee paid for parking"" means the  gross amount of consideration for the use  or privilege of parking a motor vehicle in  or upon any parking lot or garage in the  City of Chicago
column6: valued in money
column7: whether  received in money or otherwise
column8: including  cash
column9: credits
column10: property
column11: and services
column12: determined without any deduction for costs  or expenses whatsoever
column13: but not including  charges that are added to the charge or fee  on account of the tax imposed by this  chapter or on account of any other tax  imposed on the charge or fee. The term  ""charge or fee for parking"" shall exclude  separately stated charges not for the use or   (cid:132) Chicago Parking Tax (cid:132)   privilege of parking. If any separately  stated charge is not optional
column14: it shall be  presumed
column15: unless proved otherwise
column16: that it  is part of the charge for the use or  privilege of parking.    4-236-020 Tax imposed.    (a) Except as otherwise provided by this  Section 4-236-020
column17: there is imposed upon  the use and privilege of parking a motor  vehicle in or upon any parking lot or  garage in the City of Chicago a tax of  $5.00 for each such motor vehicle parked  in or upon each parking lot or garage for  every 24-hour period or fraction thereof;  provided
column18: however
column19: that if the charge for  parking is made on a weekly or monthly  basis
column20: the tax shall be calculated at the rate  of $25.00 per week or $120.00 per month
column21: respectively at the applicable rate set forth  in subsection (d).    (Omitted text is not affected by this  ordinance)    (d) (i) The tax imposed by this chapter  shall not apply if the charge or fee  imposed for the privilege of parking does  not exceed $2.00 for a 24-hour period or  less
column22: or $10.00 for a weekly period or  $40.00 for a monthly period.    (ii) The tax imposed by this chapter for the  privilege of parking for a 24-hour  period or less shall be $1.00
column23: if the charge  or fee is greater than $2.00 but less than  $5.00; $1.75
column24: if the charge or fee is $5.00  or more but less than $12.00; $3.00
column25: if the  charge or fee is $12.00 or more and paid  18% of the charge or fee paid for parking  on a Saturday or Sunday; and $5.00
column26: if  the charge or fee is $12.00 or more and  paid 20% of the charge or fee paid for  parking on a Monday
column27: Tuesday
column28: Wednesday
column29: Thursday or Friday.    (iii) The tax imposed by this chapter for  the privilege of parking on a weekly  basis shall be $5.00 if the charge or fee is  greater than $10.00 but less than $25.00;  $8.75
column30: if the charge or fee is $25.00 or   more but less than $60.00; and $25.00
column31: if  the charge or fee is $60.00 or more 20% of  the charge or fee paid for parking.    (iv) The tax imposed by this chapter for  the privilege of parking on a monthly  basis shall be $20.00 if the charge or fee is  greater than $40.00 but less than $100.00;  $35.00
column32: if the charge or fee is $100.00 or  more but less than $210.00; $90.00
column33: if the  charge or fee is $210.00 or more but less  than $300.00; $110.00 if the charge or fee  is $300.00 or more but less than $100.00:  and $120.00 if the charge or fee is $100.00  or more 20% of the charge or fee paid for  parking.    (v) The tax rates set forth in subsection (a)  subsections (d) (ii) - (iv) shall be deemed  to apply to the privilege of parking a  motor vehicle in a parking lot or garage  unless the taxpayer or tax collector keeps  accurate and complete books and records  as required by this chapter showing that  either a reduced rate or no tax applies.    Clarification of the application  of the new daily parking tax  rates to specific situations    Weekday/Weekend overlap    Where a taxable period of 24 hours or less  starts on a weekday and ends on a  weekend
column34: the weekend rate of 18% will  apply to that entire period.  Conversely
column35: where a taxable period of 24 hours or less  starts on a weekend and ends on a  weekday
column36: the weekday rate of 20% will  apply to that entire period.    Where a taxable period of 24 hours or less  starts and ends on a weekend
column37: the weekend  rate of 18% will apply to that entire  period.  Conversely
column38: where a taxable  period of 24 hours or less starts and ends  on a weekday
column39: the weekday rate of 20%  will apply to that entire period.         Example #1    If a customer parks in a garage at 8:00 a.m.  on Friday and leaves at 8:00 a.m. on  Saturday
column40: the Tax due for that period is  computed using the 18% rate.    Example #2    If a customer parks in a garage at 8:00 a.m.  on Sunday and leaves at 8:00 a.m. on  Monday the Tax due is computed using the  20% rate.    In both situations above the tax rate that  applies depends on when the parking  charge is paid. Both situations assume the  charge is paid when the customer leaves  the parking facility.  Generally the tax is  calculated when the payment is made.   Monday through Friday the 20% tax rate  applies. On Saturday and Sunday the lower  18% tax rate applies.     Example #3    If a customer parks at an airport at 10:00  a.m. on Monday and leaves at 10:00 a.m.  on Saturday
column41: the 20% tax rate applies to  each of the 24 hour periods starting at  10:00 a.m. on Monday
column42: 10:00 a.m. on  Tuesday
column43: 10:00 a.m. on Wednesday
column44: and  10:00 a.m. on Thursday
column45: with 18% tax rate  due for the period of 10:00 a.m. Friday to  10:00 a.m. Saturday.  If the customer  instead leaves at a later time on Saturday
column46: the weekend rates apply to any taxable  charges for the additional time.     Example #4    A hotel guest enters the garage at 10:00  a.m. on Saturday and departs at 10:00 a.m.  on Monday.  An 18% tax is due for the  period of 10:00 a.m. Saturday to 10:00 a.m.  Sunday
column47: and a 20% tax is due for the period  of 10:00 a.m. Sunday to 10:00 a.m.  Monday. If the customer instead leaves at a  later time on Monday
column48: the weekday rates  apply to any taxable charges for the  additional time.    Advance Purchase Situations    Defined Event    A customer pre-purchases a book of passes  for a sports team’s home games where  parking passes are on pre-defined game  days. The parking tax rate due applies as  described above for the given day the  sporting event takes place either on a  weekday (20%) or weekend (18%).      Since these charges are paid in advance  and the time and date of the event are                                                                                           defined
column49: the start time and date dictate  whether the 20% or 18% rate applies.      Non-defined Event    A customer purchases bulk validation  tickets or coupons for future use where  date of use cannot be determined. For  example
column50: a law firm that buys numerous  validation tickets to give to clients  throughout a month or year
column51: or downtown  residents who buy multiple coupons for  guest parking:    The operator selling the “bulk validation  tickets or coupons” should sell both  weekday and weekend tickets which users  can redeem on the applicable day.    The 18% weekend rate will apply to the  weekend tickets
column52: and the 20% weekday  rate will apply to the weekday tickets.      Annual Tax Returns     Every Operator is required to file an  annual tax return with the Department.   Such return shall include a separate site  schedule for each individual lot
column53: garage or  site operated by the Operator.  Returns  shall include Gross Revenues and Parker  counts by category as well as authorized  deductions by site.      An Annual tax return is required for every  lot or garage operated
column54: regardless is tax is  due or not.  A detailed accounting of all  revenues and deductions must be made  annually.       Valet Operators    The 15% “safe harbor” that had  previously been allowed will no longer be  permitted effective July 1
column55: 2013.      Valet Parking Operators are now expected  to collect and remit Parking tax using the  18% and 20% rates outlined in 4-236-020  and include all revenues received on Line 1  of the annual return.  Any revenues  received where the vehicle is parked on the  street should be deducted on line 2(e) of  the tax return.  Operators are required to  maintain documentation to verify the  deductibility of those revenues.           Furthermore
column56: if a Valet Operator parks the  vehicle in a lot or garage and remits the tax  directly to that operator they should deduct  the collected revenues on line 2 (e) of their  annual return and maintain documentation  to support the deduction because tax has  been paid to another Operator.        Questions?  If you have questions or need more  information
column57: please write us. Our  address is:  City of Chicago  Department of Finance  Tax Division  c/o Raul Medina  333 South State Street
column58: Suite 300  Chicago
column59: Illinois 60604-3977  rmedina@cityofchicago.org   "

column1: 20532`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/rev/supp_info/TaxSupportingInformation/December_2011_Info_Bulletin_ParkingTax.pdf`Success`Success`2`2`Not a fillable PDF.`  Vol.   2011  No.  1                                                            CHICAGO DEPARTMENT OF FINANCE                                                     DECEMBER 2011                     INFORMATIONAL BULLETIN   (cid:132)        Chicago Parking Tax     Registered Parking Lot  And Garage Operators   TO:     The purpose of this bulletin is to  outline recent amendments to the  Parking Lot and Garage Operations  Tax (“tax”).  This bulletin discusses  certain issues pertaining to the tax and  what tax rate applies to specific  situations.     General Information     The tax is imposed on the use and  privilege of parking a motor vehicle in  or upon any parking lot or garage in  the City of Chicago. The ultimate  incidence of and liability for payment  of the tax is on the parking recipient.      Amendments to the Parking Tax     On November 2
column3: the City  Council passed amendments which are  effective January 1
column4: 2012. The  amendments include the following  changes to the daily
column5: weekly and  monthly rates (with the old rates  stricken and the new rates  underscored):     (ii)  chapter for the privilege of parking for  a 24-hour period or less shall be $1.00
column6: if the charge or fee is greater than  $2.00 but less than $5.00; $1.75
column7: if the  charge or fee is $5.00 or more but less  than $12.00; and $3.00
column8: if the charge  or fee is $12.00 or more and paid on a  Saturday or Sunday; and $5.00
column9: if the  charge or fee is $12.00 or more and  paid on a Monday
column10: Tuesday
column11: Wednesday
column12: Thursday or Friday.       The tax imposed by this         The tax imposed by this     The tax imposed by this   (iii)  chapter for the privilege of parking on  a weekly basis shall be $5.00 if the  charge or fee is greater than $10.00  but less than $25.00; $8.75
column13: if the  charge or fee is $25.00 or more but  less than $60.00; and $15.00 $25.00
column14: if the charge or fee is $60.00 or more.    (iv)  chapter for the privilege of parking on  a monthly basis shall be $20.00 if the  charge or fee is greater than $40.00  but less than $100.00; $35.00
column15: if the  charge or fee is $100.00 or more but  less than $240.00; and $60.00 $90.00  if the charge or fee is $240.00 or more  but less than $300.00; $110.00 if the  charge or fee is $300.00 or more but  less than $400.00; and $120.00 if the  charge or fee is $400.00 or more.    Clarification of the  application of the new daily  parking tax rates to specific  situations    Weekday/Weekend overlap    Where a taxable period of 24 hours or  less starts on a weekday and ends on a  weekend
column16: the weekend rate of $3 will  apply to that entire period.   Conversely
column17: where a taxable period of  24 hours or less starts on a weekend  and ends on a weekday
column18: the weekday  rate of $5 will apply to that entire  period.     In the situations noted above the tax  rate that applies depends on when the  parking charge is paid.  These  situations assume the charge is paid  when the customer leaves the parking  facility.  Generally the tax is  calculated when the payment is made.   Monday through Friday the $5.00 rate   applies. On Saturday and Sunday the  $3.00 rate applies.    Where a taxable period of 24 hours or  less starts and ends on a weekend
column19: the  weekend rate of $3 will apply to that  entire period.  Conversely
column20: where a  taxable period of 24 hours or less  starts and ends on a weekday
column21: the  weekday rate of $5 will apply to that  entire period.     Example #1    A customer parks in a garage at 8:00  a.m. on Friday and leaves at 8:00 a.m.  on Saturday.  The tax due for that  period is $3.00.    Example #2    A customer parks in a garage at 8:00  a.m. on Sunday and leaves at 8:00  a.m. on Monday.  The tax due is  $5.00.    Example #3    A customer parks at an airport lot or  garage at 10:00 a.m. on Monday and  leaves at 10:00 a.m. on Saturday.  The  $5.00 tax applies to each of the 24  hour periods starting at 10:00 a.m. on  Monday
column22: 10:00 a.m. on Tuesday
column23: 10:00 a.m. on Wednesday
column24: and 10:00  a.m. on Thursday
column25: with $3.00 tax due  for the period of 10:00 a.m. Friday to  10:00 a.m. Saturday.  If the customer  instead leaves at a later time on  Saturday
column26: the weekend rates apply to  any taxable charges for the additional  time.                                                                                                                    The operator selling the bulk  validation tickets or coupons should  either:  (1) sell separate weekday and  weekend tickets
column27: in which case the $5  weekday rate will apply to the  weekday tickets
column28: and the $3 weekend  rate will apply to the weekend tickets;  or (2) sell one form of ticket
column29: which  may be used any day of the week  (weekday or weekend)
column30: in which case  the $5 weekday rate should be applied  to all of the tickets.      Questions?    If you have questions or need more  information
column31: please write us. Our  address is:    City of Chicago  Department of Finance  Tax Division  c/o Raul Medina  333 South State Street
column32: Suite 300  Chicago
column33: Illinois 60604-3977  rmedina@cityofchicago.org                 Example #4    A customer parks at an airport lot or  garage at 10:00 a.m. on Saturday and  departs at 10:00 a.m. on Monday.  A  $3.00 tax is due for the period of 10:00  a.m. Saturday to 10:00 a.m. Sunday
column34: and a $5.00 tax is due for the period of  10:00 a.m. Sunday to 10:00 a.m.  Monday. If the customer instead leaves  at a later time on Monday
column35: the  weekday rates apply to any taxable  charges for the additional time.    Example #5    A hotel guest stays overnight at the  hotel for Saturday night and Sunday  night
column36: and departs on Monday  morning.  The hotel charges its  overnight guests for parking based on  the night of stay.  A $3.00 tax is due  for Saturday night
column37: and a $3.00 tax is  due for Sunday night.    Example #6    A hotel guest stays overnight at the  hotel for Friday night and Saturday  night
column38: and departs on Sunday morning.   The hotel charges its overnight guests  for parking based on the night of stay.   A $5.00 tax is due for Friday night
column39: and a $3.00 tax is due for Saturday  night.    Advance Purchase Situations    Defined Event    A customer pre-purchases a book of  passes for a sports team’s home games  where parking passes are on pre- defined game days. The dates of the  events are known in advance
column40: and  those dates dictate whether the $5  weekday rate or the $3 weekend rate  applies.      Non-defined Event    A customer purchases bulk validation  tickets or coupons for future use where  date of use cannot be determined. For  example
column41: a law firm that buys  numerous validation tickets to give to  clients throughout a month or year
column42: or  downtown residents who buy multiple  coupons for guest parking:

column1: 20533`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/rev/supp_info/TaxSupportingInformation/February_2000_Info_Bulletin_Parking_Tax.pdf`Success`Success`3`3`Not a fillable PDF.`February 2000 Information Bulletin    Information Bulletin  Parking Tax Amendments/Record-Keeping Requirements   TO: Registered Parking Lot and Garage Operators  The purpose of this bulletin is to outline recent amendments to the Parking Lot and Garage  Operations tax and to advise operators of their right to appeal to the Director of Revenue for  alternative record-keeping requirements where acceptable systems
column2: controls and an audit trail are  in place to ensure accurate reporting and documentation of the collection of this tax. This is the  first Information Bulletin issued to parking operators.   General Information  The parking tax is imposed on the use and privilege of parking a motor vehicle in or upon any  parking lot or garage in the City of Chicago. The ultimate incidence of and liability for payment  of this tax is on the parking recipient. It shall be the duty of every operator of a parking lot or  garage to secure the tax from each recipient and to remit the tax to the Department of Revenue.  The municipal code reference for this tax is Chapter 4-236.   Amendments to the Parking Tax  On November 17
column4: the City Council passed amendments to the parking tax which are  effective March 1
column5: 2000. The amendments include:    •  A Tax Rate Increase     Except as noted below
column6: the parking tax rate has been increased from $1.50 to $2.00 for  each motor vehicle parked in a lot or garage for every 24-hour period or fraction thereof.  The rate of tax has been increased from $7.50 to $10.00 if the charge for parking is made  on a weekly basis and from $30.00 to $40.00 if the charge for parking is on a monthly  basis.     •  Limited Reduced Tax Rates     The parking tax has been reduced under certain circumstances. If the charge for parking a  motor vehicle for a 24-hour period or fraction thereof is greater than $2.00 but less than  $5.00
column7: the parking tax will be 75 cents. If the charge for parking a motor vehicle on a  weekly basis is greater than $10.00 but less than $25.00
column8: the parking tax will be $3.75. If  the charge for parking a motor vehicle on a monthly basis is greater than $50.00 but less  than $100.00
column9: the tax will be $15.00.     •  Limited Tax -Free Parking     The tax shall not be imposed on parking privileges where the charge or fee does not  exceed $2.00 for a 24-hour period or fraction thereof
column10: or $10.00 for a weekly period or  $40.00 for a monthly period.     In summary
column11: where an operator charges different parking rates based on the day of week  or length of time that a motor vehicle is parked
column12: the applicable tax rate for the parking  privilege shall be determined by the actual amount charged for that motor vehicle.    It should be noted that the full tax rate will apply to all parking privileges in cases where  an operator fails to keep accurate and complete books and records evidencing that the  reduced rate or no tax applies.     •  New Collector's Commission   •     For the period February 1
column13: 1997 to July 31
column15: operators may retain a total of one  percent of the parking tax they collect to reimburse themselves for expenses incurred in  connection with collecting
column16: accounting for and remitting the tax
column17: and with implementing  the parking tax changes set forth in the recent amendments to the parking ordinance.    This commission shall not be allowed for taxes not timely remitted to the Department of  Revenue or for periods during which an operator is not in compliance with the ticket
column18: tag  or receipt requirements contained in Chapter 4-236 of the municipal code of Chicago.    Issuance of Receipts    An additional requirement has been added to the parking tax. Operators will now be  required to issue receipts to daily parkers showing the amount of the parking charge and  the amount of the parking tax paid.    Unless a cash register is used which produces a daily summary tape showing the number  of motor vehicles parked
column19: the total charges paid and the amount of tax collected for each  tier of parking taxes
column20: and unless the tapes are maintained as required
column21: the receipt shall be  in the form of a two-part numerical receipt.     Operators required to issue two-part receipts shall retain one part and issue one part to the  recipient. Each part shall show the parking charge and the amount of tax paid.    Operators who fail to issue receipts in the form or manner provided for in the parking tax  ordinance shall be subject to fines of not less than $50.00 nor more than $200.00 for each  motor vehicle parked for which no conforming receipt is issued to the patron.     •  Additional Record-Keeping Requirements     Section 4-236-050 outlines an operator's duty to keep accurate and complete books and  records to which the Director of Revenue shall at all times have full access.     A requirement to maintain all cash register and other receipts and all cash register tapes  was added in the recent amendments.    In addition
column22: the daily sheets required to be maintained must now be kept separate for each   •   •   the number of motor vehicles parked in or on each lot or garage
column23: segregated on a  daily
column24: weekly
column25: monthly or other basis and further segregated by the amount of the  charge or fee imposed for parking.    the actual parking tax receipts collected from all transactions.     •  Additional Reporting Requirement   location. These daily sheets are to include:       Operators will now also be required to report their monthly parking receipts
column26: net of tax  collected
column27: and the number of non-taxable parkers on their returns    Rights to Appeal to the Director of Revenue for Alternative Record- Keeping  Requirements  The amendments related to record keeping and issuance of receipts were added to ensure a  sufficient audit trail exists should an operator be selected for audit or come under investigation. It  is possible an operator may have systems
column28: controls and audit trails in place presently that vary  from these requirements but are acceptable to the Department of Revenue.    If an operator feels this is the case
column29: an application may be submitted to the Director outlining  systems
column30: controls and the audit trail of documents.   All applications should detail the nature of the operation ( ie. garage
column31: parking lot operated at a  fixed location throughout the year
column32: parking lot operated on an event basis
column33: honor lot
column34: etc.) for  which the application is made and include sufficient explanation of proposed alternatives. Copies  of related business documents and records should be attached to the application where possible.   You should also be aware of the fact that the parking tax ordinance includes a provision wherein  operators
column35: on an annual basis
column36: may request approval from the Director of Revenue to discard  tickets and tags that were issued more than one year earlier. The Director shall grant such  approval if he or she determines that the operator's books and records satisfy the record-keeping  requirements of the parking tax ordinance.   All applications should be sent to the address below:    Chicago Department of Revenue  Audit Division  DePaul Center   333 S. State
column37: Suite 300  Chicago
column38: IL 60604-3977  Attn: Charles E. Brown   New Parking Tax Returns  Parking tax returns and instructions for 1997 will be mailed out in January
column39: 1997. If you do not  receive your returns by the end of January or if you have any questions
column40: contact our Customer  Service Unit at (312) 747-9723.

column1: 20534`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/rev/supp_info/TaxSupportingInformation/December_1999_Info_Bulletin_Parking_Tax.pdf`Success`Success`2`2`Not a fillable PDF.`December 1999 Information Bulletin    Information Bulletin  Parking Taxes for Registered Parking Lot and Garage Operators   TO: REGISTERED PARKING LOT AND GARAGE OPERATORS  The purpose of this Informational Bulletin is to outline recent amendments to the Parking Lot  and Garage Operation tax and to notify parking lot and garage operators on new filing and  payment requirements. This is the second Information Bulletin issued to parking operators.   General Information  The parking tax is imposed on the use and privilege of parking a motor vehicle in or upon any  parking lot or garage in the City of Chicago. The ultimate incidence of and liability for payment  of this tax is on the parking recipient.   It shall be the duty of every operator of a parking lot or garage to secure the tax from each  recipient and to remit the tax to the Department of Revenue. The municipal code reference for  this tax is Chapter 4- 236.   Amendments to the Parking Tax  On November 2
column3: the City Council passed amendments to the parking tax which are  effective March 1
column4: 2000. The amendments include:   A Tax Rate Increase   For the privilege of parking for a 24- hour period or less the tax is $.75 if the charge or fee is  greater than $2.00 but less than $5.00; $1.50 if the charge or fee is $5.00 or more but less than  $12.00; and $2.00 if the charge or fee is $12.00 or more.   The tax imposed by the ordinance for the privilege of parking on a weekly basis shall be $3.75 if  the charge or fee is greater than $10.00 but less than $25.00; $7.50 if the charge or fee is $25.00  or more but less than $60.00; and $10.00 if the fee is $60.00 or more.   The tax imposed by this chapter for the privilege of parking on a monthly basis shall be $15.00 if  the charge or fee is greater than $50.00 but less than $100.00.; $30.00 if the charge or fee is  $100.00 or more but less than $240.00; and $40.00 if the charge or fee is $240.00 or more.   Limited Tax -Free Parking  The tax shall not be imposed on parking privileges where the charge or fee does not exceed  $2.00 for a 24-hour period or fraction thereof
column5: or $10.00 for a weekly period or $40.00 for a  monthly period.   In summary
column6: where an operator charges different parking rates based on the day of week or  length of time that a motor vehicle is parked
column7: the applicable tax rate for the parking privilege  shall be determined by the actual amount charged for that motor vehicle.   It should be noted that the full tax rate will apply to all parking privileges in cases where an  operator fails to keep accurate and complete books and records evidencing that the reduced rate  or no tax applies.    Questions?  If you have questions or need more information
column8: please write or call us. Our address and  telephone numbers are:   City of Chicago  Department of Revenue  Tax Policy Division  333 S. State Street
column9: Ste. 300  Chicago

column1: 20620`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/rev/supp_info/TaxRulingsandRegulations/TranTaxRuling1.pdf`Success`Success`2`2`Not a fillable PDF.`CITY OF CHICAGO   DEPARTMENT OF REVENUE   PERSONAL PROPERTY LEASE TRANSACTION TAX RULING      Personal Property Lease Transaction Tax Ruling #1  Subject: Consummation of Transaction  Effective date:  June 1
column2: 2004    Formerly Ruling #3  Original effective date:  March 8
column3: 1974  Revised:  July 1
column4: 1984    Section 1.  Pursuant to section 3-32-030(A) of the Chicago Municipal Code (“Code”)
column5: a tax is imposed upon (1) the lease or rental in the City of personal property
column6: or (2) the  privilege of using in the City personal property that is leased or rented outside the City.     A  taxable  lease  or  rental  of  personal  property  takes  place  (a)  when  an  agreement  or  contract is signed or otherwise entered into by the parties in Chicago and the delivery or  use of the object of the agreement also takes place in Chicago
column7: or (b) when 50% or more  of the use of the object of the agreement between the parties occurs or will occur within  the City of Chicago.  If delivery occurs within the City it shall be presumed that 50% or  more of the use will occur in the City
column8: unless proved otherwise.    Section 2.     Application of this section is illustrated by the following:   When  a  lease  is  signed  and  the  delivery  of  the  property  takes  place  in   a.  Chicago
column9: the transaction is subject to tax.               b.  When  a  lease  is  signed  and  the  delivery  occurs  in  Chicago
column10: but  the  property is returned to the lessor at termination of the lease outside of Chicago
column11: the transaction is subject to tax.   When a lease is signed in Chicago and the delivery and entire use takes   c.  place outside of Chicago
column12: the transaction is not subject to tax.   d.  When  delivery  or  use  of  leased  property  takes  place  in  Chicago
column13: the  transaction is taxable unless it is proved that the agreement was not entered into  within the City and that 50% or more of the use did not occur within the City.   e.  When a lease is signed outside of Chicago
column14: and the property is delivered  and used outside of Chicago with  in termittent use (less than 50%) in Chicago the  transaction is not subject to tax.   The 50%-or-more-of-use requirement  applies only  if the agreement was      Section 3.  entered into outside the City.  Furthermore
column15: if a separate payment is required for each  period of rental or lease time
column16: the 50%-or-more-of-use requirement shall apply to the use  within the payment period.  If rental or lease payments are determined by usage of the   object
column17: then 50%-or-more-of-use refers to the usage within the City as compared to the  usage outside of the City for the payment period. A“payment period” is any period of  time for which a payment is required for the use of the rented or leased property.

column4: 1984      Pursuant  to  Section  3-32-030(A)  of  the  Chicago  Municipal  Code  (“Code”)

column1: 20622`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/rev/supp_info/TaxRulingsandRegulations/TransTaxRuling3.pdf`Success`Success`2`2`Not a fillable PDF.`PERSONAL PROPERTY LEASE TRANSACTION TAX RULING      CITY OF CHICAGO   DEPARTMENT OF REVENUE   Personal Property Lease Transaction Tax Ruling #3  Subject:  Personal Property subject to tax and computation of tax  Effective date:  June 1
column2: 2004    Formerly Ruling #7  Original effective date:  November 15
column3: 1974  Revised:  July 1
column4: 1984  Revised:  April 7
column5: 1985    Section 1.  Pursuant to section 3-32-030(A) of the Chicago Municipal Code (“Code”)
column6: the  Chicago  Personal  Property  Lease  Transaction  Tax  (the  “lease  tax”  or  “tax”)  is  imposed upon (1) the lease or rental in the City of personal property
column7: or (2) the privilege  of using in the City personal property that is leased or rented outside the City.  Section 3- 32-030(A)  does  not  limit  the  application  of  the  tax  to  any  specific  types  of  personal  property.  Therefore
column8: unless expressly exempted
column9: the tax applies to the lease or rental of  any type of personal property.    Section 2.  Under  Section  3-32-030(A)
column10: the  lease  or  rental  of  personal  property  includes  lease  time  on  personal  property  not  itself  rented
column11: such  as  usage  time  on  a  computer
column12: data  processing  equipment
column13: copying  machines
column14: etc.    Therefore
column15: the  use  of  a  computer for a fee by a computer operator/lessee is subject to tax even though physical  possession  of  the  computer  does  not  transfer  to  the  lessee.    Likewise
column16: the  rental  of  or  usage time on the computer software is also subject to tax.    Section 3.  A  lease  or  rental  of  personal  property  occurs  under  the  ordinance  when  there  is  a  transfer  of  the  possession  or  use  of  personal  property  or  the  right  to  the  possession  or  use  of  personal  property
column17: but  not  the  title  or  ownership  thereof
column18: for  a  valuable consideration.    Section 4.  The  lease tax is calculated on the lease or rental price.  Lease or rental  price means consideration paid for the lease or rental of personal property
column19: but excluding  any  separately-stated  charges  not  for  the  use  of  personal  property.   See  also  Section  5  below.  A primary factor in determining whether a separately-stated charge is for the use  of personal property is whether or not the charge is optional.    Section 5.  For    contracts  which  involve  both  a  sale  of  a  service  and  a  lease  of  personal property
column20: the lessor shall be required to separate the lease or rental portion from  the sale portion
column21: as provided in Section 4 above.  If  the lessor fails to separate the lease  or rental portion of the price  from the non-lease or non-rental portion
column22: the entire price  charged shall be deemed taxable
column23: unless it is clearly proven that at least 50% of the price  is  not  for  the  use  of  any  personal  property.    If  this  occurs
column24: then  the  portion  not  representing the use of personal property would be non-taxable.  Neither Section 4 nor   A transaction involving the transfer of the possession or use of personal   this  section  is  intended  to  allow  a  lessor  to  treat  normal  overhead  costs
column25: such  as  maintenance
column26: as non-taxable sales of services unless the lease agreement clearly indicates  that these costs are being charged separately to the lessee and are optional.    Section 6.  property shall be taxable even though only a small portion of the transaction involves the  transfer of the possession or use of such property.  However
column27: the amount subject to tax  shall be determined as provided in this ruling.  If the transfer of personal property is  incidental to the service provided
column28: in that the use of the personal property has little or no  value without the accompanying service and the cost of the personal property is de  minimis  (i.e.
column29: nominal) compared to the price charged for the total transaction
column30: then no  lease or rental shall be deemed to have occurred
column31: and no portion of the price shall be  taxable.  Furthermore
column32: if the lessor or lessor’s agent furnishes the services of operating   equipment for a lessee
column33: so that only the lessor or lessor’s agent uses the equipment
column34: and so  that the lessor or lessor’s agent remains both in total possession and in total control of the  equipment
column35: then no lease or rental shall be deemed to have occurred
column36: and no portion of  the price shall be taxable.  However
column37: a person who operates a terminal to use a computer  is considered the user of that computer
column38: and such use is subject to the tax
column39: even though the  physical possession of the computer remains in the hands of the computer owner; and in  such a case the location of the terminal used by the operator shall be deemed the location  of the use of the computer by such operator for purposes of the tax.

column18: ink  and  other  property  through  the  use  of  the  copying      machine  is  already  taxable  under  the  MROT;  therefore

column21: where the possession of the  machine does not transfer but where a charge is made for the period of use of the  machine by the user.  This does not apply
column22: however

column5: or (2) the privilege  of using in the City personal property that is leased or rented outside the City.  Section 3- 32-020(O) defines personal property as including all property other than real property.   The tax
column6: therefore

column8: as well as
column9: the lease or rental of hardware-type equipment (i.e.
column10: VCR’s
column11: TV’s

column13: the lease  or rental price of such personal property is subject to the  lease tax.     Section 2.  Late
column14: membership  and  club  fees  are  also  taxable  under  Section  3-32- 030(A) except when it is demonstrated that such fees are not part of the consideration for  the lease or rental of personal property.  For example:     A.  In addition to the agreed lease or rental price
column15: a late fee of $2.00 per day is  charged

A fee is charged to become a member of a particular group/club wherein  the  benefits  to  be  derived  from  membership  include  the  ability  to  lease  or  rent  video tapes for free
column17: at a discount
column18: or in advance of others.  Such membership/club  fees  are  taxable  because  they  represent  payments  which  are  part  of  the  consideration for the lease or rental of personal property.  Part of this fee might be  excluded from tax

column21: even though at a later date they are subsequently sold
column22: the lease or rental of such  personal property
column23: prior to such sale
column24: is subject to the  lease tax.  It should be noted that  withdrawal of tapes from the lease or rental market for purpose of retail sale converts  such property to sales property
column25: and as such

column28: at the sales price.

column3: 1991                    Where boats are leased or chartered or where sightseeing or other boat rides are  provided
column4: the  boat  operator  must  collect  and  remit  either  the  personal  property  lease  transaction tax (Chicago Municipal Code chapter 3-32) or the amusement tax (Chicago  Municipal Code chapter 4-156)
column5: depending on the nature of the transaction.     The amusement tax applies under the following circumstances:    The  boat  operator  provides  a  pilot
column6: and  the  boat  will  travel  on  a  route  that  is  predetermined by the boat operator and not subject to negotiation with the patron.   The transaction tax applies in  either of the following circumstances:    •  The boat is leased without a pilot.   •  The boat is leased with a pilot and the patron/lessee may determine  the route.  In this situation
column7: piloting and other service charges will  not be subject to the transaction tax if these charges are separately  stated. The remaining charge is subject to the transaction tax.   All separately stated service charges must be supported by documentary evidence   in order to be non-taxable.

There is an exemption for ""[t]he use  in the city of personal property leased or rented outside the city ifthe property is primarily  used (more than 50 percent) outside the city.""  Code Section 3-32-050(A)(I).  As with other  exemptions
column28: the burden is on the taxpayer or tax collector to prove
column29: with written evidence
column30: that the taxpayer or tax collector is entitled to this exemption.  See
column32: Code Sections 3-4­ 130
column33: 3-4-340; Telco Leasing
column34: Inc. v.  Allphin
column35: 63  Ill. 2d 305  (1976); West Belmont
column36: L.L.c.  v.  City of Chicago
column37: 349 Ill. App.  3d 46 (I st Dist. 2004).   d.  Collection.  The lessor is responsible for collecting the tax from the lessee at the time  of each lease or rental payment
column38: and for remitting the tax to the Department of Revenue  (""Department"").  Lessors that fail  to  collect or remit the tax are liable to the City for the  amount of such tax
column39: plus interest and penalties.  Code Section 3-32-070.   e.  Books and records.  Every lessor is required to retain for at least five years accurate  books and records ofeach transaction or activity requiring the lessor to collect and remit the  tax.  Code Section 3-32-110.  Such books and records include original source documents and  books of entry denoting the transactions that gave rise
column40: or may have given rise
column41: to any tax  liability
column42: exemption
column43: or deduction.  Code Section 3-4-170.   f.  Rules  and  regulations.  The  Director  of the  Department  is  authorized  to  adopt
column44: promulgate  and  enforce  rules  and  regulations  pertaining  to  the  administration  and  enforcement of the lease tax.  Code Section 3-32-120.   Record keeping.  In light of the  above
column45: each motor vehicle rental company doing  Section 3.  business in the City is advised
column46: when renting from a suburban location within 3 miles ofthe City's  border (excluding the borders of O'Hare)
column47: to a customer who will use the vehicle in the City
column48: to  maintain written records that support any claim of exemption from the tax
column49: for the company's use  in the event of an audit.   In the  event of an audit
column50: absent written proof to  the contrary
column51: the Department will assume that a  customer who is a Chicago resident (according to the customer's driver's license)
column52: whenrenting from  such a location
column53: will use the vehicle in the City; and the Departm~nt will assume that a customer who  is not a Chicago resident (according to the customer's driver's license)
column54: when renting from such a  location
column55: will not use the vehicle in the City.   The Department deems the following provisions to be acceptable to support the exemption for use  primarily outside the  City
column56: if  made part of a company's rental  agreement or related books  and  records kept in connection with such rentals to Chicago residents:   2   By initialing this space you are notifYing us that you plan to use this vehicle  50% or more of the time (including garaging) in the City of Chicago.   By initialing this space you are notifYing us that you plan to use this vehicle  more than 50% ofthe time (including garaging) outside the City ofChicago.   For purposes of this ruling
column57: the term ""doing business"" in the City includes
column58: for example
column59: having a  location in the City or regularly renting vehicles that are used in the City
column60: such that the company is  subject to audit by the Department under state and federal law.  Any company that is not sure if its  operations constitute ""doing business"" in the City may contact the Department for an opinion.   Section 4.  Three Mile Limit. As a policy matter
column61: the Department has decided that
column62: absent further  notice (as set forth below)
column63: it will not audit or assess any motor vehicle rental companies for rentals  from locations more than three (3) miles outside Chicago's border
column64: excluding that portion of the  City's border composed of the boundaries of O'Hare.  If the Department decides to change this  policy
column65: it will provide at least 120 days' advance written notice
column66: and the change will be prospective  only.  Any company that is not sure if anyone of its locations is more than three (3) miles outside  Chicago's border (excluding the.borders ofO'Hare) may contact the Department for a determination  of that issue.   Section 5.  Safe Harbor.  In lieu ofmaintaining the kind ofwritten records referred to in Section  3 above
column67: a motor vehicle rental company with suburban locations within three (3) miles ofChicago' s  border (excluding the borders of0 'Hare) may
column68: as a safe harbor
column69: assume that 25% ofits rental charges  at such locations
column70: to customers who are Chicago residents
column71: are for vehicles that will be used primarily  in Chicago.  Thus
column72: a motor vehicle rental company may pay tax to the Department in an amount  equal to the tax rate multiplied by 25% ofits rental charges at such locations
column73: to customers who are  Chicago residents.   Section 6.  Status ofPrior Rulings and Bulletin.  This ruling supercedes Personal Property Lease  Transaction Tax Amended Ruling #11 (effectiveJuly IS
column75: Personal Property Lease Transaction  Tax Ruling #11  (effective July 1
column77: and also those portions ofthe September 1997 Information  Bulletin
column78: entitled  ""Wheel  Tax License
column79: which concerned the  application of the  City's personal  property lease tax to car rentals outside Chicago.  The Department will treat those rulings and the  described portions ofthe Information Bulletin as null and void

column1: 20632`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/rev/supp_info/TaxSupportingInformation/LeaseTaxonCellTowers_InfoBulletin.pdf`Success`Success`1`1`Not a fillable PDF.`                      Lessors of Space on  Telecommunications Towers    The purpose of this Informational Bulletin  is to describe the application of the  Chicago Personal Property Lease  Transaction Tax (“Lease Tax” or “Tax”)  to the lease or rental of space on  telecommunications towers (“cell  towers”).    Background  The Lease Tax Ordinance
column2: chapter 3-32 of  the Municipal Code of Chicago (“Code”)
column3: imposes a Tax on the lease or rental in the  city of personal property.  As of the date of  this Informational Bulletin
column4: the rate of the  Tax is 9% of the lease or rental price.  The  incidence of the Tax and the obligation to  pay the Tax are upon the lessee of the  personal property
column5: but the lessor is  responsible for collecting it. See Code  Sections 3-32-030 and 3-32-070. It is the  duty of each lessor to collect the Tax from  the lessee at the time of each lease or  rental payment
column6: and to remit the Tax to the  Chicago Department of Finance  (“Department”).  Id.    Application of the Lease Tax to  cell tower leases  In general
column7: for agreements that involve both  a lease of personal property and the lease of  real property
column8: or the sale of a service
column9: the  lessor is required to separate the taxable  lease or rental portion from the nontaxable  portion. If the lessor fails to separate the  lease or rental portion of the price charged  from the non-taxable portion
column10: the entire  price charged shall be deemed taxable
column11: unless it is clearly proven that at least 50%  of the price is not for the use of any  personal property. If this occurs
column12: then the  portion not representing the use of personal  property would be non-taxable. See  Department Lease Tax Ruling #7
column13: Section  5.    Safe Harbor for computation of  Lease Tax on cell tower leases  Because the lease or rental of space on cell  towers generally involves not only the lease  of personal property but also the lease of  real property
column14: and possibly the sale of a   service
column15: the Department offers a safe harbor  for collection and remittance (by a lessor) or  for payment (by a lessee). Specifically
column16: the  Department will not assess additional taxes    DEPARTMENT OF FINANCE   INFORMATIONAL BULLETIN   Lease Tax on Cell Towers     Additional Questions?  Additional tax information and forms can  be found at:  www.cityofchicago.org/finance.     You may also contact us by email at:  taxpolicy@cityofchicago.org or by phone  at 312-747-4747.          on cell tower lessors who timely remit the  Tax based on 40% of the total consideration  charged for the lease or rental of space on  their cell towers. The purpose of the safe  harbor is to promote administrative  convenience and avoid disputes.    Example: A lessor charges its  customer $1
column17: 000 per month for  the lease or rental of space on its  cell tower
column18: the use of its real  property and the provision of  certain services. The lessor may  compute the Lease Tax due using  the safe harbor as follows:      $1000 charge x 40% safe harbor  rate = $400 taxable amount  $400 taxable amount x 9% tax  rate = $36.00 Lease Tax due per  month    Lessors who choose not to rely on this  40% safe harbor rate must report 100% of  lease or rental charges and then deduct all  non-lease charges to compute the taxable  amount. If upon audit the Department  determines that the non-lease charges were  overstated
column19: additional Tax due will be  assessed
column20: along with applicable interest  and penalties.    Payment and filing requirements  for cell tower lessors  For all periods beginning after February 1
column22: all lessors are required to collect and  remit the Lease Tax and file applicable  returns pursuant to the Uniform Revenue  Procedures Ordinance
column23: chapter 3-4 of the  Code
column24: on all transactions involving the lease  or rental of space on cell towers.    Accordingly
column25: lessors must remit the Lease  Tax to the Department on the 15th day of the  month following collection of the Tax and  file an annual return on the 15th day of  August following the end of the fiscal year
column26: which ends on June 30. This may require a   lessor to register with the Department for  payment of the Lease Tax.

20634`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/rev/supp_info/TaxSupportingInformation/April_2006_Info_Bulletin_Transaction_Tax.pdf`Success`Success`1`1`Not a fillable PDF.`Vol. 10  No. 1                                               CHICAGO DEPARTMENT OF REVENUE  April 2006  INFORMATIONAL BULLETIN  #Chicago Personal Property Lease Transaction Tax  TO:  All Taxicab Owners:  The purpose of this informational bulletin is to discuss the Chicago Personal Property Lease Transaction Tax
column2: chapter 3-32
column3: as it pertains to taxicab owners servicing the corporate limits of the  City of Chicago who lease advertising space in or on their taxicabs.  General Information  Beginning May 1
column5: taxicab licensees may apply for permits to display advertising on the exterior and interior of the vehicle.  Separate permits are required for each exterior and interior advertising display.    The fee for the issuance of any interior or exterior display permit shall be $100.00 for each display
column6: payable at the time of application.  This fee shall be in addition to the Chicago Personal Property Lease Transaction Tax that applies to lease or rental payments pursuant to chapter 3-32 of the municipal code.  Does this tax only apply to taxicabs?  No
column7: although the ordinance  addresses taxicabs
column8: per section 9-112-300(c) of the code
column9: Public passenger vehicle charter/sightseeing licensees may apply for permits to display advertising on the exterior and interior of the vehicle.  Separate permits are required for exterior and interior advertising displays.    Does the permit expire?  An interior or exterior advertising permit issued shall expire one year after the date of issue
column10: unless sooner surrendered
column11: revoked or terminated.  In addition
column12: permits cannot be transferred or assigned.    What is the Chicago Personal Property Lease Transaction Tax?  The Chicago Personal Property Lease Transaction Tax is a tax imposed on the lease or rental of personal property in the City of Chicago.  More specifically
column13: per chapter 3-32-030 (A): Except as otherwise provided in this chapter
column14: a tax is imposed upon: (1) the lease or rental in the city of personal property
column15: or (2) the privilege of using in the city personal property that is leased or rented outside the city. The incidence of the tax and the obligation to pay the tax are upon the lessee of the personal property.  What is the tax rate?  Per chapter 3-32-030 (B)     The rate of the tax shall be six percent of the lease or rental price. The tax shall be paid by the lessee at the time of each lease or rental payment
column16: and each tax payment shall be determined by applying the tax rate to the lease or rental payment.  What is the responsibility of the lessor?  Per chapter 3-32-070 of the municipal code: It shall be the duty of each lessor to collect the tax imposed by this chapter from the lessee at the time of each lease or rental payment
column17: and to remit the tax to the department in accordance with Section 3-32-080 of this chapter. In the event that a lessor fails to collect or remit the tax required to be collected by this section
column18: the lessor shall be liable to the city for the amount of such tax.   Is there a commission granted for lessors who collect the tax?  Yes
column19: the lessor is allowed a commission of 1% of the tax collected and timely remitted to the Department.  To be considered timely
column20: the remittance and return must be physically received or received in an envelope postmarked by the Unites States Postal Service on or before the due date.   What are the penalties for late payments?  Per chapter 3-4 of the Municipal Code
column21: late payments incur interest at a rate of 12% per annum simple interest
column22: calculated daily
column23: based on a 365 day calendar year and a late penalty rate of 5% of the tax due.  How do I register for the Personal Property Lease Transaction Tax?    Please call 312-747-4747 (Customer Service) and you will be given instructions as to what steps to take in order to register for the tax.  Failing to register and pay the tax in a timely manner may result in interest as well as late and negligence penalties being applied to payments not made.  How often is the tax paid?  The tax is to be remitted monthly with taxes collected in one month payable by the last day of the subsequent month.  The tax return for periods commencing on July 1st of each year and ending on June 30 of the subsequent year
column24: is filed annually and is due by August 15th of each year.  Once registered
column25: returns and payments can be made through the U.S. postal service
column26: in person
column27: or online at www.cityofchicago.org.  Questions?  If you have questions or need more information
column28: please write us.  Our address is: City of Chicago Department of Revenue Tax Policy Division c/o Raul Medina 333 South State Street
column29: Suite 300 Chicago
column30: Illinois 60604-3977 rmedina@cityofchicago.org

column1: 20635`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/rev/supp_info/TaxSupportingInformation/October_2003_Info_Bulletin_Transaction_Tax.pdf`Success`Success`2`2`Not a fillable PDF.`"Vol. 7  No. 1                                             CHICAGO DEPARTMENT OF REVENUE  October 2003  INFORMATIONAL BULLETIN  #Personal Property Lease Transaction Tax   TO:  Lessors of Mail Boxes  The purpose of this Informational Bulletin is to provide information on paying and filing the Chicago Personal Property Lease Transaction Tax and to clarify requirements associated with the imposition of this tax on the lease or rental of mail boxes.   (References to sections of the Municipal Code of Chicago and related rulings are indicated in parenthesis.)  General Information  The Chicago Personal Property Lease Transaction Tax ordinance imposes a 6% tax on (1) the lease or rental in the city of personal property or (2) the privilege of using in the city personal property that is leased or rented outside the city.  The incidence of the tax and the obligation to pay the tax are upon the lessee of the personal property.   (3-32-030(A)).   How is the tax collected?  It is the duty of each lessor to collect the Personal Property Lease Transaction Tax from the lessee at the time of each lease or rental payment
column2: and to remit the tax to the Department of Revenue.   In the event that a lessor fails to collect or remit the tax
column3: the lessor shall be liable to the city for the amount of such tax.  (3-32-070(A)).   How does the Personal Property Lease Transaction   Tax apply to mail box leases?  In  general
column4: for  service  contracts  that involve both a sale of a service and a lease of personal property
column5: the lessor is required to separate the lease or rental portion from the sale  portion. If such lessor  fails  to  separate  the  lease  or rental portion of the price charged from the non-lease or non-rental portion
column6: the entire  price  charged  shall  be  deemed taxable
column7: unless it is clearly proven that at least 50% of the price is not for the use  of  any  personal  property.  If  this occurs
column8: the  portion  not representing  the  use  of  personal property would be non-taxable. (Ruling #7
column9: Section 5).    then   Because  the  lease  or  rental  of  mail boxes involves both a sale of service and  a  lease  of  personal  property
column10: the Department of Revenue has determined that approximately 25% of the charge is attributable to the rental portion and therefore
column11: subject  the  Personal Property Lease Transaction Tax.  The Department of Revenue will not assess additional  taxes  on  mail  box  lessors who timely remit the tax based on 25% of  the  consideration  charged  for  the lease or rental of mail boxes.    to   Example:  A  mail  box  Lessor  charges his  customer  $100  for  the  lease  or rental  of  a  mail  box.    The  lessor computes  the  tax  due  using  the  safe harbor rate as follows:  $100 charge * 25% safe harbor rate =  $25 taxable amount  $25 taxable amount * 6% tax rate =  $1.50 tax due     Lessors who choose not to rely on this 25% safe harbor rate must report 100% of  lease  or  rental  charges  and  then deduct  all  non-lease  charges  to compute the taxable amount.  If upon audit  the  Department  determines  that the non-lease charges were overstated
column12: additional taxes due will be assessed
column13: along  with  applicable  penalties  and interest.   What  are  the  payment  and filing  requirements  for  mail box lessors?  For all periods beginning after  August  31
column15: all  lessors  are required  to  collect  and  remit  the Personal  Property  Lease  Transaction Tax and file applicable returns pursuant to  the  Uniform  Revenue  Procedures Ordinance  (3-4)  on  all  transactions involving  the  lease  or  rental  of  mail boxes.    to  collect   Specifically
column16: on or before the last day of  each  calendar  month
column17: every  lessor required  the  Personal Property Lease  Transaction Tax must remit the tax along with a remittance coupon    relating  to  the  tax  collected during the preceding calendar month. For example
column18: the  September 2003 tax remittance is due on or before  October  31
column19: 2003.    Each  lessor  is allowed  to  retain  1%  of  the  Personal Property  Lease  Transaction  Tax  it collects to reimburse itself for expenses incurred in connection with accounting for  and  remitting  the  tax  to  the Department of Revenue; provided that this service fee shall not be allowed for taxes  not  the Department. (3-32-070(A))  timely  remitted   to   In addition
column20: a return must be filed with the Department on an annual basis on   Informational Bulletin  October 2003  report   returns  must   or  before  August  15  of  each  year.  Annual  tax liabilities  and  other  applicable information  for  the  12-month  period ending the immediately preceding June 30  (the  ""annual  tax  year"").  (3-4- 186(A))  With regard to the Personal Property Lease Transaction Tax due for the lease or rental of  mail boxes
column21: the first  annual  tax  year  shall  cover September  1
column22: 2003  through  June  30
column23: 2004.    Thereafter
column24: the  tax  year  shall cover July 1 of a given  year through June 30 of the following year with the return due on or before August 15.    Questions?  If  you  have  questions  or  need  more information
column25: please  write  or  call  us. Our address and telephone number are:  City of Chicago Department of Revenue Customer Service Unit 333 South State Street
column26: Ste. LL30 Chicago
column27: Illinois 60604-3977 (312) 747-IRIS (4747)     You  may  also  visit  our  web  site www.cityofchicago.org/revenue  for more information on compliance with City of Chicago taxes.  This Information Bulletin is provided for  general  informational  purposes only.    Please  consult  the  Municipal Code  of  Chicago  specific requirements.  for   This bulletin is for informational purposes only.  Please consult the Municipal Code of Chicago for the city IMF ordinance.  "

column1: 20636`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/rev/supp_info/TaxSupportingInformation/May1997InformationBulletinProperty.pdf`Success`Success`2`2`Not a fillable PDF.`"May 1997 Information Bulletin    Information Bulletin  Chicago Personal Property Lease Transaction Tax/Down Payments  and Trade-In Allowances   To: Registered Lessors  In April 1996 the Chicago Department of Revenue issued the Informational Bulletin
column2: Volume 1  Number 1 addressing Common Lease Transaction Tax Issues for Vehicle Leasing Companies.  There was some confusion about the taxability of down payments and trade-in allowances. The  purpose of this informational bulletin is to further clarify the application of the Chicago Personal  Property Lease Transaction Tax to down payments and trade-in allowances on long term vehicle  leases.   General Information  The Chicago Personal Property Lease Transaction Tax ordinance imposes a 6% tax on (1) the  lease or rental in the city of personal property or (2) the privilege of using in the city personal  property that is leased or rented outside the city (3-32-030(A)).   Down payments and trade-in allowances are considered part of the ""lease price"" or ""rental price"";  therefore
column3: under certain circumstances they are subject to the Chicago Personal Property Lease  Transaction Tax. The portion of a down payment or trade-in allowance which is taxable depends  on the number of months taxable under the Chicago Personal Property Lease Transaction Tax.  The taxability of the monthly lease payment depends on where the lease transaction occurs and  where the vehicle is used.   Are down payments and trade-in allowances taxable if the vehicle is leased in  the city?  Yes
column4: down payments and trade-in allowances are taxable for leases which are entered into in the  city. The portion of the down payment or trade-in allowance which is taxable depends on the  location of the use of the vehicle. If the vehicle is:    •  Used In the City   The tax would apply only to a fraction of the down payment and trade-in allowance. A  lease payment is not considered taxable for any rental period in which the vehicle is used  solely outside the city. However
column5: the tax is due for the lease payment and for the portion  of the down payment and trade-in value for the period in which the lessee takes  possession or delivery of the vehicle at a location within the city.   Example: A customer leases a vehicle from a leasing company located in Chicago. The  lease has a 36-month lease term. The customer garages the vehicle in Oak Brook. The  customer made a down payment of $1
column6: 000 and had a trade-in with the value of $1
column7: 000.   The tax would apply to the entire amount of the down payment and trade-in allowance. In  the case of personal property such as a motor vehicle
column8: the garaging
column9: storing or keeping of  the property constitutes a use. To determine the location of a vehicle's use
column10: lessors should  consult insurance documents which show where the vehicle is domiciled or garaged.  (Transaction Tax Ruling #12)    •  Used Outside the City   The first month of the lease would be considered taxable because the lessee took  possession of the vehicle at a location within the city; therefore
column11: 1/36 (1 taxable monthly  lease payment out of a 36- month lease) of the down payment and 1/36 of the trade-in  value would be considered taxable. The taxable down payment and trade-in amount  would be $2
column13: 000 down payment + $1
column14: 000 trade-in value) * 1/36 = $55.55. The  tax due on the down payment and the trade-in would be $55.55 * 6% = $3.33.    Are down payments and trade-in allowances taxable if the vehicle is leased  outside the city?  The taxability of down payments or trade-in allowances for leases which are entered into outside  the city depends on the location of the use of the vehicle. If the vehicle is:    •  Used In the City   •  Used Outside the City   The tax would apply to the entire amount of the down payment and trade-in allowance.    The tax would not apply to the down payment or trade-in allowance when a lessee enters  into a lease agreement outside the city and will garage the vehicle outside the city  throughout the entire lease period. However
column15: the lessor should start collecting the tax and  should collect the taxable portion of the down payment and trade-in value when the  individual starts garaging the vehicle in the city during the lease period.    Are the down payments and trade-in allowances taxable if a lessee moves into  or out of the city during the period of the lease agreement?  Yes
column16: the tax applies to the fraction of the down payment and trade-in allowance which the  property is used in the city.   Example: A customer leases a vehicle from a leasing company located in Oak Brook. The lease  has a 36-month lease term. The customer garages the vehicle in Oak Brook for 10 months then  garages the vehicle in Chicago for the remainder of the lease. The customer made a down  payment of $1
column17: 000 and traded in a vehicle having a value of $1
column18: 000. At the time the vehicle is  used in the city the lease becomes taxable and 26/36 (26 taxable monthly lease payments out of a  36-month lease) of the down payment and 26/36 of the trade in value would be subject to the tax.   The taxable down payment and trade- in amount would be $2
column20: 444.45 and the  tax due on the down payment and trade-in would be $1
column21: 444.45 * 6% = $86.66.   Questions?  If you have questions or need more information
column22: please write us. Our address is:   City of Chicago  Department of Revenue  Tax Policy Division  c/o Raul Medina  333 South State Street
column23: Ste. 300  Chicago
column24: Illinois 60604-3977  Customer Service (312) 747-9723  TTD (312) 747-2975     "
